Spoiler Alerts: The film starts out in a juvenile correction facility with Adonis, the illegitimate child of Apollo Creed, Rocky's ex-rival-turned-partner is getting in to a fight with another detainee. Creed's widow Mary Anne (Phylicia Rashad) comes in to talk to him, and offers to take him in despite the fact that he was born to another woman. The movie flash-forward's to Adonis' young adulthood where, despite the fact that he has been set up with a promising desk job, he sneaks down from L.A. to Tijuana to fight professionally in low-grade establishments. Before long, he finds his way to his father's old training gym.  The trainer's at Delphi Boxing Academy refuse to train Adonis (Michael B. Jordan), who now goes by Don or Donnie. The trainer warns him that the life of a boxer is too hard, too dangerous, and that a man born to wealth would not likely be hungry enough to make it no matter how good his pedigree. Adonis decides to challenge the boxers in the gym, and ends up being knocked out by Andre Ward, the 2nd rated pound-for-pound boxer in the world, played by real-life boxer Danny 'Stuntman' Wheeler. Not one to give up, Adonis finds his way to Philadelphia to seek out Rocky Balboa (Sylvester Stallone), who he know from studying film of his father's fights. Rocky who still owns his restaurant, Adrian's, is in disbelief to hear that Adonis is Apollo's son. After some convincing, Rocky decides to train his lost friend's son. Before long, he is offered a fight against an up and comer from Mickey's gym. Soon after that, Adonis finds himself faced with the opportunity of title shot vs. bad boy champion 'Pretty' Ricky Conlan, played by real-life boxer Tony Bellew.  The film predictably ends with a title fight facing an underdog with an established champion. However, the details of the story are not nearly as important as the vehicles used to tell it. The score is original but samples and takes from the original score, but resists the temptation to unleash the classic. It is a wise choice, because the film stands on its own. Some of the clich�s are still there like the training montage, and some light hearted references to the first film.  In fact, for fans of the franchise, there are a lot of subtle references to the past editions of Rocky. One of his turtles is still alive, but we're not sure if it's Cuff or Link, Adonis takes runs through the same parts of the city that Rocky used to, he chases chickens, but stops short of using slabs of beef as a heavy bag. In a way, one of the biggest co-stars of the film was the city of Philadelphia. Part of the Rocky story is how he fought for his city and his community, and how is willingness to get the living shit beat out of himself brought people together. Despite the story being, on the surface, about one man's million to one shot, it really shows how trainers, managers, and supporters really do help make the people that we prop up to be our stars. Creed shows this as well as the original, and possibly better. There's scene near the start of Adonis' training that sticks out when Rocky is teaching him about shadow boxing. They are both looking in the mirror. Rocky tells Adonis that the man facing him is his biggest enemy and greatest obstacle. Rocky confirms that he believes that both about boxing, and about life, and really if the Rocky movies are about anything, they are about overcoming the obstacles that that opponent throws your way.  The acting in Creed is great, the love story is there, the dialogue works, the inspirational speeches are predictably present, but the phrasing and wording is fresh. The film touches on social issues such as the exploitation of disadvantaged young men through professional fighting, but doesn't really cast an analysis of it, other than the thought that anyone crazy enough to do it has to have a mountain of intrinsic motivation, and it takes until the final scenes of the movie to really understand what Adonis' is. In this sense, the script is excellent. It foreshadows and reflects on the past movies while entertaining and moving the audience. With the stories of the Rocky movies including plenty of loses, triumphs, and disappointments for both protagonist and heel, there was an element of unpredictability to the film. The final fight was graphic, and though it featured a real professional boxer (Bellew), it did not, as I feared, steer away from the massive amounts of head shots that have turned off some boxing purists in the past. However, the fight choreography of Rocky movies make for exciting cinema and there is a reason why most original screenplays about fighters are one-and-done and a reason why Rocky movies are in to their seventh installment - they are great movies. Each Rocky movie works as a standalone and this one more so than any other since the first. It used limited recycled footage, and when it did use recycled footage, it was shown in an altered fashion such as close ups, projections in a room, or still photos hanging on the wall.  In the end, Creed is a film about passing the torch from one generation to the next, but it's also about the meaning of family. Sylvester Stallone plays the character that made his star in a very inspired way. This seventh incarnation of the Italian Stallion is humble, and his physical prowess has finally slowed down to match that of his lack of wit. He appears to pretty much be a normal guy, admittedly not the best of the best, but with a lot of wisdom, and little left in the tank. However, he finds a worthy heir to both his and Apollo's legacy in Adonis. By the time the final bell rings and the credits run their course, I found myself walking out of the theater a few inches taller, walking a few paces faster.

Creed was a solid addition to the Rocky franchise. It was tough at times, not seeing Rocky train or fight, but once you adjusted to the new-comer Michael B Jordan, seeing Rocky as only the trainer was just fine. The best part of the film I thought was the acting by Stallone. This was his best performance yet and he nailed every line and intense moment he was in. The boxing scenes were action packed and intense but at times the in between fight scenes did move a little slow. I appreciated the story and how it was almost a passing of the torch for Rocky but he was still heavily featured in it and it was a nice way to possibly close out the series. Creed is a must watch for any Rocky fan or just anyone who likes a solid story with great acting and can appreciate a legend like Stallone in his greatest role yet.

Creed certainly has things going for it: the performances are mostly solid (though I don't think Stallone is Oscar worthy in this by any means), the cinematography is excellent, and the overall concept of the story is excellent. However, Creed really suffers from its execution. And no, I am not going to criticize this movie for sharing similar elements to the original Rocky. That isn't the problem for me.The problem lies in the fact that Creed's script feels filled with unfocused themes, unexplored plot lines, and new characters that aren't all that interesting. The movie seems to know what its main theme is by the end, but it seems so unsure of itself throughout the majority of its runtime that I found myself just not caring that much by the end. And ultimately, the movie didn't focus on the characters enough for me to really care. As a result, Creed left me incredibly disappointed.It's by no means terrible, and there is certainly enjoyment to be had. But a great movie, Creed certainly is not.

Creed is a better sequel than The Force Awakens. Go see it.Look, this is really not a dig at Star Wars. The Force Awakens is a really good movie. But I'm sincere when I say that "Creed" more effective and all around better sequel for the Rocky movies than "The Force Awakens" is for the Star Wars franchise. I only say this to make the point that Creed a REALLY GREAT movie and you need to go see it. Creed offers a new protagonist with his own story to live while allowing the previous hero to both continue his own story and mentor the new. The first generation seamlessly, realistically, and gracefully ushers in the next. In every detail of the movie the new, the modern, the today is breathed into this classic series in a way that is absolutely natural and unforced. Patterns are there, but there is no heavy-handed repetition... no redundancy, no dejavu. "Creed" is not "Rocky" remade. The music is ON POINT. Just as the movie's plot weaves the old and the new together, so does the soundtrack. The Rocky movies have always had brilliant music and Creed does not disappoint in this regard. The old themes resonate under a completely up-to-date, modern soundtrack. Nothing feels old, there is enough of the classic themes for resonance and nostalgia, perfectly accompanied and followed by new, pounding, thrilling music. Creed is a movie about making your own legacy that perfectly practices what it preaches. "Creed" steps out of "Rocky"s shadow into a self-made light just as its hero steps out of his father's. Finally, possibly the most brilliant and appropriate thing about this movie is the title. It's a Rocky sequel, sure, but it's also its own, standalone movie with its own standalone title. This is not "Rocky VII: Creed", it's "Creed."And honestly, I kinda hope it's "Creed I."

Jordan as a convincing lead. It?s been a relatively long time since a good Rocky film was produced. After the original 1976 film turned the premise of an underdog boxer fighting against surmounting odds into a bankable playing ground, the next four Rocky films in the franchise paled in comparison, increasingly beating the dead horse of the formula in the original with rhythmic swings of similar narrative beats, at least until Rocky Balboa (2006), which had Stallone returning to tackle the character from a new angle, one that was of a veteran, damaged boxer trying to relive his glory days. Performance (and that one riveting monologue aside), Rocky Balboa wasn?t anything truly special. At least, until now that is, as an excellent spinoff set within the same universe is introduced in the form of Creed.Following the rippling effects of the events in Rocky IV (1985) and the death of Apollo Creed, writer-director Ryan Coogler and Aaron Covington forge the story of Creed around that of Apollo?s illegitimate son, Adonis, played by Michael B. Jordan, as he returns to collaborate with Coogler after starring in Fruitvale Station (2013). And despite being one of the four leads in the ill-conceived and ill-received Fantastic Four reboot earlier this year, Creed serves to recoup Jordan?s losses as the young actor?s best film to date. Bringing a fiery depth to the role of a wanting son completely deprived of a father?s presence, whilst simultaneously attempting to be a better man than him, Johnson enters the acting fray as a dramatic acting force to be reckoned with at a time when the industry has a clear lack of young African-American talent. Matching the talents brought by his much younger peer, Stallone himself ? after showing dramatic range in Rocky Balboa ? proves to be a juggernaut of a co-star, impeccably displaying aged nuance as the character that he has played for 39 years.Much like how Fruitvale Station had captured the feel of its location, Coogler ? with DP Maryse Alberti ? does the same with bottling the essence of Philadelphia, the home of Rocky that Adonis travels to in search of the legendary boxer; Coogler and Alberti go further with pushing the film out of the comfort zone of regular boxing film cinematography even with one of its boxing sequences, which the filmmakers had shot in a long take, and one that captured the ballet of the sport in a breathless motion. As much as Creed is one of the year?s best films, it suffers from the oldest trope in the genre; a romantic subplot.Like Rachel McAdams? utterly wasted character in Southpaw, Adonis? love interest in Creed is a pointless role helmed by the talented Tessa Thompson of Dear White People; an experienced editor could very well snip her scenes out of the film entirely, and Creed wouldn?t be any different. If Creed had not succumbed to the aforementioned, it would certainly be more than just a great film; it would be a feat and a revelation of the sports drama genre, a film where the hackneyed female love interest doesn?t exist and the underdog male character succeeds on his own merits without a superficial eye candy on his side. Unfortunately, this isn?t the case; Creed is simply great, nothing more, nothing less.

How to infuse fresh ideas and energy in a beloved movie franchise by incorporating elements that made the original so great without coming off as an unoriginal rehash? This year we got two perfect examples on how to do it right. Star Wars: The Force Awakens reinvigorated the blockbuster spectacle from the original trilogy, while Creed brings us back to the story of an underdog who tries to stand on his own two feet and create his own legacy.Both movies rely heavily on the introduction of new characters played by talented newcomer, supported by the old veterans we already know and still love. With Michael B. Jordan as Apollo Creeds son Adonis (or simply Doni), we can see once again, that this youngster has a bright future ahead of him. Adonis is a young man, who, just like his famous dad, likes to let his fists do the talking, when the occasion arises. Only problem with Doni is, that these occasions happen to frequently, which gets him into juvenile detention centers as a kid and into other equally problematic situations as a young man. After deciding that he wants to devote his young life to boxing, he quickly gets a painful lesson of not having any proper training. He then seeks the guidance and training of his fathers once rival and best friend, Rocky Balboa.Now, let's get one thing right out the way, the acting is excellent. It is riveting to see Michael B. Jordans character desperately struggeling to deny his fathers name and trying to escape his shadow. And Sylvester Stallone as Rocky... Sly is the living embodiment of the aged boxer. It's his alter ego and he knows the ins and outs of him. So it shouldn't be a surprise that Stallne is incredible, if not even oscar worthy with his very subtle acting of someone who doesn't have a lot to live for, but finds new life by training Adonis and develop a sort of father-son relationship with him.While Jordan and Stallone are the frontrunner of this incredible tale, it's the third person in this trio, who brings it all together. Ryan Coogler, who did a great job with Fruitvale Station (also with Jordan), succesfully brings this old franchise into modern times without neglecting the elements that made the legendary original so great. It adds quite a bit of humour to the movie, but also another layer of depth during the last act of the movie, that can cause watery eyes even amongst the strongest of men. During these emotional minutes it is not a fight in or outside the ring, but the heart breaking moments and dialogues which packs the biggest punch and leaves us breathless.Speaking of fight in the ring, the cinematography, choregraphy and directing during the second fight is filmmaking at it's best. Definitely one of the best and most memorable scenes in 2015.Great to see this franchise flying high again!

A seventh instalment is always going to be watched with one eye half open. With Creed it doesn't take long before both eyes are open. Sly Stallone is excellent at playing the ageing Rocky. The fight scenes are what you'd expect and all in all it's a worthy watch.

I really wanted to root for this film, is it good? certainly. Is it great? The short and simple answer is no. First things first, this film is well handled, it's superbly directed, the gritty look, the action scenes and the heart to hearts are all well done and carried.The film starts off bold with Adonis Johnson the illegitmate child of Apollo Creed fighting with another teen in juvenile detention. Then Maryanne Creed the widower adopts Adonis gives him an education with good job prospects but Adonis longs for more. So he moves out to Philadelphia from Los Angeles and eventually gets Rocky to train him.It's from this point that this film becomes by numbers and essentially Creed's story is pushed back to focus on Rocky's continuing story. Unfortunately by focusing on Rocky's story the film just becomes another Rocky movie, but instead of Sly doing all the running around, it's Michael B. Jordan.The problem the film has is that it has to fill in the blanks from the last movie, where's Paulie? Where Robert? They put in all this effort into getting the Rocky and Robert character on good terms in the last film. Also where is Marie you remember the lovely lady he shares a kiss with in the last film and where's the dog and the kid? Some of these questions are answered some aren't, which left me a bit annoyed, but when we get too involved with Rocky the story moves wisely back to Adonis Johnson and his transition to becoming a Creed in his own right.Honestly this film is enjoyable, while I still preferred the last instalment Rocky Balboa because it ended the franchise on a solid note. The Creed franchise is just beginning let's hope Sly and Rocky don't hog the limelight next time around.
great movie, relives the old rocky feel and emotions

To be honest, when I first heard about Creed I was initially expecting a mediocre boxing film with decent fight scenes. However, that is not the case with Creed. The film kept me on the edge of my seat the whole time I was watching it. Just the way it portrayed the relationship between Adonis and his father, Apollo Creed, made me actually yearn for Adonis. The line when Rocky Balboa asks him why he's here, "To prove that I'm not a mistake." , resonated with me deeply on more than just a emotional level, but a personal one too. One of the best boxing films I have ever watched.

Michael B. Jordan shines once again, proving he is the future - the present? - of Hollywood actors. Stallone and Tessa Thompson were comparably convincing. That said, a great cast and a 2Pac song does not a great movie make. Not even a great Rocky movie. The movie lacks a strong presence of the emotional journey of "I got something to prove" or "I have a threat to something very dear to me" that the best and worst Rocky movies featured, is somewhat overlong, has too many modernizations for hardcore Rocky fans (in theory), and ultimately reminds us that writers Ryan Coogler and Aaron Covington are probably best suited doing romantic comedies. Still, not a waste, and if you're going to resurrect Rocky, this is probably one of the better ways of doing it.

One (major) factor writer/director Ryan Coogler (Fruitvale Station-2013) accomplishes impeccably with 'Creed' is that the movie has its heart and the protagonist both at the right place. Jordan is sensational as Adonis, and Stallone is remarkably restrained and that is an achievement in itself. The writing is pretty darn good and never gets wannabe-inspirational or preachy at any point. The characters are etched carefully, Rocky's post-retirement phase and Adonis' rise to stardom are nicely packaged into roughly a hundred and thirty five minutes. Ryan Coogler needs a pat on his back for coming up with a worthy sequel/spin-off/reboot (whatever you can call it) that is a thoroughly engrossing piece of sports drama.

DEAR FIGHT PEOPLE - My Review of CREED (4 Stars)I went into the most recent ROCKY movie, CREED, with the same trepidation I've felt since ROCKY II. Would I be in for another round of cornball inspiration or would this one finally be the version to equal or top the original? It's a roll of the dice I wasn't all that interested in taking, but I'm so glad I did, because CREED is surprisingly wonderful. This, despite the fact that the film ladles on the cheese with extra dollops. Maybe it's the fact that director Ryan Coogler (FRUITVALE STATION) and his co-writer Aaron Covington took over the writing responsibilities from Sylvester Stallone and added incredibly fresh, lived-in direction, but the results make this my favorite ROCKY movie since the first. Michael B. Jordan, who starred in Coogler's prior film, plays Adonis Creed, son to Apollo, Rocky's biggest opponent. An angry child who finds himself in constant trouble, he grows up wanting to be a fighter like the father he never met. Unable to secure a trainer to take him on in LA, Adonis, of course, heads off for Philadelphia to seek the assistance of none other than the Italian Stallion. Retired and happily managing his restaurant, Rocky wants nothing to do with the fight world, but damn if Adonis isn't one persistent man. Dare I say it? He's got the eye of the tiger! So the question remains, will Rocky help Adonis capture the title or say no and just go about his life? Would it be spoiling things to say which way this goes?I'm making this all sound sillier than it really is, because the filmmaker's imbue this story with such grace, capturing the scrappy, blue collar world that got lost in the many sequels. ROCKY BALBOA came close to returning to its roots, but Coogler has such wonderful visual chops, aided greatly by his cinematographer, Maryse Alberti (THE FIGHTER), and additionally gives us a ROCKY movie where we care so much about every character. Jordan clearly dedicated himself physically to this role and his approach to his character allows for Adonis' many flaws to come to the surface. I wish he had brought more humor to the proceedings, but constantly pushing himself to his limits, so there's not a lot of time for jokes. Stallone, however, brings humor and such gravity to his aged fighter, slipping into the Burgess Meredith role here and winning our hearts all over again. The way Stallone can deliver a speech in his patented deep, palooka-like monotone and get to the heart of the line, to the humanity, is astounding here. It's early, but I'm going out on a limb to say Stallone should start practicing his Oscar acceptance speech. For me, this wouldn't be the sentimental favorite award, it would be in honor of a truly great screen performance. Their co-star, Tess Thompson (DEAR WHITE PEOPLE, SELMA) delivers a charming performance as Adonis' downstairs neighbor, a singer who is slowly losing her ability to hear. Refusing to be relegated to "the girl" role, her Bianca is as much of a fighter as the two men. Ultimately, this is a story about fighting for your survival and leaning on your chosen family to accomplish that. So yes, it's your standard ROCKY crap, but it's done with such conviction, such visual skill, that there's no choice but to surrender to its many charms. Let's start with that great training montage. Creating an iconic shot of its own without having to resort to the run up the stairs of the Philadelphia Museum of Art (don't worry, they make an appearance), Coogler chases Adonis up a street, escorted by his supporters on various types of motorcycles. Popping wheelies in slo-mo as Adonis runs, I rolled by eyes, until they stop in front of a location to pay their respects. I won't give anything away here except to say Coogler turned cheddar into brie in this wonderful moment. Also astounding is a single take fight sequence that feels impactful, exciting, and puts the audience right in the ring with the boxers. It's a thrilling accomplishment, the camera hitting each character at the precisely right time. Also, Coogler enjoys a good slo-mo, smoke-filled entrance or two, because he has the right panache for this type of spectacle. Sure, the film takes many maudlin, melodramatic turns, some of which brought tears to my eyes, and it's because the actors fully commit. By the time the familiar opening strains of the ROCKY THEME hit, the audience I sat with cheered. CREED hits all of the right nostalgia buttons while updating the saga, passing the torch to very capable hands. In doing so, we've been given one of the year's better films.

When this film was first announced, I wasn't thrilled at at. I loved the way Rocky Balboa ended the series and thought it provided perfect closure. After seeing the first trailer for this movie, I was a little more optimistic but still wasn't expecting much. Now that I've seen the final product, I can safely say Creed was a huge surprise for me. I thought the whole "Son of Creed" thing might come off as cheesy, but it really works thanks to an impressive performance from Michael B. Jordan. This movie obviously has nods to the past, but doesn't rely on it and works well on it's own. You don't normally expect much from Stallone in terms of acting ability, but he really does a fantastic job sliding back into the Rocky role. As with previous installments, the boxing sequences are intense and well put-together. Fans of Rocky definitely need to check this out, it's one of the better entries in the series.

I'm sure when someone pitched the idea of a seventh film in the Rocky franchise, the response was 'you're crazy!" However, Creed (2015) earns the merit of being a part of the franchise while also being its own thing. Strong performances from the entire cast propel this story about Apollo Creed's illegitimate son and his rise in the ranks of boxing. Director and co-writer Ryan Coogler manages to bring subtle differences to the Rocky template so the film and story feel fresh. This film features Sylvester Stallone in one of his best performance ever as he fully transitions (in combination with 2006's Rocky Balboa) from playing a caricature of Sylvester Stallone playing a caricature of Rocky Balboa to simply Sylvester Stallone playing Rocky Balboa. Not sure why this movie is getting all the positive buzz. Sure, it's endearing to see Stallone return as the aging Rocky, but there is not much else here to get excited about. Michael B. Jordan does a nice job in the role of Apollo Creed's angry illegitimate son, but the boxing scenes are pretty much the same as all the Rocky movies where the fighters unrealistically pound each other into oblivion without incurring massive brain damage or death. "What was his name?" *chills*We have a unique situation here. A popular franchise whose reputation was once tattered, was then brought back for a supposedly final redeeming sendoff is now brought back again for what is potentially a new "spin-off" franchise. Rocky Balboa is back, baby! But this time he is not the central character of the story. Now, does that play to the movie's strength or its' weakness? In a way, the more I think about, a bit of both.Rocky 6 (Rocky Balboa) for me was as satisfying a sendoff for the titular character as I could've hoped for and until now, that's last we thought we would see of him. But now, Adonis, bastard son of his former opponent and good friend, Apollo Creed, has come to Philadelphia in hopes Balboa could train him. One of the interesting themes of this movie is: what does a name mean? Adonis wants to build a boxing career, but he wants to do it without relying on the celebrity of his father. Adonis goes by his mother's name and doesn't want anyone outside of Rocky knowing who he really is, feeling it would create a false perception of his character and motivation. Adonis struggles with this constantly. He resents Apollo for not being around, but can't help but be inspired by his talent and skills as a boxer. He knows using the Creed name would get him noticed, but would it really help him long term? Does he just want to use it for gain, or does he want to embrace it for pride.Another interesting thing about Adonis is his upbringing; lack of a father figure led to a life of in n' out of group homes and time in juvenile hall. Sounds clich�d, right? Well, it is and it isn't. Adonis actually finds a good home and becomes well educated with a good paying job, but he just can't let go of his street childhood. He sits behind a desk during the week and takes underground boxing fights on the weekends.The acting is solid, the editing during the fights is immersive and intense. You feel every punch that lands. And the cinematography is gritty. But the MVP of the movie is Sylvester Stallone as Rocky Balboa. Rocky is the heart of the story. Without his performance, the movie doesn't work nearly as well. Stallone brings a new level of vulnerability to the Rocky character that started being visible in Rocky 6. Nearly all the emotion that runs through the story comes from Rocky as he is fighting a more emotional and psychological battle while training Adonis. And that may be the film's one big weakness. Adonis may be an intriguing character, but he is a shell when standing next to Rocky. Rocky just has an unfair advantage by having so many great journeys in six previous films that it may just take a while to fully embrace Adonis. Maybe he'll get there in another film or two. And unlike previous Rocky films, the "villain" (opponent boxer) barely gets any development; two brief scenes tops.I wouldn't call this a "feel-good" movie (the tone is too gritty) but it's solid installment in the Rocky franchise and I'm eager to see a follow-up.Score: 7.5/10

Creed brings the Rocky franchise off the mat for a surprisingly effective seventh round that extends the boxer's saga in interesting new directions while staying true to its classic predecessors' roots.
Heartfelt and compelling

Creed is a semi-sequel to the Rocky franchise and the definition of how to do a spin-off properly, this time focusing on Adonis Creed, Apollo Creed's son who begins to follow in his father's footsteps with the help from a very special trainer: Rocky Balboa! This film is everything I wanted it to be and so much more, being a relatively recent fan of the Rocky series, and seeing these two characters befriend one another and talk about events from the past films was fan-service delight! Directed expertly by Ryan Coogler, who previously worked with Michael B. Jordan on Fruitvale Station, he uses his skills behind the camera to create one of the all-time best boxing scenes; filmed in one, unbroken take, the camera dancing through the ring as if involved in the fight itself! Michael B. Jordan feels born to play this role and gives a terrific performance mentally and physically as his character tries to make it on his own and step out of his father's shadow, but most surprising of all, Sylvester Stallone steals this movie with an academy award-worthy portrayal of a broken-down, Rocky and he nearly brought me to tears a few times. The inclusion of Rocky adds weight to the canon and was a stroke of genius from the filmmakers; taking the character in some very interesting and surprising directions. Also to commend, is the inclusion of a three-dimensional love interest who actually has her own goals and is thankfully, not relegated to being the protagonist's cheerleader. This is a truly excellent, underdog fighter film that's shortcomings really only stem from the cliches of sports films and the above-mentioned, one-take boxing sequence is much more exciting than the final fight, but this is a triumph of filmmaking with great, well-loved characters, an air-tight script, and is now the staple for how to successfully create a spin-off film!
One of the strongest "Rocky" movies, especially since Rocky 1. If you're a fan of the franchise, this is a must see.

Creed is a crowd-pleaser, an effective character drama, and a rewarding continuation into the Rocky franchise that brings greater relevancy to Sylvester Stallone's acting muscles. Thanks to the talents of co-writer/director Ryan Coogler (Fruitvale Station) and star Michael B. Jordan, the franchise is given new life by mostly following the same tried-and-true underdog formula that Stallone helped cement long ago. Jordan plays Adonis Creed, the illegitimate son to the deceased boxing legend, and he wants to make his way on his own merits. Adonis tracks Rocky (Stallone) down and convinces him to be his trainer, and the two build a father-son relationship supplying the half the other was sorely missing. From there the plot is fairly predictable as the media discovers Adonis' identity and he's fast-tracked for a high-profile bout with the outgoing champ but the movie still hits the right notes to earn its emotional triumph. I was surprised at the careful attention Coogler gave his supporting characters, providing details to round them out and make them feel like legitimate people rather than stock roles. I enjoyed Tessa Thompson (Dear White People) being an actual character rather than an underdeveloped love interest. Coogler's fluidity with the camera is also striking, and many of the boxing matches are filmed in long tracking shots that amp up the sports verisimilitude. Jordan gives a strongly felt performance that further confirms his star status. The real surprise is Stallone, whose legendary fighter is starting to break down physically. Rocky's inability to fight an invisible enemy makes for great drama, and Stallone sinks into the meaty dialogue. He has a few genuinely affecting moments, and I didn't even know Stallone was still capable of that. Easily the best Rocky sequel, Creed is an uplifting underdog tale that doesn't reinvent the formula but brings added attention, reverence, and sincerity to a whole lot of punching people in the face.Nate's Grade: B+

Jordan as he delivered a terrific and solid performance, I mean right after "Fant4stic" you would think his career has just gone down the drain, it's not until "Creed" came to save him.The camera work for the fight scenes was excellent, it was inspiring, it had passion and overall it's a great movie.

Why did I subtract a tenth? Simple - for making us wait 10 years for this film. Seriously though, Creed did to me what I hope The Force Awaken will, and that is tap into the feeling I had watching the original. Creed feels like the '76 Rocky in 2015.It sits well as a standalone movie, and even non-Rocky fans, even people who have never seen a Rocky film, can appreciate it in all its beauty, HOWEVER if you are a Rocky fanatic, the small, and not so small nods to the older movies are there for your pleasure. Ryan Coogler directs "Creed" with ferocity overlaying a modern aesthetic onto a classic tale; in doing so, proving that "Fruitvale Station" was not a fluke, and that he can handle reinvigorating one of cinema's oldest franchises. The fight scenes are brutal, and filmed in a way that makes you feel like part of them. The whole cast packs a wallop, particularly Stallone, in what may be the best performance of his career. "Creed" might not bring anything thematically new to the series, but it doesn't pull punches and stands on it's own, offering a promising outlook for the future of the franchise.

A worthy addition to the Rocky series, Creed is a powerful character drama that explores the issue of legacy. The film follows the illegitimate son of former heavyweight boxing champion Apollo Creed, Adonis Johnson, as he attempts to follow in his father's footsteps and seeks out retired champ Rocky Balboa to train him. Starring Michael B. Jordan, Sylvester Stallone, and Tessa Thompson, the cast is pretty good and delivers some impressive performances. Additionally, the writing does a good job at honoring the Rocky series while also passing the torch. And as always, the fight sequences are incredibly exciting. Creed is a smart and well-crafted film that has an interesting story to tell.

My Review of "Creed"... sort of...Last Saturday night I saw the movie Creed and I wanted to share my thoughts about it. It's extremely rare that I post something this long, so I apologize for that, but my experience with watching Creed can't really be separated from my experience with the entire Rocky series. When Rocky first came out I was 8 (almost 9) years old, and I was insistent that I see it. I believe it was the first adult movie that I felt that way about. My parents took my sister and me, and it did not disappoint. I was absolutely blown away. I would continue to be blown away by it for the next nearly-40 years. I've seen the move probably over 30 times, and if I were watching round 14 right now, I'd still get chills and feel like I could take on the world. "Stay down!" Mickey yells, but no, Rocky uses every bit of strength he has left to pull himself up! "Apollo can't believe it!" No movie has ever made me feel like that to that extent. To this day, I consider the first Rocky to be one of the best films ever made. I could go on and on as to why, but this isn't a review of the first Rocky. I will say though, I still don't think Sylvester Stallone gets anywhere near enough credit for the brilliant script he wrote. As I got older and learned more about how Rocky was made, how the studio didn't want Sylvester Stallone to play the lead role, I was so impressed. To risk not selling your screenplay because you know in your heart of hearts you were meant for a part, takes so much confidence... and guts. Not only was Rocky an underdog, so was Sylvester Stallone.As the series continued, of course I saw all of them. Rocky 2 was certainly a respectable sequel. As a kid, I thought Rocky 3 was amazing, mostly because there were 2 fights AND a wrestling match! Not to mention, it had Mr. T! Later in life, I would come to realize, Rocky 3 was pretty cheesy, and it completely shifted the series to another genre, but as a Rocky-obsessed kid of the 80s, it was awesome. Then Rocky IV came out. Oh man! That was horrible! I know there are people out there who love it. All I can say is those people must REALLY hate communism. For me, it was the worst Rocky of all. I would always say two things about that movie.... Firstly, it was just an anti-Soviet Union propaganda film. Secondly, it had a robot in it, which automatically made it the worst Rocky movie. Next was Rocky V... also terrible, just not quite as terrible as Rocky IV. So at this point, I assumed the series was over. Like almost all series of movies, they get progressively worse until they are unwatchable. However, then I found out Sylvester Stallone was making a 6th installment in the series, Rocky Balboa. When I heard this, I thought, "Can't this guy just let it go? He's already killed it. You can't kill what's already dead." And then the trailer came out. I couldn't help it; I actually thought it looked sort of good. And to be honest, I'd probably go see any Rocky movie no matter what. So of course I went to see Rocky Balboa, with my friend Tom. When the movie ended, I turned to Tom and said, "Am I crazy, or was that actually good?" Tom replied, "No, I think it was actually good." I was floored. Now, I'm not saying Rocky Balboa is a great movie, but it's really good... arguably the second best movie in the series. It's a really nice film about a former champion who is grieving the loss of his wife. The amazing thing about the movie, isn't necessarily how good it was, but that Sylvester Stallone did the impossible once again. He took a series that had become completely ridiculous and made a sequel that totally worked! I cannot think of another example of this in movie history. It was a beautiful ending to a series that I can only assume is very dear to Sylvester Stallone. Personally, I was so happy to see that Rocky, a movie that meant so much to me, got to end so well. But then...I started to hear about a plan to make ANOTHER Rocky movie focused on Apollo Creed's son. Quickly I added up the years to see if that even made logical sense. It did. I was so annoyed. You did the impossible (I'm talking to an imaginary Sylvester Stallone in my head, by the way) and ended a defunct series well, and now you're going to ruin that by making another one? This seemed ridiculous to me. But then I was reading about the movie, and I saw that Stallone was neither the writer nor the director, the first time he didn't play at least one of those roles in a Rocky movie. The movie was written and directed by Ryan Coogler, the young filmmaker who did Fruitvale Station. An indie filmmaker? I wondered if this was even Stallone's idea to make it, or did Coogler go to him with the idea. Either way, I was suddenly intrigued. A few months ago, I watched the trailer, and like Rocky Balboa, I was surprised by how good it looked. Then again, you play that Rocky theme and almost anything looks good. Then the early buzz on the movie started to come in, and it was actually quite positive. I couldn't believe it. Again, this series, which is about someone doing the impossible, is doing the impossible. At this point, I was starting to get excited to see it. I was still skeptical, mind you. Part of the reason Rocky Balboa works so well is because it practically ignores Rocky 3 through 5. Creed, however, can't ignore Rocky 4 because that's when Apollo dies. I told a friend before I saw it, "If Creed makes one reference to Drago, I'm not sure I can like it." So last Saturday night, I went with my nephew, sister, and brother-in-law to see the seventh movie in the Rocky series, Creed. I'll get right to the point; I enjoyed it quite a bit. To begin with, and most importantly, we truly connect with and care about the character of Adonis (Apollo Creed's son). Coogler does an excellent job explaining how this young man, who comes from a wealthy and famous father, has grown up to be a fighter who is haunted by his own personal demons. Michael B. Jordan is excellent as Adonis, as is Tessa Thompson, who plays his love interest, Bianca. With that said, Sylvester Stallone steals the show. Every time he is on screen, I was pulled in. This has to be his best performance since the original Rocky. He conveys so much even when he's not saying a word. This might sound crazy, but I think it is a performance that is worthy of an Oscar nomination. Oddly, the nomination would mostly likely be, and should be, for Best Supporting Actor, because this movie is definitely Adonis's story. Coogler's script and direction take the Rocky series and bring it to the next generation. He creates so many beautiful little moments, and brings us along nicely as we root for Adonis on his journey to be a fighter and to accept his past. There are a couple choices that Coogler makes that I would've done differently, but I won't share those at risk of spoiling anything. Besides, what's most important is that Coogler captures the spirit and the heart of the Rocky series, which he does big time. I was moved through the entire movie. I can't think of another series where you have the unique experience of literally watching a character grow older over 39 years. Eat your heart out Boyhood! If you're a fan of the Rocky series like I am, it's a moving and heartbreaking experience. After the movie was over, I found myself thinking about it a lot. I was so impressed that it was as good as it was. I was also blown away that Stallone was willing to hand over the gauntlet like this. I still have so many questions about how that happened and how much say Stallone had in the final product. It's truly amazing to me how this series, from beginning to end, has broken the odds. Because, to be frank, there is no way this movie should've been good!On Sunday, I went to Trader Joe's, and the checker was a young man, probably in his mid-twenties. He asked how my weekend was going, and I mentioned I had seen Creed. He had seen it as well. We both shared in a short conversation about how good we both thought it was. It was clear from how his eyes lit up, he REALLY thought it was good. I asked him if he was a fan of the original Rocky series. He said, "Yeah, it was pretty good." I asked him, "So you liked this more?" He said, "Oh yeah!" I left so thrilled that it seemed the Rocky series (now the Creed series) was successfully handed off to teach a whole new generation that life is hard, but you have to keep moving forward, and that our biggest opponent is ourselves.

For those of us who grew up in a certain era, the Rocky movies are a treasure that we hold dear to our hearts (Those same people do not recognize Rocky V as having existed). Creed does what Rocky Balboa (the 6th installment) could not do. It brings us back to what made Rocky such an inspirational story to begin with. A true underdog, going through hell and getting an unlikely shot to rise to stardom. Michael B. Jordan and Sylvester Stallone deliver award-worthy performances (No exaggeration here, and especially Stallone) and Tessa Thompson delivers a solid if not underrated performance as well. The boxing (in true Rocky fashion delivers more punches than anyone could ever take) was intense and the camera work was outstanding during those sequences. For anyone concerned that this is anything less than the standard the original Rocky movies set, fear not. This is an outstanding movie and one that in a different year could have received some Oscar consideration (though Stallone may still have a chance).

DISAPPOINTINGI saw CREED Saturday, and loved Stallone's and Jordan's acting. But that didn't balance the mediocre theme, of being as good as your dad. As good as Apollo Creed, an arrogant. manipulative showman who could beat anyone (except Rocky) into the ground?. For some people, that might be inspiring, not for me. As far as fighting being "in your blood," that's one of the thuings humans need to transcend, not make a life out of.The boxing choreography was good,but I one mouthful of blood being spit would have been enough..I'm not surprised Stallone didn't direct or write this one. He produced it, but I don't think it will be long remembered. I can watch ROCKY and ROCKY BALBOA once a year. Not this one.The other acting was mediocre, and the secondary characters (including Rocky) were poorly drawn. Yeah, Rocky talks to the dead again and that's moving. But he gets seriously ill (no spoiler; it's in the trailer), and gets dangerous treatment, but we see no impact of it. And the love interest's flaw is not developed either.

Michael B. Jordon and Sylvester Stallone give outstanding performances in the newest film of the Rocky franchise that reminds us why Rocky became an icon to us in the first place. Adonis Johnson never knew his fighter father Apollo Creed as he was the child of his mistress. Apollo died before he was born. Adonis finds himself getting in trouble, and is later adopted by Apollo's wife, who feels a connection to Apollo's son. Adonis has boxing in his blood even though no one in his life approves of his career. He decides to move to Philadelphia to meet the man that fought his father and eventually took his title. He has watched Rocky fight on tape against his father so he decides this is the man who should train him. Apollo and Rocky had a good friendship. When Adonis introduces himself to Rocky, Rocky is reluctant to talk about boxing or even training him. Rocky has lost so much in the last few years, and spends time talking to his wife and best friend at a graveyard. When Adonis finally convinces Rocky to train him and become a part of his team, the story reminds you of all the things you loved about the first Rocky film. Sylvester Stallone is brilliant playing the now elder boxer who is living in the shadow of his past while trying to find a purpose in his new reality. I though this was one of the best films of 2015. You should see this film, it will make you cheer inside a quiet theater and make you believe that anything is possible.
Excellent start for Adonis's struggle and a fantastic way to conclude Rocky's. The baton has been passed successfully.
This was exceptionally well cast, acting was good and it had a way of pulling me in. I was hooked mid way and enjoyed it throughout.

My chidhood idol becomes my adulthood inspiration. Creed made me laugh, cry, reminisce,and cheer for the next generation of Rocky movies. It went so beyond my hopes and expectations that I can't wait to watch it again. Thank you Ryan Coogler!!!

Creed is a fantastic film. Deeply emotional, sad, fun, and highly motivating. The cast is just perfect, with Stallone ready for an Oscar nomination. Jordan is as good as Stallone, with an impressive physique and great acting skills. Creed does the Rocky universe justice, and that itself is an victory. Ryan Coogler shows that he may be one of the best directors to come. Another highlight is the score, which fits perfectly in nearly every scene. After Rocky Balboa, most fans (me included) thought Stallone found the perfect end for the saga. But after watching Creed, I have to say that this film is another highlight in Rocky-Land. A Must-see!
Michael B Jordan is a star, and Stallone still has it. Great chemistry on screen with these two. It's #2 in my book behind the original Rocky.

Sometimes, you just want to see the cliches. Yeah, it's Rocky. And with that, you probably know what's coming. But that doesn't stop the chills when these things happen. Add in upgraded fight scenes, Michael B. Jordan delivering the performance we all know he's capable off and the best Sly performance in years and you have a winner.

Spin off movies are kinda difficult to do, look at the movie I can not mention cause it makes me so mad, cause what on earth did it have to do with Alien?!!! But here is a spin-off movie that really makes a good go of it. Rocky isn't the purest of boxing movies (look at the fight scenes in the Rocky movies) but its entertaining, except Rocky V which plunges head first in to pure farce during the last 30 minutes. Rocky isn't the main character in Creed, Adonis Johnson is and that is where the movie breaths fresh life in to the franchise. Johnson is the result of an affair that Apollo Creed had sometime before Rocky IV. Caught in the shadow of his fathers name, he shys away from the Creed Surname. The movie you can tell is shot and told in a way to separate its self from the previous Rocky movies, but at the same time does embrace the Rocky legacy. Its something that had to be done but had to be done carefully as to not make another Rocky clone, Southpaw was a Rocky clone. There are nods of course to the previous Rocky moives (all except 5, but who can blame them for that?) and Rocky's larger than life legacy is woven thru the movie. But what this movie does so well is show Johnson's struggle with who he is, what he is and what that name could do to him if he let it. Eventually Johnson takes on the Creed moniker and has the Rocky-esque perfromance. Michael B. Jordan does a great job as Creed/Johnson, Stallone is really good too as a older, wiser and supportive father figure to Johnson. This movie didn't get caught in the shadow of Rocky it refreshes and moves everything on. Sequels will of course follow and if Michael B. Jordan returns with Ryan Coogler (watch the Fruitvale Station, excetllent movie) then Creed stands a real chance of making its own real legacy.
Excellent way to continue this epic story, Great intense fight scenes.
The best Rocky movie since the original. I recommend seeing it after watching 1 through 6 in order.

I'm a big fan of the first Rocky movie. Of the other ones? Not so much. None of them hit me the way the first one did. Pun sort of intended. In a way, I wish it didn't follow the first one as much as it did. I wish it had something to stand out on its own.But at the same time, it did it with so much elegance and class that I can't really complain. I feel that this movie really stands on it's own. It is a great movie. The acting is fantastic. The score is big and epic. And don't even get me started on the choreography. I don't think it was as good as the first one, but only because I feel that the first one had that bit of a sprinkle of magic that comes with nostalgia. But also just that the antagonist was not as interesting as Apollo was. My only other complaint is that I don't think it passes the bechdel test, despite having 2 main female charaters and one who was a side character and were all very well written. However, I will definitely be buying this movie once it comes out and I will proudly display it next to Rocky on the shelve.

"Creed" is superior entry in the "Rocky" series. It adds some surprising depth of character and some interesting plot choices. During the films climactic sequences, it does lose its way a bit by grandstanding too much. The overused issues of using the commentators to tell what is going on gets annoying quickly. Sylvester Stallone and Michael B. Jordan are excellent, however.
Fantastic movie. Hope they make another.
Got me pumped to follow work hard toward my goals! Excellent movie!

When I first heard of another Rocky movie I was apprehensive to go for another watered down version of the 1st terrific movie, 'Rocky'. Creed exceeded my expectations with a good story and fine acting. For the first time in years there was real dialogue between men drawn by past events that drew a picture of the imperfections of life. Like the John Wayne saying,"There are some things a man just can't run away from." - "Stagecoach," 1939. I was drawn to the search for truth by Creed's son Adonis played by Michael B. Jordan and Rocky's sadness brought on by the loss of Adrian, Pauley and his diagnosis, which would be his biggest challenge ever. Much like the original Rocky, which in this viewers eyes was a love story strengthening Rocky Balboa and Adrian as they together "filled the gaps" together. Creed shows the frailties we all encounter in our lives and the imperfections. There is a realness to this story that goes beyond championships but the road to discovery of what it is in life that brings you closure or understanding of life's many forks in the road.Fighting is the metaphor for getting knocked down and getting back up. Creed has a resounding right hand in this series. Life's struggle can be a lot of bobbing and weaving, not the clich� that would neatly wrap this up in a bow at the end. It is overcoming the obstacles and helping one another, not at the best of times, but when everyone gives up on you and you go with your dream.Go see this movie it is 15 rounder with plenty of punch.

Wonderful story of fighting (not just boxing) with parts of the 'Rocky' lore seamlessly embedded throughout the movie. And the fights - man, they are exquisitely choreographed. Awesome movie. Highly recommended.

For anyone who remembers how great the original Rocky movies were, you have to, HAVE TO see this movie. I went with my family and we were absolutely moved. Go see it, you will leave with a lump in your throat which I had a hard time containing it. Just absolutely great!

This film has much going for it besides being a crowd-pleaser.Director Ryan Coogler challenges himself with sweeping one shots and up-in-your-grill fighting scenes. His vision injects purpose and focus into the Rocky saga giving it some modernization. As a result, it doesn't feel like another obligated Rocky movie at all.Look at Stallone here. He's still finding meat on the character, thanks in part to Coogler's script. Though the setup is a little contrived, one scene in a locker room may be one of Stallone's most honest acting moments I've seen.I hadn't seen Fruitvale Station yet, but Michael B. Jordan just showed me he's a powerful, capable actor.This is another big budget studio surprise this year!

While the Rocky franchise hasn't been exactly heralded for its writing, but you could always tell that every single word out of the characters' mouths in Rocky I and II felt incredibly genuine, coming from a place in Stallone's heart that wouldn't stop beating onward through adversity. Creed somewhat fails in this aspect, with dialogue that feels neither genuine nor even believable. At about the 30 minute mark, I seriously considered walking out during an insufferable scene between Jordan and Tessa Thompson, playing the love interest/FKA Twigs-esque R&B singer, at a philly cheese steak restaurant. Now, if you can make it past the sometimes inane dialogue, slow-to-start plot structure, and some goofy moments that could have been straight out of Rocky III or IV, you'll very much enjoy this film. What Coogler lacks in writing believable, consistently toned dialogue, he more than makes up for in dynamic scenes and dramatic tension. When you get to the first fight scene between Creed and another young undefeated boxer-a scene that, I might add, appears to have been done all in one shot-you'll find yourself so engrossed in the action that you might be on the edge of your seat. Jordan's performance is incredible, as he battles his way through unrealistic lines, and Stallone's performance is clearly close to his heart, as an aging legend nears the end of his life. Thompson has some great chemistry, despite being given some of the most out of character lines of any character. Overall, I did enjoy this movie, It definitely makes up for the post-II Rocky films, but seems cheesy in comparison to Rocky I.
For me this was good movie and the best of the entire Rocky series but its not something I'd wanna watch again. Once was enough for me.

It's Rocky for the millenial generation. Donnie "Hollywood" Johnson, who drives a Mustang, lives in a mansion, trains in Nike and Jordan gear, may have lived a privileged life, but his experiences growing up without a father, going through the foster care system, and denying his identity as a Creed is genuine enough to ground him as a person who wants to create his own legacy. Aside from the contrived fight with former champion Conlon, who would have never accepted that fight in real life, all the elements in this film are inspired work from the cast crew. Seeing Rocky become the OG after being the main character all these years, it made me appreciate how special his character is and how even the best fighters have to move on with life. But it's Donnie's story now, and people my age will definitely find a lot of things in common with him.

Excellent! one of the best in the "Rocky" series and a great stand-alone film in it's own right, Apollo would be very proud. The new cast and the ageing legend that is Stallone ("Rocky") deliver an absolute T.K.O.

Creed is probably the biggest surprise of the year for me! Not only does it make Michael B. Jordan a bona fide star, but it revives Sylvester Stallone's career in a HUGE way! Stallone as Rocky Balboa once again is powerful, heartbreaking and is Stallone's best performance since the original Rocky! This isn't Stallone doing the same thing he's done in past Rocky films. He brings new depth to the character that we've never seen before and is surely the front-runner for Best Supporting Actor at the upcoming Oscars! Director Ryan Coogler brings this story to life in a way no other filmmaker could have! The boxing sequences are incredibly staged and shot like no other boxing film. Apart from one or two character decisions I didn't necessarily feel were fleshed out enough, this is a flawless film! From the incredible performances, epic direction, great soundtrack, and heart felt moments that made me weep more than any film this year, Creed is a knockout film that everyone should see! 4.9 out of 5 Stars!

As an ashamed Rocky series virgin, I was excited to finally see one of the widely-praised and beloved Rocky movies. I knew to expect some of the stereotypical Rocky traits, like the training montages, the unorthodox practices (like working on speed by catching chickens) and the inspirational motivation from the trainer, in this case Rocky Balboa himself (played, of course by Sylvester Stallone). Even those famous steps got to peek into the movie. However, I did not really expect the new, hi-tech, striking shots throughout the flick, the ones that kept you begging for more. From the graphics that pop up next to each potential opponent with their records and nicknames to the surround-sound shouts from Rocky Balboa in his corner, you really see the world from the perspective of Michael B. Jordan's Adonis Creed character. When he gets hit, it's disorienting, it's blurry, and it's real. When you hear the chants of 100,000 people in a loaded soccer stadium for a fight, you start to feel a bit nervous. You even feel that loneliness when he first comes to Philadelphia in his crappy apartment. So, naturally, in comes a romantic encounter, but Bianca does so much to the story. Around her, you really get to know Adonis and how real he is, because she brings something different out of him. He can be something better than a tough kid trying to prove that he can be as good as his father by himself. He is a caring human being who Bianca pushes to be the best, teaching him to do what he loves and accept where he comes from. In a similar fashion, the paternal bond between Rocky and Adonis adds another incentive for Creed to keep fighting and always keep working, even if he was slightly skeptical of Rocky's Karate Kid-like tactics. It becomes so obvious that Rocky cares so much about this kid and sees something in him that many didn't. Sure, their bond gets tested, after all, preparing for a championship fight breaks Adonis down to the core, but you always feel that they will stick together in the end, because that's what family does. Likewise, even though his providing, caring mother wanted Adonis to not go down the path her husband, Apollo, took, she still supported him in his fights, because she loved her son. Creed is about finding your own way, but never forgetting your roots, and without love, family, and support (like some of the best boxing staff in Philadelphia) it's incredibly difficult to succeed. Even the proudest and toughest of men ask for help, because they will always fight for what they want.

Sure, it may not move and SOUND like the classic Rocky films we know. But much like it's new character, it has no problem standing on it's own two feet.There are many elements to this feature that deserve praise. The excellent camera work. The non traditional route of storytelling. The superb acting by the whole cast. And since we're on the topic of acting, the real bright and shining star of this picture is Stallone. That's not to discredit any of the other actors in this feature. They all did phenomenal work. But this could seriously be considered his Opus. There are some very cathartic words in Stallone's speech in this movie. Mainly pertaining to his late son who passed in 2012. Every ounce of his acting is truly genuine, and it easily sends this movie into a different category. One we haven't seen since the original. And that's something that's been missing from this franchise for a long time.But with that being said, there are a few minor problems. While the movie doesn't go the cliche route (which i appreciate), it still tries to find it's own identity. It's separating itself from the other Rocky films. A passing of the torch if you will. While i 100% agree with this decision, i still found some of the filming choices a but bleak and generic. Sure, it doesn't have to have the same bells and whistles as the original. But it has to be just as LOUD. Had they created some iconic sequences, ones that give you goosebumps everytime you watch them, then this would rival the originals. And yes, i understand that's easier said than done. But the mere fact that it's this pictures only downfall speaks volumes.My rating, 3.5 out of 5 stars

Excellent installment. After Rocky and III, this was probably the next best. Michael Jordan was excellent and Tessa Thompson kept righ up there. They were both very believable. Stallone was also very good as himself. The boxing scenes were also very well done. Not quite a classic - but very good.

I saw Creed the day it came out, and I kept thinking about Rocky but was constantly upset by the face that it's about Donny. But Donny wasn't a bad guy to be around, and it was pretty funny seeing an old timer like Rocky interact off of a young guy like Donny - such as the Icloud part, that was pretty funny. Rocky still had some good moments, like when he's visiting Paulie and Adrian's graves and gives Paulie a bottle of his favorite whisky. When Rocky had cancer at the middle of the movie, I was pretty shocked, and I don't normally feel that way about fictional characters. But since I love Rocky so much, I was pretty worried for him. That stuff happens when you follow a character you love for so many movies. The scene before the final boxing match was just awesome! When Donny gets Apollo's American flag shorts, I said "Yes" with so much joy in the theatre, and when the Rocky theme played during the fight everybody applauded, and I joined in. I look forward to another movie, if they ever make one, and if they do i'm pretty sure Rocky will die. It's sad but inevitable.

Rather than put audiences between Rocky and a hard place, winning combo Creed brilliantly plays out as one of the best and freshest chapters in the storied sports franchise. What's most amazing is the continuing development of an older Italian Stallion into a complex evolving mentor figure even after he's given up the titular mantle. Reverential to the past with a dynamite new fight story all on its own, Creed pits a new unlikely underdog and his trainer on the hard knocks road to a title fight. The whipsmart result brings you to your feet almost as much as 1976's Rocky, the classic that put us all in this fight. Oh, predictability rears its punch-drunk head at times and females get underserved, but not nearly enough to throw in the towel. On the contrary, this is a rare film about legacy that beautifully honors and extends its own. In this PG-13-rated sports drama, former World Heavyweight Champion Rocky Balboa (Stallone) serves as a trainer and mentor to Adonis Johnson (Jordan), the son of his late friend and former rival Apollo Creed. If Mad Max Fury Road and Jurassic World proved anything this year, it's - with the right vision and creative minds -it's better to continue a known franchise than start from scratch with an uninspired reboot (Poltergeist). Thankfully, Creed doesn't throw out the Balboa with the bath water. In fact, Ryan Coogler finds fascinating new depths for the simple Philadelphia fighter. More than proving that he wasn't just a one-shot pony after his harrowing feted drama Fruitville Station, the writer-director advances the game of the iconic character while charting the riveting course for his prot�g�. With Rocky Balboa, Stallone conceived a warm epilogue for the series, signing off Balboa's fighting career on a high note, complete with a new status as widower keeping his beloved's memory alive by running a restaurant under her name, Adrian's. Coogler, however, uses this as an awesome jumping off point, offering up the palooka as benevolent elder statesman. With Jordan's Adonis Creed, he gives us a new hero worth rooting for while still cheering for the old hero. You get on your feet for the performances as well, especially Stallone in a career highlight that's surely due an Oscar nomination for Best Supporting Actor. Bottom line: Gonna Fly and How

Creed definitely earns its spots in the Rocky universe, but I feel all the raving reviews are a little crazy. MBJ is a fine actor and is great in all the non boxing scenes, but he just doesn't have the presence as a boxer. There's nothing unique about his fighting style whereas all the boxers in the Rocky movies did, even Tommy Gunn. The writers focused a lot more on his backstory and relationships with Rocky and the girlfriend rather than his boxing. A better balance would have definitely made me rate this higher. No complaints anywhere else. Sly is still awesome.

"Creed" is a coming of age boxing film about a boxing prodigy (Michael B Jordan) who has to live up to his father, Apollo Creed's glorious legacy. In a spin-off of the Rocky movies, Sylvester Stallone plays his mentor and trainer. Jordan has a lot to prove and brings his passion and thirst to prove himself to the big screen. This is the finest acting the young actor has done to date. The film is energetic, passionate, lively and spirited. It takes the underdog story to a new level and infuses it with good character development, believable story arcs and a thoroughly likeable protagonist. This is one of the finest films of 2015 and should fare well come Oscar time --------------------------------------------------------- A-

The franchise that keeps on trucking and giving despite all odds and all of these years has given us another unexpectedly sincere, touching and enthralling chapter in the Rocky universe, and I say universe in this case since Rocky truly isn't the centre of the story anymore although still provides a lot of heart in what amounts to the combination of Mickey/Adrienne role, this is the story about the underdog Adonis Johnson, Apollo Creed's illegitmate son who is looking to step out of his father's shadow in the sport he ruled, boxing. After the disaster that was Fantastic Four earlier this year, Michael B Jordan has found his first blockbustery/studio franchise film to take him to the next level and he defintiely delivers cashing in the charisma, angst and passion as well as humour to the role of the aspiring boxer and really holds the screen against the former champ as they bound over the love of the sport, and the respect of the ghost of Apollo Creed. Very really directed and believeably executed checking in on Rocky and where he would belivably be at this point. A worthy entry against all odds in the series and given the franchise new legs even if it is still comfort food.

Creed has a good story, but way too similar to the original Rocky! Creed's illegitmate son must fight personal demons and needs the help of Rocky to fight in an once in a lifetime fight. The story goes full circle with Rocky as Micky and Creed becomes Rocky. The story is about people and personalities. Rocky comes to grips with loss and aging. Directed well with good boxing choreography. I give Creed 2 stars.

Every day it seems a new reboot or remake or prequel or something is coming out. I look at films like J.J. Abrams Star Trek which rebooted the franchise but changed everything and for a fan like myself, its difficult to process. Creed on the other hand took a franchise like Rocky, which has been dying for years and rebooted the world masterfully, keeping the old and the history and incorporating it into a film franchise of the future. This film was great and a must see for any Rocky or boxing fan. Ryan Coogler did an amazing job putting it together, he understood the history and understands how to build a better future for this world. Michael Jordan was great as Apollo Creed's son, and now boxer. His performance was flawless. Rocky took on a supporting role but this is some of the best acting Stallone has done in some time. The film is very true to the original Rocky film, Rocky is now Mickey, Creed is Rocky, and then there is the other boxer. The story was engaging and it moved well, the boxing sequences were spectacular. This is without doubt one of the best films to come out this year. The last good Rocky film came out in 1986, Rocky V was a disaster, Rocky Balboa was so so, this film was the perfect film to correct those mistakes and make you feel like you were watching a great boxing film.

***** Excellent I promise I will not knock you out with a bunch of punnercuts with my review of the latest film installment of the Rocky franchise called "Creed". Yo, I lied. Anyways, "Creed" is a marvelous picture which should round out in my list as one of the top films, if not the top, of 2015. "Creed" stars uprising actor Michael B. Jordan as young boxer Adonis Johnson. Adonis is also the son of Apollo Creed; and I don't have to tell you who Apollo is, unless you are spaced out with the Rocky flicks. Adonis wants to make his own name in boxing so he seeks the training help of the late Apollo's friend & competitor; the one & only Rocky Balboa. Balboa is played by..... really, do I have to tell you who it is? Come on, this is about the eight count of Rocky movies, so we all know it's Sylvester Stallone. Rocky now is an aging Philly restaurant owner who has lost both his wife Adrian and his brother-in-law Paulie. Rocky is first reluctant to train Adonis, but with some soul searching, he changes his mind. Rocky later discovers that he has to put up with another fight, no ring required in this one but it turns out to be his most important fight. "Creed" is proficiently directed by Ryan Coogler. Ryan's hope was not to discredit the Rocky franchise, and his hope came true with his unanimous stellar direction of "Creed". He also put in some inspiring write jabs with fellow scriber Aaron Covington with their heartfelt screenplay of "Creed". Jordan has to be a slam dunk for a Best Actor Oscar nomination with his powerful performance as Adonis. And a Stallone Academy Award nomination playing "Rocky" might just make a comeback to the Oscar ring with what should certainly be a Best Supporting Actor nomination. I also admired the performances of Tessa Thompson as Adonis' love interest and Phylicia Rashad as Creed's adoptive mother. I won't reveal much more of "Creed" because that would give this review a "black eye"; not that it doesn't have a few already. "Creed" is my second favorite of the "Rocky" franchise; still prefer the original by a split decision. So get creedy, and feel the "Creed".
