Remarkably written-directed by Ryan Coogler that is smart, kinetic, exhilarating, wellwell-crafted piece of mainstream filmmaking. Once again superb acting by Michael B. Jordan along one of the best performances by Sylvester Stallone for a very long time. Creed follows the illegitimate love child of Apollo Creed that loses his father before he was born, driven him to fight all his life and track down Rocky Balboa to train him. Ryan Coogler able to jump-start a Rocky franchise, managed to distinguish the film enough to have its own identity, but preserving the intentions of the original franchise.

"Creed" (aka Rocky 7) is heartfelt and features good performances from Michael B. Jordan and Sylvester Stallone, but the story is too implausible. (How can a man with no professional training become a title contender in months? How can a post-op cancer patient undergoing chemo travel oversees to coach a prize fight? How come Creed's climactic opponent seems to have over thirty pounds on him?) Also, the subplot with the girl is perfunctory.
Much like the protagonist, Creed doesnt want to stay in the shadow of its predecessors. This movie takes the Rocky franchise in a new direction while still staying familiar where it matters

Amazingly directed and filmed, this might be the most technically brilliant boxing film I'd ever seen, at least up there with Raging Bull. After the incredible Fruitvale Station, the Coolger-Jordan team continue to impress.

The biggest thing for me: CREED made sense without having seen any of the Rocky movies. I apologize for this oversight in my filmic knowledge.CREED is incredible. (InCREEDible? Sorry.) I'm not big on sports movies and have never loved boxing, but stellar performances from Michael B Jordan and Sylvester Stallone and virtuosic direction from Ryan Coogler left me breathless with excitement. The film follows the son of Apollo Creed as he seeks to make a name for himself in the boxing world, enlisting the help of Rocky Balboa as coach and mentor. Inspires without cloying; loves Rocky fans but is not indulgent; tells an origin story without feeling tired or fabricated. One of the best of the year.

I really liked this film it kept itself true to the original ROCKY, ROCKY 2, and ROCKY BALBOA. Not as good as ROCKY 1 and 2, but It does show heart and bravery. The fighting scenes was amazing and the camera angles made every fight look more realistic and different compared to all the other rockys. Creed's son did a good job playing his, but not as close as Slyvester Stalone did in his films. Great storyline, acting, gripping, and very motivating. A must see!! Can't wait to see the second one. If they do I have a huge feeling what the main plot would be about :)
This movies was so entertaining, it is not just a boxing movies, everyone will enjoy it. I loved it!!!
Michael B. Jordan and Sylvester Stallone are sensational, but Ryan Coogler is the true star, delivering in "Creed" a stylish, rousing, and heartfelt tale the Rocky legacy more than deserves.
An absolutely outstanding, intense and heartfelt inspiring story. One of the 3 best of the year.

Excellent 'Reboot' while also staying true to the feel and narrative or the original Rocky series. Acting was A+, Script was sold (except for a little too much cheese near the end courtesy of Adonis' 'mother).Cinematography was superb; meaning that modern audiences felt the drama, fighting and feel of a gritty landscape in a surprisingly high quality. Bring on the new generation of the Rocky/Creed series!

Creed is the seventh film in the Rocky franchise. However, it's the second best film in the franchise (right behind the first Rocky). The theatre I watched this movie in was decently filled, so when strong moments of the film occurred (such as as when the Rocky theme began to play in the final fight) applause erupted from the crowd, and rightfully so. Creed has excellent leads from Michael B. Jordan and Sylvester Stallone, who has proven that he is still an undeniably great actor. The cinematography of Creed also deserves an Academy nomination, as the entire film looks beautiful and there were many impressive long takes that I could not stomyself from gasping in amazement. The last time I have seen cinematography this good was in Boogie Nights, which was another great film. The fight scenes in Creed are brutal, bloody, and exhilarating, with every punch making me wince in my seat. Outside the ring, the story becomes a moving and inspirational drama, creating a great blend of emotions. Overall, Creed could be the best movie of 2015. Me and my Johnson highly recommend seeing it.
Went to see this with my son and husband. I thought that I was going to be bored but I was WRONG. I loved it, great story
The Rocky story is about redemption. This movie, from the first bell to the last, reminds us of this.

Indeed the 7th round seems to be a knockout. With Stallone outside the ring and Jordan in the ring, a winning combination of character dynamics and on screen chemistry blossoms. While it may share a lot of similarities to the original "Rocky," this film would be fine as a completely stand alone experience. Even if the ending could not be as original as it desired to be. As different than the middle entries of the Rocky legacy, this one does well with characters you will want to see succeed. Even if there are minor allusions to past films, viewers can sympathize with such characters often in dramatic sequences.If any Rocky film has been worth watching since the original, it would definitely be this movie here.
I thought this movie was phenomenal in all aspects.

Like the other Rocky films, Creed is a little uneven and sometimes cheesy. But it overcomes these faults thanks to fantastic direction, powerful and emotionally-charged performances (Stallone deserves an Oscar nomination), and thoroughly explored themes of legacy. It ends up as not just possibly the best Rocky film, but a phenomenal film overall.

The first fight in this movie is the best I have ever seen. One continuous camera shot puts you right in the middle of the ring and I could swear these guys were actually punching the hell out of each other! Both Stallone and Jordan deserve Oscars for their performances. My only wish is the final fight was done as graphically as the first.
hell , I did not expect anything amazing film and I left excited , my fourth favorite film of the year

All around good movie, but with some flaws. The main character isn't really a character, but is more of an archetype.Also, my personal bias is that I've always thought of boxing as a rather archaic, savage activity, though I respect that it could also be viewed as an art form.I also appreciate that Coogler made several attempts to make this something other than a white savior film by utilizing counterpoint strategies such as Rocky's reluctance, Creed's attempt to make the relationship familial, etc.The movie's ending, however, is missing something. Something about the rhythm/beat was off and the impact I was looking for sort of peters out. But I must say that it was nice to see black love on film.
Absorbing, heart felt and some damn good fight choreography to boot make this a beautiful flick you cant miss

A worthy addition to the Rocky Balboa legacy, this movie does a good job of capturing the fighters spirit. It has all of the poignant montage moments, a hyped up performance by MBJ and Old Rocky, who is just as hard headed and likable as ever. The boxing scenes are very immersive, and the sound design helps by isolating the corner voices. It's a story that has been told well in previous films (a few of the sequels at least), but even while going over familiar territory, it captures the heart of the series well.

To most baby boomers, the "ROCKY" a.k.a. Rocky 1 was a tremendous movie capturing all emotionssurrounding the rise of the uber underdog Rocky Balboa (Sylvester Stallone). This movie killed onmany levels do the story line, the characters, the soundtrack and yes the incredible boxing scene. Nosurprise that this film won the Academy Award for best picture and spun of a multitude of sequels.As long as Stallone was in the mix (Rocky 1-4), though not as good as the original, were entertaining.' Rocky V & VI I barely remember as attempts to capture the magic and not.So Rocky VI was made in 2006 and most folks, including me, assumed it was the end of the journey as Stallone was well past fighting age (regardless what Hollywood could create with special effects).Now the newest Rocky film titled "Creed" I'm sure will be successful with a whole new generation of fans with falling for Creed (Michael B. Jordan) and his love interest (Tessa Thompson). Plays on the same themes of underdog, Philadelphia based, blue collar training and of course Stallone in an aligned but different role.For me, it was enjoyable and forgettable. No pun intended, but I was "pounded" by the Rocky brand meaning the fighting Balboa, his timid yet wonderfully loyal wife Adrian, the unforgettable goofy brother in law Paulie (the great Burt Young) and quintessential old school boxing trainer Mick played by Burgess Meredith).Adrian, Paulie and Mick are no longer in the mix and for me there significant supporting characters completed the Rocky family. Hence, though entertaining, I'm hard-wired and can't forget the past. Must say the fight scene was excellent but the rest just okay. Hope a new generation of Rocky/Creed fans surface and the series continues for them.

Rating: 3.5 out of 5: A worthy addition to the Rocky franchise. While this is technically not a Rocky movie, Creed does a great take on the Rocky universe. Michael B Jordan does a great job as the son of Apollo Creed and his determination to make it as a boxer. Sylvester Stallone also does a great job being on the sideline as Rocky Balboa and being a supporting cast rather than the lead character. I think Sylvester's take on Rocky in this movie is close to winning an academy award for best supporting actor and showing us an aged Rocky in the Rocky universe. One of the disappointing parts of the movie was the role of Phylicia Rashad, she is an incredible actor and totally under used in this film. I really hope there is a follow up to this film as I believe there is more to say about Adonis Johnson and his new journey as a boxer and the son of Apollo Creed.

On the surface, this looks like your average boxing film. But instead of having the cliched underdog story we've seen a million times, this film has a twist and is portrayed through a great movie franchise. Michael B. Jordan is great as the lead but Sylvester Stallone was fantastic! Some of the best acting I've ever seen him do. This isn't so much about the young gun defeating the all powerful evil undefeated champion, it's a story about the father and son relationship many of us are so fortunate to have. If you are looking for something in theatres to hold you over until Star Wars comes out, Creed is a pretty good choice

Tonight I went and saw the movie "CREED" with Sly Stallone and Michael B. Jordan. Now Creed is Rocky reborn and in a very good way, with Sly Stallone giving his best performance well since "ROCKY"!!!Now if you play both the Rocky and Creed movies side by side; you will I see the similarities but also you will see the big difference!This movie is an instant classic and captures the same formula that made " ROCKY " an overnight hit back in the 1970's.I give this film a 5 out of 5 stars for bringing that A-game type of feel.The5 Reasons why that this movie is great:1. Sly Stallone is at his best in this film and it wouldn't surprise me if he got a Best Supporting Actor nod at the Oscars next year.2. Michael B. Jordan is at his best here to.3. It acknowledges all the Rocky movies including the bad ones, to give the story its necessary backdrop that it needs to hold up this great film.4. Of course flashbacks of Apollo Creed.5. We finally get an answer to the age old question; who won between Rocky and Apollo in the third fight behind closed doors after "ROCKY 3".
Absolutely phenomenal work. The more I think about this film, the more impressed I am.

Words simply cannot describe how much of a simultaneous relief and absolute thrill this movie was for me .Those familiar with this franchise are aware of its tonal quirks, messily progressing from artful (and Oscar-winning) minimalism to pop-entertainment to all-out cornball fun, THEN BACK, over the course of six films. While I thoroughly enjoy its sequels for their consistent sense of optimism and overall entertainment value (I challenge you to find imagery & sound that is nearly as physically motivating), Rocky '76 remains one of my all-time favorite films for its textural grit and humble storytelling.With CREED, we have, from what I can judge, something of a miracle. Not only does it mesh the heart of the original with the mythological oomph of its sequels, but it breathlessly bridges the cultural gap between the old and the new. We see the physical and social consequences of boxing, as old heroes are juxtaposed with equally ambitious offspring as some of the most pulse-pounding boxing scenes unfold (EVER. No joke. You FEEL every punch, and many camera shots go on FOREVER). We experience a heartfelt goodbye to old friends, while meeting a new batch of interesting characters that carry enough potential for future exploration. And the city of Philadelphia pulses with the spirits of its past, even if the music scene has changed.The soundtrack, like the central character, lives up to the legacy of its heritage, and should be downloaded to the phones of all who want something to get them on their feet. I will go on record, here and now, by saying that if you see me listening to more hip-hop and rap any time soon, it's because of this movie (yeah. that's right. Rocky 7 did it folks. go ahead and judge. F*** you Kanye. F*** you Nikki. Making sounds that pump people up to do some good with their lives through sheer sonic force, and not spending millions to make dis tracks and show how Warhol i am. Sorry, that's just better music to me...i SO can expand my horizons...sigh...i'm so proud of me...rant over.)And Stallone. You beautiful bastard. You got me to cry again with your signature role. Seeing the ripples of Mighty Mick himself through this performance, thus giving a more complete arc to a legendary character, will bring generations of fans to tears. That's a fact. Give him the supporting actor statue. Ya did even more for the Duke, dammit.Great cast. Great direction. Great heart, which matters immensely for a flick like this. I salute everyone involved, and urge anyone looking for a good time at the movies to see this one as soon as humanly possible.

Creed is wonderful shot film with a good story-line that breathes new life into the Rocky franchise. From great performances of Michael B.Jordan, Sylvester Stallone and the rest of the cast along with wonderful dialogue, this side sequel is enjoyable and a successful sequel.
Solid start to finish. Good movie.
Easily the best film I've seen all year. Excellent in so many ways.

i didn't think any boxing movies were going to top Southpaw this year, but boy was i wrong! Creed is an amazing film, and it felt like it picked up right after the last one. i really hope they decide to turn this one into a franchise, but i really hope they do it right! if you like sports movies, boxing movies, rocky movies, or even none of the above, i still highly recommend you see this film, and see it in theaters just to say you were there! on a side note Michael B. Jordan is going to have an amazing future in movies, and i can't wait to see what is next!
Probably the only movie made in 25 years featuring Sly Stallone that's actually good.

Michael B. Jordan portrayed the profile of a fledgling, yet unyielding, boxer with impressive elan. His character is emblematic of anyone that has ever truly, diligently pursued a dream. And after all is said and done, perhaps our greatest legacy lies in the singular triumph over Self.
I have been on the Rocky journey from the original up to now. This one stayed true to heritage, among the best of 2015 for sure.

November 25, 2015"Creed" unfortunately proves a movie franchise can pretty much go on for all time so long as each installment is well made (and continues to make money for the studio, of course). I write "unfortunately" because although this seventh "Rocky" picture is, indeed, well made, it means we're probably bound to see more of them, and that means the talented cast and filmmakers will be diverted from other projects that could be just as good but also different, and Hollywood could use different.But I suppose I'm being unfair, not to mention unrealistic, since Hollywood ultimately sustains itself by producing the same type of content over and over again. So if we're inevitably going to get more "Rocky" movies, we should at least be grateful when they're given this kind of thought and attention. Plus, I must admit, there's something comforting about seeing the avuncular and gentle Rocky Balboa (Sylvester Stallone) every few years, watching him age across time. "Creed" even suggests the Italian Stallion has finally passed his torch to someone else and that perhaps we'll see an entirely new set of "Rocky"-like adventures, albeit with a different central character.His name would be Adonis "Doni" Creed (Michael B. Jordan), the illegitimate son of boxing legend Apollo Creed (Carl Weathers), whom you'll recall was Rocky's opponent in the first two "Rocky" films and eventually his best friend, before dying in the ring in "Rocky IV." At some point, though, Apollo had an affair and that relationship produced a son whom he never saw or supported. After young Doni's mother passes away, Apollo's widow, Mary Anne (Phylicia Rashad), feels responsible for the boy. She visits the young hothead, who's prone to fights, in a Los Angeles youth facility and asks him if he wants to come live with her, taking on the role of surrogate mother. That was in 1998. Now it's 2015, and Doni, truly "his father's son," routinely sneaks off from his cushy job at a financial firm to box in Mexico. Twelve hours later, he's back at his desk. Clearly, boxing is in the young man's blood, and he's determined to go professional and leave a legacy of his own, apart from his father, which is why he doesn't tell anyone who he really is. So Doni quits his job and moves to Philadelphia, where he seeks out Rocky as a trainer. Rocky, who still runs his own restaurant, is hesitant at first, but the kid gives him a new purpose, and so they begin training the old-school way, like waking up at the crack of dawn and running the streets of Philly, or chasing a chicken around the backyard to acquire speed and balance. Soon, Doni is winning local matches and word gets out of his true identity, which prompts the current lightweight champion, "Pretty" Ricky Conlan (Tony Bellew), to challenge him in the ring to see if the son of Creed can "really fight."Amidst his training, Doni fosters a relationship with Bianca (Tessa Thompson), an aspiring singer-songwriter, and we have to give the movie credit for actually taking the time to develop her character and for allowing Jordan and Thompson to really engage on-screen. Their one-on-one moments seem obligatory at first but the film lets them play out naturally and fully so they take on meaning. It helps, too, that the actors have strong presence and chemistry. Meanwhile, a subplot develops with Rocky as he must come to terms with his own mortality.The plot of "Creed" is by no means complicated, and much of it mirrors the original "Rocky" (1976), not to mention countless other sports movies, in regards to it structure. You know the drill: the underdog hero starts off lost and cocky and struggles with adversity and self-identity. Eventually, through hard work and determination, he gains knowledge, compassion and humility, thus coming out as victor, either literally or just in the eyes of himself, his family and his friends. We've seen this story hundreds of times, but what makes "Creed" special are its genuine human qualities. One could argue each of the characters is an archetype in a standard genre film, but the dialogue, performances and drama allow them to overcome that label. Director and co-writer Ryan Coogler ("Fruitvale Station") also adds some subtle, unexpected nuances to the storytelling that help overshadow the predictable plot. For instance, in one scene, Doni has a panic attack and needs to have his boxing gloves cut off immediately for reasons I won't reveal, although when you find out why, the moment will ring of one we've all experienced at one point or another. Praise should also be given to Claudia Castello and Michael P. Shawver's soft, rhythmic editing, which makes the drama really stick. So often in sports movies, excessive, rapid cutting prevents us from soaking everything in. But "Creed" takes its time, from a long take when Doni walks down the hall toward the climactic match, to the beauteous final shot, which could have been cheesy, but Coogler lends it grace and even the last line sounds perfectly right. Given how good "Creed" is, do I want them to make more "Rocky" movies? Honestly, no; we've seen our fair share and this one allows the series to end on a high note. I would, however, like to see more from Coogler, Jordan, Stallone and Thompson, perhaps all in the same film that tells a completely different story. Since they've shown they can breathe fresh life into a nearly 40-year-old franchise, how about they create an entirely new one altogether that's just as good? "Creed" makes me believe they can do it.
Totally overrated. Not a bad movie. ok . that's it. Can't understand why 95% liked it. I loved Rocky. I love boxing. I can't believe this movie is so predictable.

I thought it was very well done and humorous. Who would think they could bring back the "Rocky" franchise and make it great again? GREAT chemistry between the two lead actors. Nice shout-outs to Adrian, Apollo, Pauley and Mickey. Very well done and Stallone was at times hilarious.

Not going to lie, this movie was every bit as good(if not better at times) as the original Rocky. You will leave the theater wanting to become a prize fighter lol. It was fun watching the champ become the trainer. Go see it before it leaves theaters, the sound editing and film work during the fights was phenomenal.

A crowd-pleaser for sure, Creed is a rousing follow up to the Rocky franchise that manages to develop its own style as well as being on par with the original 1976 film and the equally satisfying Rocky Balboa in terms of realism and quality.
The story is well developed. The characters are intriguing.. Entertaining from start to finish.

Creed, like each of its six predecessors, is ostensibly a boxing film, and quite a good one. There are two featured fights: the first is intense and natural, punctuated by an artfully effective long take; the second is pure edge-of-your-seat action that, as clich�d as it sounds, really pumps you up. Thankfully, however, relative-newcomer Coogler recognizes what makes these movies great: not the boxing or even the plot, but the people. Creed is by no means super-original, but its big-hearted script and punchy performances soar it towards the top of the Balboa heap.Part continuation, part spin-off of the Italian Stallion saga, we meet Adonis, the son of Rocky?s one-time opponent / friend Apollo Creed, as he makes waves in the boxing community under the training of Balboa. Jordan, playing Creed, continues his assent to stardom, showing his hard-work and commitment in every frame. However, he still pales next to the Rocky character, one of the most lovable in all Hollywood cinema. Stallone wears Balboa like a wonderfully tailored old suit, playing the ever-deteriorating champ who, once the icon of running up flights of stairs, now struggles to get up a slight hill. Natural, funny, and ever-affable, Stallone puts himself deep in Oscar conversation, beautifully underlining his character?s optimistic exterior with soulful heartbreak from years of loss. This unrelenting passing of time is highlighted in an early line of the film: ?Time beat him. Time beats everybody; it?s undefeated.? But while this pessimistic realism may be the message, it is by no means the attitude; Creed is still very much a ?Rocky? film at its core: unabashedly earnest and crowd-pleasing.
A great movie and the second best Rocky film after the first.

Not normally a fan of the genre, but, this was pretty amazing. So well done all the way around, performances (Stallone, Stallone, Stallone), script, and, especially, direction. Best Director and, perhaps, picture.
Great movie. I would see it again.

Loved it.!!! Does it resemble "Rocky"? yes...but in it's own way. It had enough new story...added with old story...to make a great combination and amazing movie....when some of the old Rocky score was used...yes..it made me cry....and yes..I cried at least 3-4 times.....Love Stallone in this roll...Michael B Jordan does an amazing job as young Creed too!

Watched all six (6) Rocky films over three nights to get a feel for a franchise that I've never been interested in before - and was pleasantly surprised. This passing of the torch story does rely on key locations and scenes from Sly Stallone's best work as writer/actor/(sometime)director, and is not without its slower moments. Michael B. Jordan cuts a lean machine and the fight scenes are choreographed well. Not sure about the Oscar buzz at the moment, but it is certainly very enjoyable and approaches the quality of the first and last Rocky movies.

This is the 2nd WORST Rocky movie only better than 5. There's a cultural shift in Hollywood and America in general that now loves anything black even if it's not good. This shift happened once Obama came into office. This movie is just okay. It's not anywhere near as good as 1-4 nor does it stand against Rocky Balboa. Don't be fooled by the white guilt everything black is cool movement.

This is a very good boxing movie and part of the 'Rocky' franchise. Just me and two talkers where all the Old Geezers Who Go To The Matinee Alone showed up, but except for the damn talking we enjoyed it. Sylvester Stallone takes his role out again and it is terrific. In this movie Stallone only acts and is Executive Producer (ever wonder what they do? I do) but the focus is on Michael B. Jordan, a very good young actor. The story proceeds like most boxing movies from the bad guys winning, the good guys having a crisis, the good guy comes back and works out and wins in the end. No spoiler there, all boxing movies are like that. Anyway I had a great time and might even go see it again.

Works on every level: From passing the torch while simultaneously being a sequel and a reimagining/remake that somehow remains fresh to the chemistry between Jordan and Stallone's chemistry to a female lead with an original, natural romance element, this movie fires on all cylinders. The soundtrack and the tight direction add to it. Particular praise to Stallone as one of cinema's mostly fondly remembered characters shows his age.

Yes, it is formulaic, but when a formula works, it works. Enjoyed every scene. Lots of emotion in little scenes and big ones. Even some very subtle touches were the action begged to copy one of earlier Rocky movies, but refused to do so. Acting was solid, with Stallone as the stand out in a supporting role.
Great story, great acting and the soundtrack will make you want to embark on a training montage.
Very good movie overall. Could not form an emotional attachment to the main character. Fight scenes are amazing. Good plot and excellent acting. Highly recommend.

Creed is more than just a boxing movie or a Rocky spin-off. Its a varying tale of outgrowing one's parental shadow, identity, loss, and hope. Sylvester Stallone returns as Rocky Balboa, as a trainer this time, but also gives the film some legitimacy. The film's boxing scenes are done smoothly without cuts, to heighten the brutal boxing matches between opponents. The movie is able to balance, drama, sports, and still provide a familiar but new story, with a new character. Most spin-offs are made for a quick buck, but Creed is one that can hold its head up high in that regard.
It's hokey, it's predictable and, if you're a fan, it's surprisingly engaging. A big reason is that Stallone-often an underrated actor -underplays the role.

Pound for pound, this is a nice tribute movie to the original Rocky.All of the little moments that made the original film so nice to watchare here in modernized versions. I never felt bored at any point in thefilm, which is a testament to how great the director andcinematographer are. There are moments where the film was simplystunning, captivating, and honest. What made it less than perfect forme is the anticlimactic ending. It just didn't have the sameoverwhelming excitement for me as the original. Of all the Rocky films,I had Rocky ranked first followed by Rocky Balboa. I think Creeddeserves to be right in between those two. Hoping to see Creed II.
Creed is one of the year's best films, hands down.

The director stresses one single point through-out the film, and never forgets that he himself is following that one idea...creating his own legend. Creed is a brand new film on its own, yet molds so beautifully into the incredible Rocky series. Although tipping his hat to the Rocky series numerous times, the film is left classy by never falling to the cliches we want or expect...and it works..

Let's be honest here. Creed is not a work of art, it is formula, predictable and clich�d. But it is also enormously entertaining, wonderfully uplifting and features the best performance ever by Sylvestor Stallone. But is he really acting? As far as I am concerned he is really Rocky and his public persona is someone else. He is great as the aging Rocky Balboa who takes the young son of his old adversary and friend Apollo Creed under his wing to lead him to boxing greatness. Young Michael B Jordan as the young Creed is terrific, fulfilling the potential he showed many years ago as the youngster Wallace in The Wire. And don't think this movie is just for guys. My wife was shadow boxing throughout the boxing scenes throwing lefts and rights as she became caught up in the action. And the villain of the peace is from Liverpool England so he is very easy to hate. Highly recommended.

Not as edgy as fellow 2015 boxing flick Southpaw, but tonally more consistent and featuring an equally brilliant central performance, this Rocky spinoff delivers the sort of fist pumping sports drama you would expect. Following Adonis "son of Apollo" Creed as he channels his anger into a boxing career, there's little variation from the tried-and-tested cinematic sporting formula, but it's executed with such flair and intensity that barely matters. Taking on both writing and helming duties, Ryan Coogler's technically marvellous direction finds fresh ways to capture both the drama and the action, dispelling any thoughts that his fantastic debut Fruitvale Station was a one-off. The training montages are traditional yet electric, the emotional beats are occasionally a little too melodramatic yet still pack a wallop, and the showdowns in the ring are ferocious and exhilarating. There's a truly awe-inspiring mid-film fight that is shot in one, long continuous take (aided by some cleverly hidden edits), which stands up as a genuine contender for the best sequence of the year. Bulked up and bringing the emotional heft, Michael B. Jordan puts Fantastic Four far in his review mirror with a compelling portrayal of a man attempting to step out from underneath another's shadow in order to craft his own legacy. Sylvester Stallone shakes off the cobwebs to return for the seventh time as the Italian Stallion, thankfully toning down his usual overwrought acting to offer a subtler supporting turn as Adonis' mentor and surrogate father. Serving up a hugely satisfying slice of sporting drama, both Coogler and Jordan demonstrate they are young Hollywood players to keep a close eye on.
Best movie of the year ...., almost

The name Rocky has become a home stable for many people since the release of the first film, and over the years the series has been going up and down in terms of quality. So after a implausible but still enjoyable finale to Rocky's legacy titled: Rocky Balboa, the director of my favorite indie film of 2013: Ryan Coogler decided to do a spin-off to this great series titled: Creed. And oh boy, this is what i hope Star Wars: The Force Awakens does that Creed did: Have a new fresh take for young and old adults while keeping the energy and spirit of the series alive. The film has many things that makes this not even close to ripping off the series: a great and moving story about Apollo Creed's unknown son, a emotional and very uplifting tone, great cinematography and boxing action that adds grip and tension to the film, and a spectacular performance from Michael B. Jordan and a LEGENDARY performance from Sylvester Stallone whose role as Rocky fits PERFECTLY in this film and shows that Stallone NEEDS to return to this type of role he once defined. Though only the final sequence is lackluster than the rest of the film, Creed definitely finds the spirit of not just Rocky Balboa but also his enemy and friend: Apollo Creed.

My first impression of the announcement of CREED was that the movie was being produced as a way to continue milking a dead franchise for every penny that could be squeezed out of bored audiences. When I realized that Ryan Coogler would co-write and direct, I became a bit more excited about the movie. As it turns out, I should have been *much more excited. Coogler delivers an emotional powerhouse with CREED in addition to coordinating one of the most technically interesting movies of the year. Further, Coogler uses his film as a way to inject discourse on race, heritage, and aging. The story is packed with various character developments along with the expected boxing action. Somehow, though, nothing ever seems rushed or out of place. The story is both intricate and pieced together well. The movie is about the son of Rocky Balboa's greatest opponent: Apollo Creed. Creed's son, Adonis (Michael B. Jordan), finds himself attracted to fighting, but unable to get out from under his father's shadow. In his process of accepting his history, Adonis turns to Rocky for help while trying to make a name for himself as a boxer. Odie Henderson of the Chicago Sun-Times observes, regarding the climax of Adonis' journey, that "the moment he owns up to his heritage is intertwined with the film's rousing, climactic boxing match but does not depend on it as a means of [his] acceptance". The ending definitely serves up an interesting boxing match, but is far from a typical ending for the genre and features much more significant stakes than winning at a sporting event. Coogler's script and direction were no doubt invaluable to the success of the movie.Visual story-telling is equally as important as scripting, though. Coogler's CREED features excellent cinematographic moments throughout the whole feature. The style of cinematography adapts to the needs of the moment. Directorial and Director of Photography choices also well balance intimate moments with broad, environmentally sweeping ones. Other technical elements are noticeably outstanding as well - particularly, sound mixing and sound editing contribute to powerful visceral effects. While the tech elements are impressive, front and center in CREED is the wonderful ensemble. Michael B. Jordon brings attention to detail and makes interesting choices as always. Although, in my opinion, Phylisia Rashad and Sylvester Stallone steal the show in their supporting roles. Unfortunately, too little screen time is offered to Rashad. Stallone, on the other hand, makes a surprisingly heart-felt return to the role of Rocky and is given plenty of time shine. Rocky's outward and inward battles with age, death, purpose, and the role of family is heart-wrenching and fascinating to watch. Whether or not he receives it, Stallone deserves another nomination.The true "winner" here is Coogler, though. A young, black director, Coogler is very likely to be overlooked for awards attention (much like with his previous film efforts) even though his work is among the best I've seen this year. I can only cross my fingers that Coogler will receive the accolades he deserves. With or without awards, though - Coogler has offered up an interesting and important movie with CREED. In fact, its one of the best movies I've seen this year.

It's easy to forget that the original Rocky was a masterpiece. A couple of terrible sequels will do that to popular perceptions. This also happened with Sylvester Stallone's other signature character Rambo, which had a truly excellent original thriller and weak, silly sequels. But I like to assert that there was great value in the character of Rocky Balboa and there were some later installments that did work. Rocky II and III were fun, above average efforts that handled character development in a way most mainstream franchises these days seem incapable of accomplishing. And sure IV and V were steaming pieces of garbage, but Rocky Balboa (2006) redeemed the character in a realistic and endearing turn. So a spin-off using an entirely new character may seem totally unnecessary. So why is this movie so damn good? Creed (no, not the crappy post-grunge band) centers around the son of Apollo Creed, Adonis, as he tries to hack out his destiny in the arena. Along the way, an older Rocky Balboa takes him on as an apprentice, serving as his Obi-Wan Kenobi like mentor. Both form a bond and learn to keep fighting in the face of tough odds. Creed doesn't break any mold, but it manages to fill it quite well, delivering a hard hitting but sentimental movie that both Rocky fans and general audiences will enjoy. Michael B. Jordan comes into his own as a leading man, proving that Hollywood really needs to start putting more diverse actors in roles such as these. He has the right amount of likeability and charisma that made Rocky such a relatable character in the original film. He commits fully and deserves credit for not using a body double during production, receiving all the punishment himself. Sylvester Stallone reminds us that yes, he can act. Old Sly provides much of the humor and light-hearted-ness of many scenes, while bringing a special type of gravitas to the film. This is a character that has grown immensely over the years, graduated from the school of hard knocks, and has much wisdom to offer to our protagonist. But what makes the picture exceptional is the back and forth between the two. There are funny moments as I mentioned before, but there are also touching and bittersweet scenes as well - on par with any awards season material this year. Creed is well directed and edited with Ryan Coogler accomplishing a masterful job helming his first large film with precision. The fight scenes are brutal and skillfully choreographed. The camera work is impressive, often revolving around the action and seemingly in one take. The final fight scene in particular, bears much in common with the climatic showdown at the end of the original film. In fact, I was quite impressed how reverential Creed was in relation to the rest of the franchise, treating all the previous movies as canon, even the bad ones. Furthermore, while these are used as background, they are not exploited or rehashed as one might expect. The love interest for the main character was completely tacked on and unnecessary and proves to be the sole weakness. So yes, you need to see this film. It is, in my opinion, the best since Rocky III, a good start to a new spin-off franchise, and one of the best dramas of the year. It goes the distance.

Overrated. Who cares about Apollo Creed's son?? Poor writing. I love the Rocky franchise but I'm gonna have to pass on this one. I hope they don't come out with more "Creed" movies and if they do I won't be watching. Sorry not sorry.

As both a continuation of the Rocky franchise and a stand-alone boxing film, Creed is a knockout! Ryan Coogler once again delivers the same powerful direction he made with Fruitvile Station, while Michael B. Jordan continues to shine with his acting career. However, the Italian Stallion himself, Sylvester Stallone, continues to hit the hard emotional punches with his performance as Rocky Balboa. A

A pretty good movie, with great performances from the whole cast. The movie also represents Philadelphia with great shooting locations, visuals, and its culture. The movie starts off kind of typical and seems to be cliche. But, a little after the mid point, the writing really gets good and the movie gets deep and emotional. Unfortunately, this is the point where Stallone becomes the main character and Jordan becomes the supporting actor. Nevertheless at this point, the chemistry between Stallone and Jordan really become remarkable and brings the movie to another level. The movie also has great fighting cinematography and choreography, which gives the movie a lot of excitement. Even though this movie is trying to be a stand alone movie and a reboot, it is definitely a sequel because the movie doesn't really start getting to be an excellent movie until we feel the emotion from Rocky. Also, when that Rocky music comes on, you know it's on. Don't get me wrong, Jordan does great, and later in the movie you start understanding Creed's pain as well. With all of this said, It is a must see.

I suspected CREED was not as great as critics and audiences were saying, but I wasn't incredibly disappointed. For one thing, Stallone continues to be a great Rocky Balboa. The story is good but dragged out and other characters are not fleshed out quite enough to sustain the length of the film. Also several scenes which should have an enormous emotional impact fall flat. At any rate, I'm glad I saw it.
Cant wait to go see this. Love Stallone & all the Rocky movies!!

Adonis Johnson never knew his famous father,world heavy weight champion Apollo Creed, who died before he was born. Still, there's no denying that boxing is in his blood, so Adonis heads to Philadelphia, the site of Apollo Creed's legendary match with a tough upstart named Rocky Balboa. Rocky sees in Adonis the strength and determination he had known in Apollo - the fierce rival who became his closest friend. [Rotten Tomatoes]Let's get this out of the way: Creed is hype. It's got the raw grit and the perfectly calculated emotional beats of Fruitvale Station. It's got two of the best powerhouse performances of the year; that by Michael B. Jordan as Adonis and Sylvester Stallone as an older, melancholic version of Rocky. Stallone deserves an Oscar nomination for Best Supporting Actor this year because he killed it. It was really astonishing to see Stallone give his best performance in years.Ryan Coogler's debut film, Fruitvale Station, is one of my favorite biopics and a truly beautiful drama that I deeply cherish. As one would expect, Coogler's direction was top-notch and it elevated Creed above your typical boxing movie trappings. Hands down, this film is the best boxing movie since The Fighter in 2010. It more than makes up for the disappointment I found Southpaw to be. I appreciated how the script, written by Coogler and Aaron Convington, knew how to cater to all generations. It's hella nostalgic and I love how there's a great balance between the old and the new.The best part of the film is the fight sequences, directed with flawless grace by Coogler. The action is heavy and intense, the sound design makes sure that you feel every hit and the first two major fights are enough to get your blood pumping and adrenaline rushing long after the credits roll. The one-take fight around the half-way point is the best sequence I've seen in a film this year. It was so perfectly done and when it was finished, I almost fell over. I felt like I was taking each punch and that is something to praise.Another highlight of the film is the absolutely fantastic score. It's epic and loud and empowering. I loved how ambitious Ludwig G�ransson's approach to it was. Also, all the various artists that accompany the soundtrack help turn Creed into a great technical beast. It was sweet to hear "The Fire" by The Roots & John Legend at a high point in this movie. Lastly, a really cool idea was to have Tessa Thompson performing original songs, as well as acting as Bianca, the love interest of Adonis.Creed is a must-see knockout and one of the best films of 2015. It's emotionally complex, choreographed with technical finesse and acted beautifully. I was fighting back the tears a few times throughout the run-time and that's a good thing. If you love boxing movies, this is the one you've been waiting for. Creed knocked me off my feet and it was a wicked experience. Highly recommended.

Better than Rocky Balboa, fantastic drama, restored my confidence in Michael B. Jordan. Oh, and give Sly Stallone an Oscar, because he was ACTING. a lot of older actors *cough* arnold, bruce willis *cough* just phone in roles and they make fun of themselves. Sly actually played a person with a story around him.

(4/5) You might not expect much more than a cash grab judging from the concept of Creed, but don't worry, because director Ryan Coogler will make you care. This is at once an intimate character drama and an exhilarating sports film in great balance. Coogler is faithful to the environment and emotional concentration he captured with Fruitvale Station, but Creed showcases his abilities even more, leaving me convinced that he can do just about anything.The environment that Coogler creates here is similar to that of his great independent hit, Fruitvale Station. Both take place in small cities and highlight a grittiness that reflects a unique and underrepresented perspective in cinema. His film does not, for the sake of Hollywood, shy away from having a black voice. It's refreshing that Coogler is confident about sticking to his roots and showcasing what he knows. Creed is certainly a Rocky film and has plenty of references to the old ones, but works, as I'd hoped, entirely on its own, thanks to a director who makes films that are distinctly his.Coogler spends a lot of time with his characters, increasing the emotional stakes and creating genuine tension between them so that we care for far more than just the boxing. He manages to get great performances out of actors Michael B Jordan, Sylvester Stallone, and Tessa Thompson. Jordan convinces us of his character's innate aggression and will to fight, but certainly allows us to see his insecurities and emotional side. Tessa Thompson gives far more depth to her character than one might expect. Her unique interests make her a well-rounded character, and Thompson gives her character a fitting amount of wittiness, intelligence, and independence that is rare to see in her type of role. Stallone relives his character in an extremely grounded way that exposes subtle emotional turmoil. The boxing scenes in Creed are exhilarating. The first boxing scene is more intimate, small scaled and personal, filmed all in a single shot. Each punch feels so real that audiences will cringe at every hard blow. The single shot captures an intensity and moment of exhilaration for Adonis. The finale boxing sequence is filmed completely differently, but is equally effective. This time the stakes are much higher and the fight is being broadcast nationally, and we get broadcasting narration, which is put to surprisingly well use. The editing brings this scene together fantastically, as we cut between shots we'd see on television to more intimate shots, to reactions of Adonis' loved ones. Although this scene makes a heavier use of editing, it never uses editing to disguise the punches, and evokes that same cringe-worthy feeling from the audience as the first match did. What kept me from loving Creed is that for all the time it spends with its characters, and for how developed they are, I didn't feel that the character's spiritual motivations were as strong as they could have been. Certain issues in Adonis's life as well as Rocky and his girlfriend's life could have been explored deeper to give the film a more triumphant feeling that wasn't just accomplished through the fighting. That doesn't mean Creed is a flat film thematically, but it didn't bring a level of depth I think it could have for the great characters it built. Audiences should flock to the theaters to see Creed and will flock away very satisfied with not only the boxing, but with the characters, weather they wanted a character-driven movie or not.

Somewhere after hitting commercial and critical gold to the tune of two Oscar statues with the first Rocky, Sylvester Stallone created a musclebound, bulletproof, campy 80's alter ego: Sly. The Sylvester who penned a beautiful script about a down-and-out boxer who makes the best of a gift opportunity to enter the ring against a brash champion had been vanquished by the loud bombast of the umpteenth Rambo sequel. Look no further than the latest Expendables movie if you want the Ne Plus Ultra of Stallone's schlocky 80's roided, orange, action man. The last thing I expected walking into this movie was any resembling a return to form of a soulful Stallone. He's back and, if you'll excuse the pun, he's added a few wrinkles to his game. In Creed, he's essentially swapped roles with Micky from the from the first 3 movies. Now Michael B. Jordan playing the upstart boxer and Stallone is now the grizzled old trainer. As much as I enjoyed the previous Rocky films, the boxing fan in much grimaced during each of the boxing scenes. Not from thunderous blows landed but by how exaggerated the actual boxing choreography was. In Creed, they finally get it right. In fact, the actual boxing in depicted this film might be the most realistic portrayal of sweet science in any movie ever. Much of the credit goes to the director and cinematographer for the staging but also to Michael B. Jordan for really selling it. In fact, every boxer Creed faces in this film was played by real boxers and Jordan's scenes with them hardly ever hit a false note. It was really nice to see Stallone the actor back on screen in perhaps his last Rocky film. After a period of unsuccessful actioners, Stallone sought after smaller roles to showcase his acting. He even appeared in Copland opposite of acting heavyweights like De Niro and Keitel. Whatever his acting aspirations were, Stallone will certainly be remembered more for his macho action films. But just this one, it was good to be in the company of the understated, loving Rocky we all knew and loved. If the Rocky franchise is the definitive work of Stallone's career, then he can rest assured that he's passed his baby on to Ryan Coogler's caring, confident hands. This wasn't simply a case of a fresh-faced but fledgling director acting as a hired gun: Coogler wrote this script and his directorial choices breathe new life into what could have been an exploitative, by-the-numbers cash grab. Sports movies about struggling athletes are a mindfield at this point with so many opportunities for missteps. Jordan really kills the role as Creed's illegitimate son seeking to step out of his father's shadow but also try to be the man that he was. And for a young director stepping up to his first mainstream film, Coogler really knocks this one out of the park. This is the second film the actor and director have made together and the chemistry is obvious. Just as Rocky was the big break Stallone needed to launch his career, here's to Creed for giving Coogler and Jordan the breakthrough they deserve. And here's to more of their shared work together in the future, cinema will the better for it.

VIEWS ON FILM review by Jesse BurlesonYou gotta hand it to Sylvester Stallone. About fifteen years ago, I figured his career had been left for dead. Somehow with his revision of Rambo, his clout to get studios to make those Expendable movies, and his relentless drive to revitalize an old, punch-drunk boxer, he's gotten into Hollywood's good graces once again. Heck, back in the day I used to quip, "Sly who?"Anyway, unless you've been living on a desert island via the last four decades, you'll know that Creed (my latest review) is indeed the 7th film in the storied, Rocky saga. Everyone in character Rocky Balboa's life, is gone. That includes his spouse Adrian, his brother-in-law Paulie, his trainer Mickey, and his old boxing rival Apollo. But hey, nothing can stop Stallone and company from milking every bit of the Italian Stallion's account till it runs bone dry. That's why he brought in director Ryan Coogler (he did Fruitvale Station) along with his budding movie star, Michael B. Jordan (he was the lead in Fruitvale Station). Translation: This is yet a bland Rocky entry but a mature, valiant effort. It's on par with Rocky Balboa (2006), it's a lot better than Rocky V (I'd hope so), and it has moments that are deeper and more subdued than Rocky IV ("I must break you" ha ha). Somewhere somehow though, I can still hear the late Burgess Meredith saying, "I'm going on a permanent vacation". Rocky being an Irwin Winkler-produced franchise with its obligatory training sequences and its obligatory final fights, should probably just do the same.Containing a film score that feels less compelling this time around (probably because Bill Conti wasn't at the helm) and featuring sound effects inhibiting a hammer slamming into a cookie sheet, Creed delves into Apollo's illegitimate son, Adonis (Michael B. Jordan). Adonis never knew his deceased dad but subconsciously, he always had the need to fight, to punch someone with plenty of lefts and rights. At the beginning of the proceedings, he's a teenager, serving time in a Los Angeles youth facility. When Apollo's actual widow shows up to take him in, Adonis goes with her, finally knowing who his father is and eventually finding out what he wants to do with his life. Cut to 2015 and he's winning fights in Mexico while working at a securities firm on the side. He eventually quits his job, moves to the fighting city of Philadelphia, and seeks out a man who had a long history with his pops. That would be Mr. Rocky Balboa. After some resistance from wanting to train the youthful Adonis, old Rocco caves in knowing that this youngin wants to be the light heavyweight champion of the world. "Baby" Creed in time, wins one big fight and then somehow gets a title shot in Liverpool, England. It's all far-fetched stuff but then again, so is the grizzled adage, "it's only a movie".Now the main asset in Creed, is how its story translates easily from the events in the previous Philadelphia slugger installments. It would make sense that Rocky would now be too old to fight. It would make sense that Rocky still ran a restaurant and was open to training a young buck. It would make sense that Apollo Creed's son would come knocking on Rocky's door salivating for sparring advice. Finally, it would make sense that Rocky would go back to grieve Adrian and Paulie at their respective grave sites (for reasons unknown, the Paulie Pennino character kicks the bucket circa 2012). My biggest misstep involving this flick however, is how the lead troupers (mainly Michael B. Jordan and romantic interest Tessa Thompson) fail to meet the demands of selling Creed's most considerable and most substantial scenes. Basically, they turn it into something that lacks the dramatic heft of the earlier movies and the entertainment value/popcorn feel of Rocky III and Rocky IV. What's left is a slow-burning affair, a vehicle that goes through the motions and renders itself vapid. As the end credits rolled, all I wanted to do was revisit Mr. T's portrayal in 1982, Rocky and Apollo's second Superfight in 1979, and Philly's favorite son hitting the proverbial meat back in 76'. It's all in the (collection addition) DVD set and it comes pretty cheap at Best Buy. My overall rating: 2 and a half stars.Of note: There's been talk about Stallone possibly getting an Academy Award nomination for his work in Creed. I'll admit, he knows the character well and occasionally, has some heartfelt moments. But Oscar? Come on. In all seriousness it seems like a bit of a stretch don't you think?

The best Rocky movie since the original, as well as the best boxing film since The Fighter. Creed finds director Ryan Coogler making a more commercial transition after the success of his indie film Fruitvale Station, but sacrifices none of his razor-sharp filmmaking tactics. The film just carries a weight too it that most modern sports movie exudes, as it's plausible, semi-gritty, and ultimately triumphant. Is it groundbreaking? Hardly, but audiences with reasonable expectations and a yearning for a real underdog story will get there money's worth and then some.

Admittedly, I was a lot skeptical when I first saw the trailer for Creed. But I was pleasantly surprised with a film that captured the heart and fun of the Rocky films. Long time Rocky fans will be happy to see old staples and icons come to life again on the big screen; and Michael B. Jordan and Sylvester Stallone deliver stellar performances.

Ryan Coogier's wonderfully rousing new entry in the Rocky legacy. It tells the engrossing story of Adonis "Hollywood" Johnson, the illegitimate son of the late great heavyweight boxing champion, Apollo Creed, who died before he was born, Adonis is superbly played by Michael B. Jordan, in a truly sensational performance that is filled with fire and conviction. Adonis is a gifted fighter in his own right and is making his way up the ranks, while trying to face his father's legacy. But Adonis is up against a tremendously dangerous fighter by the name Leo "The Lion" Sporino, well-played by Gabe Rosado, for this upcoming match he seeks out his late father's best friend and opponent the legendary former heavyweight boxing champion Rocky Baloba as a mentor and trainer, played magnificently again by the scene-stealing Sylvester Stallone returning to his iconic signature role, his impressive surprisingly subtle performance has already won him the National Board of Review Critic's Award for Best Supporting Actor. What follows is a brilliant well-crafted motion picture of style and substance that exhilarates and has the audience rooting for the underdog, thanks to Coogier's masterful direction. The edge of your seat boxing sequences are fiercely intense and visceral. Solid entertainment from beginning to end, and an exceptional crowd pleaser. Highly Recommended.
It was good, but not the classic I expected.
fantastic. don't miss this movie. loved it. lots of connections to the original but it's solid on it's own. really well done.

Creed is sensational, heart-pounding film that will inspire and entertain the younger generation. Michael B. Jordan and Sylvester Stallone are both phenomenal. They have given the best performances so far that they will make you feel sympathy and emotional. They have the chemistry to keep themselves stable to keep moving forward. Even though this is Ryan Coogler's second directional movie, he is already showing audiences that he is a incredible filmmaker with more masterpieces to come. Creed is a must-see sports drama that will get your adrenaline fueled up. 5/5

The director of Fruitvale Station sure knows how to build characterization. The latest entry in the revered franchise showcases powerhouse acting in a way that speaks to both young and old generations alike. Dreamer trains dreamer who dates dreamer aimed for dreamers. Happy dreaming... after your food coma this holiday season!

Creed is well done, and I loved it. There were a few questions I realized later that weren't answered, loose ends from the previous Rocky Balboa movie, but we're moving forward here, not looking back.In Creed, Adonis Creed ascends to his birthright, with Rocky's help. The torch is passed.Adonis Creed is a natural born fighter, the son of boxing champion Apollo Creed, who died in the ring decades ago fighting Russian champion Ivan Drago. With his birth parents dead, Adonis receives the love of a good woman who decides to become his guardian and raise him right. Eventually, Adonis seeks a mentor to help him take his natural ability to a higher level. His new mentor is Rocky, of course. This is a beautiful friendship for both of them. Rocky has come full circle into his own mentor Mickey's role. He's ready to help young Creed rise up, and Creed also helps motivate and support Rocky as he fights his own great battle, a battle for his life.It's both a fun and touching story. There's a romance, too. Looks like it's love at first sight when Creed meets his beautiful new neighbor, Bianca. He gets busy trying to win her, while also working on preparing for fights.The story and the fighting are well done, satisfying. Could the ending be any more picture perfect? Clearly, this story was made to continue, with Creed II, Creed III, etc. I'm looking forward to it.

Creed is the Rocky reboot we didn't know was coming. In 1976, Apollo Creed takes on unknown Rocky Balboa in an exhibition match that nobody believed would last 3 rounds. Rocky demonstrates an almost immortal ability to take punishment and stands toe to toe with the Champ. Twenty nine years later Apollo Creeds illegitimate son shows up on Rocky's door step to ask the aging, now restaurateur, former champ to help him train. At first Rocky declines, but soon comes to see something worthy in the young Creed and agrees. From there we see nearly the same story that we saw in 1976. The young Creed isn't taken seriously but is invited by the current champ "Pretty Ricky" to enter the ring. Ricky's intended opponent suffer a broken jaw at Ricky's hand during a promotional session ending a million dollar bought. Young Creed of course says yes and we see nearly the same fight we saw in '76.Don't let that turn you off, it worked in 1976 and it works in 2015. Michael B. Jordan brings a surprising amount of depth to a troubled kid who spent half his life in Juvenile Hall and the other half growing up with the widow of Apollo Creed. For his part Stallone reprises his Rocky character, a simple man with few needs who just wants to live a quiet life surrounded by the memorabilia of his days in the sun while waiting out his time to join his dead wife and brother in law in the afterlife.Creed pulls all the right strings at all the right times. These two men, both suffering from different injuries, bring healing to each other. Creed learns that there are actually people in his life he can trust and Rocky learns that there's something to live for after all.I give this two thumbs up.
The story is very good and Stallone Jordan are fantastic, really you will like this movie

With Rocky Balboa's career at and end, the Rocky franchise becomes invigorated with the arrival of Creed. Michael B. Jordan delivers a great performance as Adonis Creed, the son of the late Apollo Creed. Creed mirrors the original Rocky, while adding new plot points. Sylvester Stallone gives his best performance in years and is definitely a shoe-in to win Best Supporting Actor at next year's Oscars. After all, portraying the iconic Rocky Balboa is what he does best. A new franchise involving Adonis Creed is certainly on it's way, and with Michael B. Jordan at the helm, we can expect Rocky's legacy to be honored.
Fantastic installment in the Rocky series. Stallone is great and so is Jordan. This is the best installment since Rocky IV. Pleasantly surprised.
This movie is awesome and Sylvester Stallone will probably win the Academy Award for best supporting.

Definitely not just another Rocky movie. Intense, funny and surprisingly well acted, it's one of the most entertaining films of the year. The fight sequences are awesome.

The movie "Creed" is an epic follow up to the Rocky movie franchise. From the beginning the movie automatically pulls you in and attaches you to the main character Adonis "Doni" by following him from his rough journey as a troubled youth in and out of foster homes to current day Adonis, the illegitimate son of professional boxer Apollo Creed. This is not just another boxing movie this movie is about the fight for survival and the fight for who you want to be in life. Doni leaves his life of luxury in LA to move to Philadelphia in hopes of training with the one man who had beaten his father in a fight "The Italian Stallion" Rocky Balboa. As Doni and Rocky's relationship starts to grow so does Doni not just as a fighter but as a person overall. This movie is fantastic and has something for everyone action, romance, and some tear jerker moments.

So as it turns out one of the best Rocky movies is not even a Rocky movie. I thought that the trailer looked interesting, but my expectations were not all that high. I was hoping for something that was at least as decent as Rocky Balboa, but based on the story line, I was half expecting something along the lines of Rocky V... Well all I have to say is WOW! I love coming out of a movie that defies my expectations and surprises me like that. The story was fantastic and felt like it had a lot of heart. The directing was really good... It maintained the "Rocky feel" but brought something new that made it a bit unique. The acting was great and Sylvester Stallone did an amazing job at playing a Rocky that we are not use to seeing. This is easily better then the last 3 Rocky movies... It felt really good in the same way that the first 3 did. I really hope that they don't continue to spin things off in to a new franchise... Because this was the perfect ending to an old one. 4.5 stars
With an intense and emotional story, perfect direction from Coogler, and fantastic performances from Jordan and Stallone, Creed is a sequel that actually lives up to the original.

Great film, has its moments of cheese like imitating certain rocky moments. The soundtrack was ok but for me lacked the punch of the original rocky movies, ll in all a very enjoyable film with just a few small flaws.

I wouldn't call myself a fan of the Rocky movies, even though I really liked the first film, and I quite enjoyed the last one, Balboa. Still, the Rocky movies are just whatever to me. However, I, like many people, heard some buzz about Creed, and it got me curious, and so I decided to give this film a chance, and I am pleased to say that I am so very glad that I did. Well directed, acted, shot, lit, scored, etc. Creed is worthy of Academy Nominations across the board, especially, and surprisingly, from Sylvester Stallone. Bottom line: Go so Creed in the theaters, ASAP! I give Creed an A+.

CREED is not only the best film to feature the character of Rocky Balboa since 1976's ROCKY, it is also one of the strongest movies of 2015, featuring a thoughtful script, excellent performances, and dynamite direction. Implementing a storyline that is an extension of the ROCKY series more than it is a real sequel, Michael B. Jordan's Adonis is very clearly the focus, with Sylvester Stallone's Balboa being a true supporting figure, albeit one with a strong character arc of his own. The script is surprisingly sensitive as it charts its course, just as it is structured incredibly well; it's also a testament to the script that the movie's romantic subplot feels entirely of-a-piece and not some kind of distraction (this is also aided by very appealing work from Tessa Thompson, who has great chemistry with Jordan). Jordan has a magnetic star presence, and he handles Adonis - who could be a tricky guy to portray - with total ease; this is a guy with a chip on his shoulder, and who is insecure, but who is also a fundamentally decent and good person. Stallone, for his part, contributes career-best work; that might be damning-with-faint-praise to some, but Sly's effort here is deeply moving, with several moments of powerful emotion that (importantly) are not overplayed. Speculation of awards potential for Stallone's performance is absolutely warranted. Co-writer/director Ryan Coogler is the other key piece of the puzzle, and his direction is energetic, visceral, and engaging throughout; this is a guy who clearly "gets it," who knows how to shoot and stage things with both a classical eye and style/personality (there's a single take fight in the middle of the movie that is thrilling and inventive). His contributions to the script are equally impressive, because the movie completely works as an installment of a franchise, while also saying something truly personal. Longtime fans of the ROCKY movies will surely dig this film, but those who are arriving at the material with fresh and impartial eyes will almost certainly a lot of things to enjoy. Engrossing throughout, CREED is a great movie.
Rocky fan.. now a Creed fan

Easily one of the best movies I've seen this year. it's faithful to all the things you'd expect from a Rocky movie, including the music, but updates it all to feel fresh and current. Michael B. Jordan is fantastic as the star of the show, and he and Stallone have great chemistry. The story has heart and comedy and a few great fight scenes as well. The main event was so stirring the people in the theater with me were clapping, cheering, and gasping with every punch. That's how engrossing this movie is.
Joe and I really enjoyed this movie. Best line IMO was "Father Time is undefeated"

Creed isn't the seventh film in the Rocky franchise. It's the first movie in a franchise about Adonis Creed, the son of the famed boxer Apollo Creed. As the name implies, it's about a self-taught fighter trying to break into the boxing world under his own name instead of riding the reputation of his famous father. The movie is good with no complaints. There is however one important thing to point out. Creed is directed by Ryan Coogler and stars Michael B Jordan. This is important because it's the duo that directed and starred in 'Fruitville Station', the real life story of the death of Oscar Grant. If you haven't seen Fruitville you're missing something powerful and great. Creed isn't as powerful but just as good at following Jordan through a range of emotions. There isn't much to say about Stallone as Rocky Balboa, the movie isn't about him. Stallone, like his character plays a supporting role taking Creed in and training him when no one else would. There is a lot of significance here. While Balboa passes the boxing torch to Creed, Stallone passes the torch of the franchise to Jordan. In the end, Creed overcomes the battle with his demons. It's also clear that Michael B Jordan has overcome the reputation of 'Fantastic Four'. And the big screen is better off for because of both.
If you love Rocky, you'll love this. It's the perfect Rocky movie, and the only one of those is the original. So go see it already!
Great Movie, almost predictable, will see it again.

Before I get started on this review, I should let the public know that my review maybe slightly inaccurate as I watched this film hungover running on 4 hours sleep and catching the 9;30pm session. I still stand by this review, if this changes after I watch this movie a second time i'll update my review. I apologise for my unprofessionalism as I know hundreds, dare I say thousands of people rely on my reviews.If anybody asks me what my favourite movie of all time is my answer is Rocky, it doesn't even matter which part i'm referring too. Rocky is the best movie of all time for me full stop. So I had been waiting for this movie to hit for a long time super excited. My expectations and hopes were sitting so high but that all came crashing down 3rd nov 2015.I was very disappointed to find out Sly hadn't written or directed this movie, everybody knows Rocky was built on Sly's back so the thought of someone else writing and directing this film annoyed me.I've given this movie 2 and a half stars which means it was a decent watch but I would by no means call this movie great. Not only was the movie predictable (yes I know all rocky movies are predictable) but it was long (2 and a half hours) I found myself just wanting the movie to end so I could go home and go to sleep. The movie revolved around Adonis and Biancas relationship way too much. I guess the director wanted to follow the style of Rocky 1 (Adrien and Rockys relationship) but I found myself yawning every time these two love birds graced us with 15 minute scenes filled with cuddling and small talk.Rocky and Adonis on the otherhand had really good chemistry together the movie should have focused more on their relationship or perhaps focus on Adonis's journey a little more.Michael B Jordan was great, I don't have a bad thing to say about him he looked the part and his performance was solid. The producers should have spent a little more money and hired Zoe Kravitz to play Bianca but that's neither here nor there. For a while there I felt like I was watching Stomp The Yard and not a Rocky movie. This movie turned too ghetto for my liking. Rumour has it Chris Brown will be in the next installment and Fetty Wap will be providing the soundtrack :)Adonis's training montage was the worst i've ever seen out of all 7 movies. At one point he was running and yelling while random people were on dirt bikes doing tricks and burnouts which made zero sense whatsoever but okay.And all of this led us right to the predictable ending of Adonis going the distance, which I have no problem with but for me it was bitter-sweet because the build up was done poorly. It was like getting on a rollercoaster that went slow the whole ride but had an awesome ending. By then it's just too late. By all means its not a bad movie I'll gladly watch this movie again on a nice cool day when I have nothing else to do but I just didn't feel the "Rocky" magic in this movie. The first time I saw Rocky 1 I joined boxing classes (and quit a month later) I used to watch the training montages from part 2, 3, and 4 before every workout I did. Even "Rocky Balboa" made me wanna run straight to the gym! "Creed" on the other had made me tired and hungry the only thing I was inspired to do was to sleep. I wouldn't call "Creed" the worst instalment but if I had to choose between watching "Rocky V" and "Creed" it would actually be a tough decision. Good try to the producers and writters hopefully the next instalment will be better. Sly is a hero of mine so it was still great to see him on screen as "Rocky"Definitely worth the watch, a hell of a lot better than "South Paw" don't let me get started on that heap of junk. But I must say I was disappointed. 2 and a half stars from YakBrah

I heard Creed was good. I had no idea it was THIS good. Coming off of the brilliant Fruitvale Station, Ryan Coogler and Michael B. Jordan are back collaborating for the Rocky spinoff, Creed. Knowing how well made of a film Fruitvale Station is, I figured Coogler was the right guy to helm the film but for some reason I was still skeptical about the project in general. The story itself is fascinating but I didn't know if it would be handled with the care needed to produce a quality installment in this legendary franchise. Not only is this a great boxing film, it's one of the best all around films of the year. Everything you love from the original films is here in at least some capacity and the nostalgia is at an all time high. I haven't seen all of the Rocky films but I love the characters and aesthetic of the series enough for Creed to emotionally resonate with me multiple times throughout the film. A lot of people are going to complain that it's too similar to the first Rocky, and while that may be a valid criticism, I think you can make the case that great films always take from the best. Creed has the best aspects from the original films and takes an original spin on it.Most notably being that our lead character, Adonis Johnson (son of Apollo Creed) isn't like Rocky Balboa at all. He has the passion and fire but his background is completely different. He's from Hollywood and due to his father being a heavyweight champion, he's well off as well. I really like this twist on the boxing film. As much as I really liked Southpaw from earlier this year, Creed really hits on all levels. The acting is getting a lot of credit and rightfully so. I don't know that Sylvester Stallone has ever been better. Michael B. Jordan, who may have been snubbed for an Oscar a few years back, is just as good. I think because of how good Stallone is in a supporting role, you don't realize how perfect Jordan is in this role.The directing from Ryan Coogler and cinematography from Maryse Alberti is marvelous. The camera work and shot selection alone is worth seeing on the big screen, and then probably seen again. All the fight scenes are good, but the first big fight Creed has is quite simply one of the most well choreographed scenes of 2015. It is all done in one continuous few minute take. I really couldn't believe how well that was handled.But by far the biggest thing I took away from this film was that it doesn't try to be something it's not. It knows it's a spinoff from Rocky and it plays on that in a perfect way. Yet it also doesn't rely on the nostalgia factor alone, though it does have some great callbacks to the old films. It doesn't take unnecessary risks or try to do too much with its plot. It is just one of the best executed films of the year. The entertainment value is just as much if not more than the superhero films this year, and it also has a well written story, directed to perfection, along with a fantastic sound design/mixing/editing, with incredible performances all around. What's not to love about this movie?+Stallone at his career best+Impressive direction+Contained story+Awesome fight scenes+Sound design+Nostalgia9.6/10
It's good, not perfect, but surprisingly original and fresh. Also, just awesome to see Rocky in his right place, carrying on the tradition of Mick, as a hard core, old school trainer!
