Creed was...wow. From the previews I had high hopes and knew it was going to be good. But I had no idea it was going to be like this. This movie was phenomenal. Creed did so many things right to create such a beautiful film. One of the best things Creed does is not relying on all the old Rocky elements but still bring back some aspects that we all loved. I like how Rocky had his little ball, the chicken scene was funny, and I loved how in Rocky II when all the little kids start following rock to the theme music, but in Creed all the bike guys start following Adonis to a sick rap song. Now that got me hyped. Ryan Coogler comes up with a brilliant idea and directs a masterpiece which can be an amazing franchise. All the characters in the film are so well developed. Each actor gives such a great performance that make the movie that much more amazing. The movie in a nutshell, Adonis Creed, son of the famous Apollo Creed, wants to be a fighter like his father but not under his name and start from his own. He gets in to fights as a kid, in and out of jail, and the hardest thing not growing up with his father. Michael B. Jordan shows us he can do anything. He perfectly played this role and gave one of the best performances of the year. His emotion, anger, and determination throughout the film is memorizing. And Stallone,(supporting actor nomination?) you can tell he wanted to give his all in this film. He brings back all the great elements of Rocky's character that we saw in the better original films. The chemistry between Rocky and Adonis is excellent. A man who needs a role model in his life connecting with a man who just needs someone in his life. The emotion, drama, and boxing scenes are so well balanced and portrayed, There are a lot of scenes between the main characters that are quite touching and are very well made. The boxing scenes and montages. WOW. There is so much to say about the fight scenes that I have to keep it short. The shots were great, and the fighting was so fun to watch. Great ending, Creed was one of the best films I have seen in awhile. Beautifully shot, directed, and acted. Creed is a movie not just to watch for its boxing, but for the incredible story as well.
A surprisingly deep script and excellent chemistry between the characters. Sylvester Stallone is terrific in a grandfatherly role.
It's a not just about boxing, but life. Well directed, written and acted. Highly recommended
Very entertaining, fast paced, face paced & funny. Stallone should be nominated for an Oscar for his performance.
Better than I thought it would be, and reminds me of why I love the rocky series. Just not as good as most of the other movies in the series.

Superb entry in the "Rocky" franchise that stays true to the original while moving the series in an exciting new direction. The cast is excellent, with Michael B. Jordan giving a breakthrough lead performance, instantly charismatic while believable as a boxer (his physique is insane). The highlight, though, is Sly Stallone returning to his iconic role, this time playing a supporting role as a trainer while delivering a nuanced turn as Rocky slowly comes back to life when Creed enters his. Behind the camera, writer/director Ryan Coolger pays fine tribute to the previous films while keeping the movie more down to earth. Nothing feels cheesy and even the classic 'Rocky' theme is only used at the right moment. The boxing is superbly filmed as well, especially the first fight, with appears to be in just one take. The only quibble is the absence of Rocky's son, Robert, which is explained at first but events later in the film leave you questioning where he's at. Despite that, this is not only the best Rocky sequel to date but one of the most entertaining & crowd-pleasing movies of the year.

It also touches on their histories of the last movies, enough so that you know what's happened without even having seen them.To top it off, the music is fantastic, philly is gritty and real and the camera work and editing is fantastic.A must see movie!

Sly did his absolute best to ruin the once amazing Rocky Franchise. After the pinnacle in #3, we were fed some hardcore Reaganism in IV, garbage in 5 and inexplicable stupidity in 6. However, the old man found it in the annals of his brain to come up with Creed. This last iteration is not only great but it's a total flashback to the original. It's actually about boxing and while it has it's share of fluff it really is a fighters movie. Creed is a really good movie and it has all the ingredients for a surprise Oscar run. In fact it would be a travesty if Sly doesn't get the nomination as best supporting actor. Thatsaid, the most important thing about this movie is that they finally give Apollo the respect he deserves. Not only was he the best rival Rockhead ever faced but he was the best fighter ever. When Adonis had flashbacks with the old man fighting, I almost soiled my pants.

Perhaps just a little bit too sentimental to be a classic, this is still an excellent film with three Oscar-worthy performances. Although the fight sequences are typically storybook, the action is realistic and intense. The chemistry between Jordan and Stallone is evident throughout and their bond as uncle and nephew (the way Jordan's character perceives their relationship) is believable. Tessa Thompson provides a more modern take on the hero's romantic interest providing strength, rather than serving as a diversion. The story, though far-fetched, seems believable within the context in which it is told. The ending is riveting; I heard gasps and "come ons" from the audience. Based on the conclusion, it seems clear that the intent is to make another Creed film. As was the case for Rockys II through VI, the bar will be very high for any sequels. Although it's impossible to top the original, this movie is, in my opinion, a clear second.
I definitely teared up a few times watching this. Powerful film. 4.5/5! :D

Predictable and sentimental entry in the Rocky franchise is still a solid film that is grounded in the nostalgia of past glory while determined to pave a path for the future. Stallone steals the movie in a supporting role and Coogler handles the material with a conventional yet deft touch.

Creed gave me goosebumps. Going into the movie I was thinking this would be just another retread/retelling/money grab movie in the Rocky franchise, but I was wrong about that. Creed goes back to the roots of what made the original Rocky so good and even goes it's own path. There are some winks and nods to the originals but this isn't a simple reboot. I think it's well written, it absolutely is well shot, and well acted with a terrific musical score. Sly Stallone isn't the focal point but he is very good and so is Michael Jordan. There's plenty of depth to these characters that simply builds from a pretty slow beginning to a fantastic third act. The middle fight scene goes down as one of the well shot sports scenes in film history with a continuous no cut camera during the entire fight. The beginning is a bit slow, but this is one of my favorite movies of the year.

Too often Hollywood falls into a rut when it involves some of its most famous franchises (Terminator comes to mind first) by keeping its aging star at the forefront of future movies it produces. In a complete about face, Creed levels that trend with an emotional, yet believable rise of a new young boxer played by the true star of the movie, Michael B Jordan.Rocky Balboa was truthfully a movie that didn't make any sense yet still allowed the character to have his day in the spotlight once again. Move over Sylvester Stallone. Passing off the "Rocky" franchise to Apollo Creed's illegitimate son Adonis was a near flawless way to continue making these movies. That being said, I don't necessarily think they need ANOTHER one, but you should definitely expect it this day and age with all the remakes and reboots and sequels we see.Let's start with Sly. He delivered his best performance at this age in this movie. Hands down. While nothing about it screams Oscar-worthy, it's the most relaxed and at home in the 'Rocky' role he's been in since he started making them. This is the tale of coming full circle you want to see from someone as beloved across the movie community as Rocky is. For a guy who lost just about everything near and dear to him, it was incredibly easy to empathize with the character throughout the movie when some major decisions force his hand late in the film.Jordan was fit, fast and loose as Adonis. We get a bit of a rushed look into his upbringing that gives you the basics on why he wants to be a fighter, but even with the fast tutorial on his younger years, that's easy to overlook as a small nuisance by kicking things off fast and heavy after the time jump to his 20s where the bulk of the film takes place. Jordan and director Ryan Coogler did Fruitvale Station together. Their chemistry is easily seen.The love interest, played by Tessa Thompson, came off as organic and believable. There's a subtle contrast between her approach to music and Jordan's approach to boxing. While it's no "Adriaaaaan" kind of relationship, it does the job.My only other knock on the film was the opposing fighters. The first big fight was well done. In fact, probably done better than the final fight. Though it was shorter, it had more pop. That's not to say the second (and main) fight was bad...it lacked that same ferocity in the buildup. And that has everything to do with the guy he was fighting who looked NOTHING like a boxer. There was a great knockout in that final fight that knocks you back in your seat, but aside from that, getting someone who looked the part (and a little more imposing) would have helped.Creed is a standout sports film that does everything you want from an up-and-comer. The film rises with its star character and is anchored by its veteran. If they made another, would I be surprised? No. Am I looking for it in a year or two or three? No. Would I take it? If it was anything like this...absolutely.

Any doubt I had about this movie going in was removed almost immediately. The story really draws you in and makes you feel deeply for Adonis Creed. Rocky plays an important part of this film, but never overstays his welcome nor overshadows his student. This movie is indeed about Creed.
Threw the biggest fist pump as soon as the credits started to roll, and I'm not even ashamed of it
I expected it to be a knockout and it was better than I expected. Michael B Jordan was superb and Sly, did some of his best work ever

Hey Yo, Creed is the Rocky film that everybody has wanted since the first Rocky become a sleeper hit in 1976. The idea to have Apollo Creed's son meet up with Rocky is the only way a 7th film could have ever overcome the odds against any critical opponents in the other corner of the ring. Michael B Jordan's portrayal of Adonis Creed is amazing and highlights the impressive talent of the young actor. On the opposite age spectrum is Sylvester Stallone, Hey Yo, who shows why Rocky is still the champ while also creating an undisputed chemistry with Jordan. Creed's plot, music, acting, and the film as a whole are the best of 2015, you know? Even if the tryptophan of Thanksgiving Turkey is making you sleepy, go out and see Creed. If you get there and still can't open your eyes from being so full, simply say "Cut Me Mick" and watch a Knock Out!

i think i expected to much after seeing fruitvale...heavy symbolism works well in a story like that, but it comes off as catering to people like they don;t get it in a story like this...kind of alienates people who actually do train hard to get where they are, this guy goes from almost no training to beating the #1 pound for pound, and his motivation is just not real..."i'm not a mistake"....he comes from a multi-million dollar home with a multi-million dollar job....just doesn't have a reason to be that angry...wasn't that entertaining

This film will finish in my top 5 favorites of this year. Absolutely masterful movie making and the best Rocky since the original. Remember the names Michael B. Jordan, Ryan Coogler, and Tessa Thompson. Those people are gonna be huge within the next few years. And Stallone has never been better playing his defining character than he is here. A true contender for Best Supporting Actor.In fact, I'm seriously expecting Screenplay and Directing nominations for Coogler, Best Actor nod for Michael B. Jordan, Best Supporting Actor for Stallone, and Best Picture. YO CREED.Studios: Warner Bros. Pictures/Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer/New Line Cinema
A great movie for fans of the Rocky films and new fans alike.

Excellent! Beautiful cast of actors, stunning music and filmography. Creed is emotionally touching. Plot and ending isn't necessarily surprising, but the character development and poignant storytelling make up for it.

Knowing that the last 3 or 4 Rocky movies were - as the French say - garbaaaage, I sure as hell did not expect to like a "spin-off" of Rocky. [SEE MORE ON URBANRHETORICBLOG] I won't tell you how this movie ends, but I can say that I cheered right along with the idiots who forget that a movie is only a movie. Adonis Johnson is just a made up character, fighting a choreographed fight that was shot on a movie set with countless takes-retakes. Still, I literally moved as if I had to bob & weave right along with Adonis as he fought through each round. That's a sign of investment. Kudos to Michael B Jordan and Ryan Coogler for making Adonis a likable albeit flawed millennial - much easier said than done! The emotional rollercoaster ride and all the talk of battling memories and the feelings of loss that a adult child has to deal with when losing a parent(s) got me thinking about struggle and responsibility and all that business. As a dude who grew up with a father who was widely respected from the streets to the pulpit, and whose name was bigger than most, I found myself getting a little verklempt; then, I shook it off and remembered it was a damned movie spin-off of Rocky, son. Rocky. SMDH [FULL REVIEW ON URBANRHETORICBLOG]

After a few years in development and a lengthy stretch in a rumor mill, the spinoff to the Rocky franchise Creed is here and it is hands down one of the finest sports films in recent memory and is a standout entry into one of film's most notorious franchises. There is so much to say about this movie I will try to get through this so let's start with the story. The story here revolves around the illegitimate son of Apollo Creed, Adonis, and his struggles to find himself as a boxer as well himself growing up in the shadow of his father. In order to do this he seeks the help of his father's friend Rocky Balboa and thus we have the makings of a spectacular film. This film sounds simple but the excellence lies in the execution of this film. Director Ryan Coogler has crafted a truly thrilling film here with outstanding boxing sequences as well as truly touching and moving dramatic scenes that make this film stand out above the rest. Coogler made this movie look pristine but it is also worth mentioning that the sound and music department did their job and compliment this movie extremely well. The script here is also fantastic with dialogue that is both simple but complex in it's delivery that even harkens back to the glory days of the Rocky films. At times, has the feel of the first Rocky film with a gritty undertone mixed with lighthearted humor and heart. Speaking of which, this movie isn't a cheap excuse to see Rocky again. This film focuses on Adonis and his growth and uses Rocky as a plot device rather than a gimmick and even pays homage to the work of Carl Weathers from the early Rocky films. The character of Adonis is rich here with depth and isn't a simple write off protagonist and this is thankful to the script but also to the performance by Michael B. Jordan as Adonis. Jordan had a rough year this year with him starring in Fantastic Four, but he does more than rebound here. He delivers a performance of a lifetime here that never borders on sentimentality but instead makes us cheer for him and deeply care for him. Simply put, Jordan establishes himself as a contender in this movie. Sylvester Stallone returns here as Rocky Balboa and he does a great job here. Stallone looks like he is where he belongs and it was great to see the character again. The rest of the cast is great with Tessa Thompson and Phylicia Rashad delivering fantastic performances. Normally this is the part of the review where I list my problems with the film but I have to be honest, I literally had no complaints with this film. The pacing is perfect, the boxing scenes hit hard and are thrilling, the drama is perfect, and we get an introduction to a fantastic new character in Adonis Creed. Overall I absolutely loved this film and I urge you to see this film as soon as possible. This isn't a cheap spinoff or a film that panders to fans, this movie is simply an outstanding piece of cinema that is well worth your time.
One of the best movies of the year. Great performances, directing, score, everything.
Two fine performances from Creed's talented leads make the film more than a mere boxing drama but not a complete victory.

Not only does Creed succeed as one of the best in the Rocky franchise, but it also pushes the extra mile in terms of how boxing can be translated to film. Michael B. Jordon is phenomenal and is complimented by the return of Stallone to his iconic portrayal of Rocky Balboa.
Creed is a fun and interesting take on what is a Rocky reboot. It has heart, passion, desire, and the flare of any good boxing film; that's why it works so well.

Sure, you've likely seen a variant of this story before, but this is so well done you probably won't care. It is so nice to see Michal B Jordan show some acting chops after that other film this year that I won't mention, and also nice to see Stallone slide smoothly into the supporting role. This film also has some of the best use of camera angles I've seen, because as much as steady cam shots will often bother me, here they were used to excellent effect. It also features several montages, which often irk me, but his is how to do it RIGHT: stay on a scene long enough for you to get the idea, jump to the next for the same length, etc, showing progress each time, as opposed to simply showing an unrelated series of events that don't actually tie together to show progress. Simply put: if you want to do a passing-of-the-torch type film, this is how you do it. I'm even honestly not a huge fan of the original "Rocky" films, but this was great.
Many have said this movie is the best of the films since the original Rocky and hell even as good as it........and I couldn't agree more

Creed is a masterclass both in Michael B. Jordan's performance and Ryan Coogler's insanely good directing. After all these decades, I never thought a film from the Rocky franchise could be so good until this day, Creed lifts up the franchise to a new height, and is a possible new franchise that is promising, and leaves me waiting for the sequel. At last a film leaves me anxiously waiting for the sequel, since its script is so promising, and has a lot more to expand. Overall, Creed is a fantastic film in a year where sequels and reboots have dominated. Creed is not only one of the best films of the year, but it has some of the best performances this year has offered, and a promising new direction which I hope Coogler can take the director's chair again in the sequel.

Strong performances, particularly one from a surprisingly subtle Stallone, elevate this above its unavoidable sports movie tropes. A bold, authoritative sense of visual composition, and a restrained-but-moving score, also elevate the proceedings. Rocky fandom may enhance your appreciation, but it's not a prerequisite. I'll put this above 'Rocky Balboa' & below 'Rocky,' making this my 2ns favorite entry in the series.

A pretty formulaic boxing movie with a punchy soundtrack that spins off from the Rocky series. Most of it is predictable - but not entirely. One particular moment in the story was unexpected - but I can't tell you which one without spoiling the plot. The problem with boxing movies is that they seem to rely quite heavily on the boxers training - and there's only so much of the training you can watch without getting bored. While CREED might be an adequate movie, it doesn't reach the creativity of the recent Southpaw starring Jake Gyllenhaal. Sylvester Stallone is pretty good and exceeded my expectations. If you really like watching realistic boxing, then maybe give it a go. As a continuation of the Rocky franchise, it's ok.

This movie was everything I hoped it would be. Great performances from Michael B. Jordan and Sylvester Stallone. Most importantly though, the film was well written and the characters all had good POV and motivation. Clear writing is lacking in bigger films these days, so it is nice to see it come through for this type of movie. Ryan Coogler did it again and his star should continue to rise.

Hard hitting and entertaining, Creed may follow the typical Rocky formula, but when the "Big Fight" at the end comes, you still root for the underdog. But the real star of the film is the city of Philadelphia, shown in all of its gritty glory.

Not a Rocky clone, and not as inspiring. The Rocky movies always had good music --this movie did not have any music that identified with it. No music, no soul. No soul, no passion or inspiration. It was a safe cinematic journey of mediocrity that would best be served on blu-ray. Save your ticket money, buy the blu-ray.
My son and I loved this movie.. If you ever loved Rocky, see Creed. Hats off to Sylvester Stallone. Everyone in the theatre was clapping at the end.
As a Rocky fan from the beginning I was prepared to be disappointed in this film but I could not be happier after seeing it... can't wait to see it again!
While not a "Rocky" movie in the truest of sense, it is a fantastic movie that grows our beloved character Rocky Balboa and add a new direction for the franchise. I would highly recommend!

Most of the reason I went to this movie is because it has received a whole lot of hype. As far as what I thought of this movie, I can tell you that the story was kind of interesting, but there were some scenes here and there that I felt were not necessary. For example, they tried to through a little romance in the movie for Michael B. Jordan's character, and I felt that the movie could have been just as good or better without that. As far as the fighting scenes go, they were very good, and I went sort of on the edge of my seat at the end. As far as comparing this movie with Southpaw, I can say that they are close to the same on my list, but I still think that Southpaw was a little bit better. Anyway, I would recommend this to any movie person.

This stays with the boxers story without getting dragged down into drama.. But keeps it so interesting, you are literally on your seat's edge.. Great use of past and present. And being a Philly girl by history, I loved the views of my city.. Great job..

"You see this guy here? That's the toughest opponent you're ever going to have to face. I believe that's true in the ring, and I think that's true in life. Now show me something.""Creed", stars Michael B. Jordan and Sylvester Stallone, and is the unofficial sequel to the well-known franchise called "Rocky". Now at the moment, Creed is off the charts for it's ratings, and although I feel that this movie does not live up to all of its hype, I still feel that this was an excellent film, with an exhilarating final act. So I have yet to watch a single Rocky movie, which is probably something I should've done before watching this film. But, this film does a pretty good job of being its own stand alone movie, while also catering to any fans of the Rocky franchise. First off, I want to start out by saying that this movie isn't perfect. The first act of this movie was not so great, the pacing was choppy, and the editing could've been better. They skip through so much time in the first act, and many of the scenes just cut off really quickly. Nothing in the first act made an impact on me, and I actually wasn't really enjoying the movie. I didn't even like the camera work in the first act, as in one of Johnson's first fights, the camera work felt awkward and bland, and it really didn't capture the intensity or the realism of any situation. So at first, I was actually dissapointed with this movie, but that didn't last for too long. By the time Johnson (Creed) moved to a different city to start to build his legacy, that's when things started to pick up. We started to get introduced to Rocky and Bianca, and when the movie started to dive into a deep character study, that's when the movie started to grow on me. The second act of the movie really focuses on the characters, and the actors manage to build great chemistry on screen. I really like how this movie focused on the characters, rather than the boxing aspect of the movie. I heard that the first Rocky film did the same thing, so it was nice that we got to know our characters more and build an attachment to them .When the third act rolled around, I was honestly excited and invested into this movie. This is when the character development payed off and was one of the better third acts I've seen from a boxing movie. It was exciting and exhilarating all at the same time, the pacing felt perfect, the editing was cleaned up, and my emotional attachment to the characters made the ending really perfect. I mean, the third act was as good as it was ever going to be, and there was more than one memorable scenes in there.Michael. B Jordan is really proving himself as one of the upcoming stars of Hollywood today, and he gave it all in this performance here. He's quickly becoming one of my favorite actors, and hopefully, this will save his name from the mess that was Fantastic Four. Sylvester Stallone also shows that he still has the acting chops, and he might have been one of the best parts of the entire movie. It was great seeing him back on the big screen in a quality movie, and both he and Jordan were standouts in this movie. Tessa Thompson was also really excellent, and I loved seeing all three of these characters interact together. I loved the chemistry between all of them and the relationships that they built together truly made it feel like they were a family. Keep in mind that when you watch this movie, it isn't a movie solely about boxing. It's a film that focuses on the characters, and who they really are. It shows us that although the family's legacy and past may define your reputation at first, you are here to carve your own destiny and create your own legacy. In this movie, Creed has always had a tough life, and although he lived in a huge mansion, and had a great job, none of that mattered if he couldn't prove his worth to the world, and to himself. In his mind, he wanted to create his own legacy, rather than let someone else create it for him. He shows us a great example of working hard and pushing to become your own individual, and this movie really focuses on those aspects in the story. The boxing parts are just there to show us an end result, and to entertain us with some action, but it really is a movie that focuses on a bigger picture in life.In the end, this movie isn't perfect. The first act has poor pacing, an awkward flow, some uneven camera work, and a slow start. But when the movie picks up in the second act, we are blessed with some amazing performances, excellent character development, emotional and intense moments, and a memorable third act. This movie really did a great job of building upon the relationships between the characters, and in the end, you'd be missing out if you didn't see this movie. If you never saw Rocky, this film does a decent job of standing on its own, and there were plenty of memorable moments here.

If you are a fan of the Rocky movies you absolutely have to see this movie. I am looking forward to CREED II. Hopefully it' won't be about a second child that Apollo conceived out of wedlock. If someone takes this idea and does a comedic short film, just remember that you heard it here first. @chokolatedaddy

Creed manages to breath new life into what could've been an exhausting 7th round in Stallone's decades-old ring by forming a beautiful hybrid between new-age Hollywood polished filmmaking and the raw passion of what made the original a classic. While many of the beats and training-sequences are almost too familiar, its hard to fault the inventor of the Hollywood montage for throwing a few of the same jabs.
I always wished to go back in time to watch Rocky for the first time on opening day, but now I don't have to.

A new entry in the Rocky series brings nothing new to the genre, yet plays its cards so well, it becomes a film that's very much worth watching. Great acting, intense fights, and a heavy dose of drama (I cried) make this film one of the best of the year. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED
Much better than I was ever expecting. Like that is was brought back to that rough Philly roots. Awesome to see this accessible to another generation.

Let me start this little review by saying that I am a HUGE fan of the Rocky film series. The original 1976 Rocky is not only my favorite sports film ever made, but it is also one of my favorite movies of all time. That being said, I DID NOT WANT this movie to happen at all. In 2006, Sylvester Stallone released his 6th and seemingly final film in the series and it was a perfect ending to the franchise. So when they announced a spin-off film about the son of Apollo Creed and Rocky taking over as the trainer, let's just say I was not jumping for joy. This film was...FANTASTIC! Seriously, this movie was far better than it should have been. Don't go into this expecting to see Rocky 7...this is definitely Creed! Not only does this movie do a wonderful job of fitting right into the Rocky universe, but it also stands on its own as a standalone film. If you have never seen a single one of the 6 Rocky movies, you will have no problem seeing this. The focus is primarily on Michael B. Jordan playing the illegitimate son of Apollo Creed (Rocky's friend and opponent in the series). He is trying to become a fighter like his father while also trying to make a name for himself to avoid the pressure of the family legacy that has built up before him. When you throw aside all the Rocky attributes, it is really just the story of a young man trying to find his place and be somebody. He doesn't know his father, but he wants to honor him at the same time. Don't get me wrong though, Sly Stallone (showing that he can beautifully play this character in his sleep) delivers the best performance of his in almost a decade. He is most definitely a strong supporting component and if you are a fan, you will love how Rocky is handled as you have the feeling of catching up with an old friend. About 40% of the film is devoted to him. Paulie and his wife are long gone and he has lost contact with his son. Everything he loved in life has moved on and he is trying to find some sort of purpose to fill the void of being a has-been. First of all, the performances and the chemistry between the two stars is flawless. The film does a wonderful job of keeping you in the Rocky-mood while also delivering new characters that you will fall in love with. This is the perfect example of how to make a spin-off film and hand off the baton to the next arising story. You will laugh, cry, and cheer during this story. And yes, there are some great callbacks to the previous Rocky movies but not so many that it feels forced or cheesy. As a huge Rocky fan, I loved this movie! Go and see this as soon as you can. It is debate-ably the best film in the series since the original. 4.5/5
So looking forward to seeing this movie.

I never watch real boxing but a good movie on the sport is hard to resist. And this might be one of the best boxing movies ever made. It's by no means another Rocky movie. It has its own style and energy level, along with the best in-ring direction and camera work I've ever seen. Creed is easily one of the best movies of 2015. Though I wonder if any movie has ever had more names for its lead character before.
Loved it!!!! Very well done. Fell in love with Rocky all over again!
I like this movie. Good story but slow at time. Fight scenes were good.

One of the best movie of the year. It seem recapture all great aspect of the original Rocky film and give it a modern update. A great performance by Michael B Jordan but Sly Stallone steals the show. Despite it lengthy running time, I was hooked from the opening scene with that spectacular boxing scene which was done with one take! I was so glad that I got to see this movie with my brother who is a big fan of boxing. In his own words, Creed is a great movie.
A very good movie! In the top three of all seven of Rocky's movies.
Excellent all around.
Urging everyone to go see this! It's just so raw, emotional and realistic.

Amazing film. Charming and the second act has you on your seat. You want the characters to succeed, and it comes from a place of genuine concern. There are some great references to the earlier films, but are done in a way that don't make you roll your eyes. I genuinely hope there will be a sequel, this is one of the best fighting movies I've ever seen.

Too predictable. The movie bases itself off old nostalgia from the old Rocky movies and cannot stand on its own. The story is the same story from the old Rocky movies. Constant repetition "You are Apollo Creed's son" over and over and over again, we get it. You are Apollo Creed's son, how many times can you hear the same thing over again? I fell asleep. Too boring and predictable.

Was it a good movie. Yes, I'm glad I saw it. Sylvester Stalone delivers a heart wrenching and tender performance. Is this movie any where near as good as the original? no, sorry. There are several scenes in this movie where you can see they are either trying to pay homage to the original or possibly recreate some of the magic, but in my opinion these moments fell flat The fights in this movie were OK but felt predictable to me. I think this movie could have been done much better. One other point, if you are going to have an apponent that is supposed to champion of the world, then for crying out loud, find an actor who looks like he spend more time at the gym then he does at the bar. The looked flabby. Better casting choice would have made this all more believable. The story line of the singing girlfriend going deaf was also just a distraction in this movie. The performance by Stalone alone in this movie is worth the price of admission. The performance by M Jordan was good. They should have definitely used Raschad more in this movie. She acted almost like a disinterested bystander she could have been used to much greater effect. It would have also been good to see Jordans character fight at least one more time on his way to the title fight. It would have made the whole thing a lot more believable. Probably a rematch with with Andre Wards Character as the fluke win that suddenly puts him in the ring with the world champion. That would have been better than "he gets the fight because of his name" story line. My last name could be Bush, but that does not make me our next president. The whole story line made no sense.

Woah. This movie is awesome. The 'Rocky' franchise is my favourite of all time, so when I first heard about this, I was wary. When the trailer dropped, I started to get excited, and thankfully, the film itself lived up to that excitement. It does a perfect job of balancing the legacy of all that's come before it and still telling it's own story. Stallone and Jordan kill their respective roles. The soundtrack is on point. Go see this while it's playing in a cinema.
Best of the Rocky franchise.
can you take meee hiighher...

Creed is a fantastic film. It fights for and wins it's place among the strongest of this boxing film series. Michael B. Jordan and Sylvester Stallone share a relationship and on-screen chemistry that is unlike anything that I can recall from the Rocky franchise or even most sports films in general. Every scene that could have been used as pandering to fans of the "O.G." franchise was instead used to build this films title character into one that can stand on his own. By giving us a familiar story with modern elements and well developed characters, Ryan Coogler's vision for this film does honor to the series. Combine that with great fight choreography, camera-work, and knock-out performances by the lead cast. Creed gives us a memorable film to help close-out the year of 2015.
Great movie. Well written, well presented.
Oh yes - another Rocky film!!!

Creed is an exceptional film in its own right as well as one of the best in the Rocky universe since the original classic. The film centers not on the iconic character which made Sylvester Stallone a house hold name, however, and instead focuses on the offspring of the man who he defeated to become the champ. The second we get a glimpse of this young man, Adonis Creed, son of the heavyweight champion Apollo Creed, we know that he has a drive for something. The narrative that Creed weaves tells us that for the whole of Adonis's life, he has been drawn to the world which his father found fame, fortune and tragically destruction, which means escaping from the shadow of his father's name. A character with such a complex goal and a premise infused with so much thought and commitment make Creed extremely entertaining and uplifting. Michael B. Jordan is phenomenal as Adonis Creed, a being full of rage, resentment and life. Jordan expertly portrays the harsh and personal struggles the young Creed faces in accepting his heritage and that he can be his own man without having to embrace something he isn't. Returning in one of his best performances to date is Sylvester Stallone in the iconic role which almost anyone could recognize him from, accept not in Creed. Stallone is transformed from a young and vibrant life force with endearing quirks and some trouble being heard into a broken and desolate man who we never believed the character could become. Rocky is reluctant to take on the role of his old trainer, Mick, not believing he is truly capable, which provides another layer to what remains of Rocky Balboa. Everyone he cared for has left him or passed on, leaving him an old sick man without a purpose. He is content to allow himself to leave the earth and not have to be a prisoner of his own isolation. Luckily, Adonis won't let him. The contrast between the world-weary Rocky and the newcomer Adonis is perfect. The cinematography is very impressive, especially in the fight sequences, and the ending leaves you with a feeling that anything is possible and that the human spirit drives us forward to greatness.

This movie brought me back to the time I first watch Rocky when I was a little lad. Really good film and great start to the Creed franchise. Got me a little emotional but had me and my wife on the edge of our seats during the fight. Awesome camera work for a boxing film, made you feel like you was right in there. I suggest you watch it. Everyone in the Alamo Drafthouse gave it a round of applause when the film ended.

a powerhouse beautifully orchestrated and inspirational movie. with oscar worthy acting and motivational story Creed, in my eyes steps above every Rocky movie and every boxing movie ever made. Yet another classic added to the 2015 shelf there really hasnt been a year this good that I ever remember.
Great great movie! If you're a Rocky fan and even if you are not 5 stars
A reboot that stands tall above most reboots, Creed is an emotional ride from start to finish and contains Sylvester Stallone's best performance ever.

Creed does a good job of keeping the elements of the Rocky movies that make it recognizable to audiences and putting the franchise in an interesting new direction, while also keeping true to it's motif of building one's own legacy.

Creed is a knockout even if no punch landed. For it is a movie that deals with the human psyche that is surrounded by the sport of boxing. It takes you deeper in the mind and surroundings of the sport then any of the Rocky movies have done in the past. To be honest the movie didn't grab me until the 1st round but once it started moving I didn't want to leave till the ending credits. Yet even if one is not a fan of boxing the need to fight our own battles is a message that should ring in all our hearts. Creed **** (I added a 1/2 star because I'm a big Sylvester Stallone fan.

What a knockout! Creed has the "Eye of the Tiger" in successfully passing the torch down to the next generation. You don't have to be a huge Rocky fan like myself to appreciate the masterful execution of writing, cinematography and acting. Stallone puts on his best performance in decades alongside Michael B Jordan's phenomenal performance. Very surprising to see this in a franchise that one would have expected to run its course. New director Ryan Coogler brings the series back to full form. It's also the best "Rocky" movie since the original yet stands on its own paying homage to it's roots without relying on nostalgia. The formula pioneered by the original is still relevant almost 40 years later to a generation with new struggles. This is up there with Mad Max as my favourite film of the year, let's see if Star Wars can join these ranks next month. I can't believe the best films of this year are connected to franchises from the late 70's

Good movie. Better than I thought it would be.
OMG, this is an excellent movie all-round: outstanding acting, great script and dialogue! I thoroughly enjoyed it. Amazing how it stayed true to its roots without being cheesy.
Future boxing movies take notes.

Absolutely fantastic! I was already sold after hearing that "Fruitvale Station" director, Ryan Coogler, will be helming this Rocky spin-off. In all honesty, I had no doubt in my mind that this film would be nothing short of extraordinary and boy was I right on the nose. Not only is this a very well directed, well written film (major props to both Coogler and co-writer Aaron Covington), but it is also powerfully acted. Michael B. Jordan has been an actor that I truly believe has an immense amount of potential as being one of the most bankable rising young stars that can captivate an audience with his acting since watching his work in films like "Chronicle" and the aforementioned "Fruitvale Station." He has a lot of promise and after seeing his performance in Creed, my respect for him as an acting talent has only increased. Along with his supporting co-star Tessa Thompson, who does a superb job as Bianca, Jordan's love interest. She makes a wonderful addition to the pantheon of beloved "Rocky" characters. Now I cannot talk about the acting of this film without discussing the brutally emotional performance by Sylvester Stallone who has been given some serious Oscar consideration for his role in this movie (a sentiment that I also agree with). It's truly incredible to see Stallone strip down all the macho bravado commonly found in his action roles and view a completely different, yet genuine side that audiences have not witnessed in a long time from him. I have grown up watching the Rocky movies (minus Rocky V) so I do consider myself to be a big fan and Stallone gives a career-best in his seventh outing as the iconic Rocky Balboa.Creed holds a lot of similarities to the first Rocky, but it's more of a homage than a blatant rip-off as there is a lot of sentimentality and love for the franchise behind the film as this is a deeply personal story for director Coogler. And with that level of inspiration, Mr. Coogler produces one of the best films of the year. Some of my most memorable moments from Creed includes the boxing match shot in one-take (mesmerizing isn't enough to describe how epic and awesome an experience it was). Another were the training montages that were able to fuse both the old and the new by which I mean certain clips from Adonis's training to the musical score remarkably done by Ludwig Goransson, taking over the reins of former composer Bill Conti.This is a marvelous example of how blending the traditional Rocky tropes with the more modernized grittiness of today's urban world can be done right if in good hands. If I had to rate this film, I would adamantly reward this film with a perfect 5/5 stars! Well worth watching even if you've never been introduced to the Rocky series before, although it would only benefit you if you did.

I saw the movie Creed today, and it was terrific film.The performance by Michael B. Jordon as Apollo Creed's son was superb as well as Sylvester Stallone as Rocky.I also loved how the fight scenes were filmed and how it pay homage to the first Rocky film.This is one of the best films I saw this year and definitely recommend everyone to go out and see.I give it a grade of an A-.ENJOY!

I loved this movie; it's a great way to carry on the franchise. Stallone's performance was excellent; he didn't overshadow the lead actor but displayed a range of emotion to draw you in with the screen time he had. Michael B. Jordan's performance was also excellent; despite that atrocious FF4 movie, he is on the rise as a young talented black actor in Hollywood. Last but not least, Ryan Coogler directs another 90%+ film (Fruitvale Station). I commend him on 2 quality films as a young black director in Hollywood. I hope his success continues!!!

Well now this is how you do a movie. It is hard to believe this is a sequel as it stands alone so well. I'm liking the new trend in Hollywood to do sequels a decade or two after the original in real-time (such as Jurassic World and possibly the recently announced Gremlins 3). Michael B. Jordan carries this movie and at times Rocky himself (literally). This rising star (see Friday Night Lights, Fruitvale Station, don't see Fantastic Four) is given a real world nod with a quote in the movie ("You're the future of this field"). The entire cast impresses as does the direction, especially with a long one-take shot that will make you realize you haven't blinked in minutes. And let's not forget about Sly, who excels in his supporting role and reminds us what the Rocky franchise tries to teach us, that you don't have to win to be a champion.
This movie does the Rocky franchise right..
great movie, is it wrong that i cried
Good movie...Stallone aka Rocky brought his "A" game to this role. Oscar worthy...and because he is not a Hollywood douche.

I am a huge fan of the Rocky series. When it comes to Creed its an alright film. Not as amazing as critics are praising it. Which I am actually quite shocked about. When I first heard about this film, I thought the idea of it was a joke and thought it was going to be panned critically.I'm not too sure if Creed started off as an ordinary boxing film and then the idea of Rocky was added to sell it more. It tries hard to be it's own thing, while trying to please the Rocky fans by going down a checklist such as Stallone himself, music cues, locations etc. Just like the character Adonis Creed being in the shadow of Apollo Creed, this movie is in the shadow of Rocky.Michael B. Jordan gives a good performance, but nothing special. For me the entire film relied on the performance of Stallone, who is still able to give all the heart and soul of the Rocky Balboa character.Overall Creed to me feels like a better made Rocky V. It's entertaining, but not much more to justify its existence. The film Rocky Balboa, for me was the better way to end the series.

Michael B. Jordan and Stallone deliver a pitch perfect update to this long running series. The melding of the Creed and Balboa storylines along with adding a couple of classic touches that will bring long time fans to tears, literally has fans applauding in the aisles and eagerly anticipating the next round of this engrossing reboot.

I went into this film with high expectations, as I had read the great reviews and, to be honest, I think it's a little overhyped. Having said that, it is still a very good film. And the reason it is so good and why I have given it 4 stars (besides the very strong direction and cinematography)? Two words: Sylvester Stallone. This is not only the best performance he has ever given, it is one of the best supporting performances of the year. It is a beautiful thing to watch and I had tears rolling down my cheeks on more than one occasion. Honestly, the film dips whenever he isn't on screen (Rocky is a much more interesting character than Adonis, in my opinion) and I was much more emotionally connected to his story arc than Adonis or Bianca. Yo, Oscar voters! You have your winner right here!

Despite universally great reviews, this movie was only so-so.Stallone was fine but Michael Jordan, though handsome, was not believable in his role. The film is overly long and could have been helped by editing out some subplots which did nothing to advance the story.Watchable... but disappointing given all that I had read before seeing it. This installment of the Rocky series pales when judged in relation to the original, emotionally captivating chapter. Even the soundtrack seemed less than uplifting.

A perfect movie that takes the best parts of the franchise and builds it's own place in history. Stallone delivers a remarkable performance true to the Rocky character. It's amazing how he can step back into character nearly 40 years after he created it and he so accurately portrays a Rocky exactly how we thought he'd be - understated, simple and honest. All performances were top notch, and this movie will go down as one of the best and an instant classic.

This movie first came to my attention as a trailer to the somewhat (IMHO) inferior Southpaw. Co-writer / Director Cooger knows this formula. The nature of the sports movie is self-aware and it rides the inner conflict of the protagonist. So this one kicks in the real drama a little late. Michael B Jordan does well. Phyliicia Rashad is consummate veteran. While it is a bit focus stealing from Jordan's starring role, the performance to talk about is that of Sylvester Stallone. He is not just one of the most Razzie winning actors ever and director/star of the Expendables. He can act the heck of the Rocky persona. Lest we forget he was nominated an Oscar for it. And unless the Academy is cranky, he might be due another, this time as best supporting actor.
It's a nice, sweet boxing movie despite it is about a sport about how to give your opponent a concussion

While holding a legendary franchise on its shoulders, this film succeeds in bringing a new, singular and engaging story to life. Great performances and direction galore in this stellar addition to the Rocky universe.

Amazing performance, score, and choreography. Michael b. Jordan did Carl Weathers justice, and Sly reminds the world of his capabilities to enhance a scene with talent. Tessa was a beauty and was a strong female lead. I loved this movie and it is a 5 star to me!

Writer-director Ryan Coogler gives new vitality to the "Rocky" series by updating the old sports drama formula with a fresh spin. Former prize fighter Rocky Balboa (Sylvester Stallone) is now an old, broken down, restaurant owner, out of the boxing limelight, who takes under his wing, training the illegitimate son (Michael B. Jordan) of his former rival, Apollo Creed. Coogler respects the formula but he doesn't cheapen it as the sequels did. By telling this story from the black experience, fraught with paternal identity crises, Coogler elevates the myth for a younger, more multicultural generation and announces his presence as a major commercial movie director. Jordan is a rising star with the charisma and forcefulness of a young Denzel Washington. Tessa Thompson is affecting as a hearing-impaired musician and Cree's love interest. Stallone gives possibly his finest performance in his most iconic role. He underplays beautifully and expresses shades of regret, mortal recognition, and sorrow, but also the triumphant spirit that made his character so popular. Written by Coogler and Aaron Covington based on characters by Stallone. With Phylicia Rashad, Tony Bellew, and Wood Harris.

Now that's how a title fight should be. Watching a boxing movie & people in the movie theaters were actually cheering for the underdog as though it's an actual real title match. Hot tempered upcoming pugilist that wants to make a name for himself & prove to himself that he's his father's son.
If this is considered the 7th installment of Stallone's Rocky franchise, it might just be the best one yet.

Honestly when this film was announced I didn't care much, sure I like the Rocky series (even though I have seen only Rocky & Rocky Balboa), Michael B Jordan is one of the most promising young stars in the field right now, & Ryan Coogler directed Fruitvale Station two years ago (one of my favorite films of that year). But something about another installment of the series didn't excite me, maybe because I am not a fan of Boxing & had my fill of boxing this year with the excellent Southpaw. Frankly, this film is actually more of a 'Rebirth' for the Rocky franchise a passing of the baton in a way. Cut from the same cloth maybe, this film is much more than just the seventh installment in the Rocky film franchise. As a no-holds-barred sports drama, this is every bit an exceptional crowd pleaser with a lot of heart, plenty of amusing jabs to the ribs, and an unexpected but emotional haymaker to the gut. And a lot more. Trust me, missing out on the previous Rocky films will not harm your experience with this film. This is definitely not a 'Rocky movie', it definitely stands on its own and the main focus of the film is Adonis Creed. Of course, being in the same universe and featuring the series' main protagonist does lead to many callbacks to the other Rocky films. But these callbacks (apart from the obvious) are not crucial to the plot and really are just there for die hard fans of the series. Yes! Director and writer Ryan Coogler's spinoff is awesome. Director Coogler brilliantly reinvents the "Rocky" saga for the hip-hop and cyber versed generation. Coogler with his film is beholding to heart, love, and the journey of rediscovering our innate greatness-what made the original "Rocky" so special. Visually the film is staggering, light, texture and motion all draw you in. Ironically the fight music from the Rocky franchise is called, "Alone in the Ring" at least twice I was drawn into this film deeply that I would have swore I was in Adonis's corner if not in the ring myself. The story follows Adonis Johnson (Michael B. Jordan), an illegitimate son of Apollo Creed (played in the first four Rocky movies by Carl Weathers), born shortly after the latter's death in Rocky IV. Appolo's widow Mary Ann (Phylicia Rashad) rescues young Adonis from what is certain to be a life on the streets and raises him as her own in the plush Creed estate in Los Angeles. Cut to present day and Adonis is a corporate executive half way up the ladder. Like Rocky, Adonis (calling himself Donnie) knows he is destined for something else, so heads to Philadelphia to meet his late father's rival turned best friend. His search lands him in his father's old Philly stomping ground, where he pesters one Rocky Balboa (Sylvester Stallone) into training him. He pulls every angle to get Rocky to help him since his pop and Rocky were combatants and close friends before he died. Once Rocky begrudgingly gives in, things begin to coalesce. Adonis finds balance as he falls in love with beautiful musician and singer Bianca (Tessa Thompson), who is also dealing with her own adversity. Jordan displays a gentle and playful side with Thompson. In a funny twist, Bianca outs Adonis for not telling her that his Uncle is Rocky Balboa. As stories collide reigning Light Heavyweight Champion Ricky Conlan (real-life former champion Tony Bellew) has one more fight before serving a prison sentence. His anger costs him a fight with the top contender. Suddenly, he needs to find a legitimate sacrificial opponent. So would that be the son of Apollo Creed? Rocky gets a call and this is all too familiar. Also Adonis and Rocky poignantly deal with mortality. It is life. Time is undefeated. Co-written by director Ryan Coogler, there's no doubt that this film is a passionate love letter to the first film, which in itself is a poetic love story about fighting the good fight. Although boxing is the central theme, and often frowned upon as a brutal blood-sport that causes serious injuries, it's never been about the fight but more about what you are fighting for. This film is an excellent example of mixing newcomers with established names on both sides of the camera and having the end result come out perfect. The crew and cast turn in great work. Coogler had the fortune and skill to work with people who know what it takes to put together a film that would appeal to critics and audiences alike. There were a couple scenes that are "wow" moments, not just fight scenes, which are are amazing, but little scenes that are set up, shot (by Maryse Alberti) and acted that will have a lasting effect on the viewer. Maybe classic isn't a stretch. The meeting with Rocky is one of several great moments in the film while also serving as a nostalgic homecoming occasion for every fan of the franchise. It's a fascinating intersection of the past but none better than the fact that in many ways, this film is an inverted mirror image of Rocky. And before sending this film off on its own pulsating trajectory, Coogler reveals a full hand of spades. One of which is the legacy Rocky bestows on Donnie, and in essence, Stallone handing over the franchise baton to Jordan. We may not realize this at first and that's because we are already smitten by the father-son relationship developing between Donnie and Rocky. Their character study is the most significant aspect of this film. Donnie has always been an orphan and the reason why he never took on his father's name is an emotional revelation. Who he is and why he wants to become a professional boxer is his darkest secret. Having Rocky Balboa in the film and being a mentor and coach for Adonis was a really great aspect of the film that worked in every way. This could have easily been a very forced element where they just threw Rocky in a few scenes occasionally to make sure people know "Hey come see this film because of Rocky". But he really was an integral part of the film and contributed to the plot, bought a slight tad of humor to lighten the mood occasionally and also really emphasis the emotional weight of some of the films key moments. Sylvester Stallone was great in the role, i can't speak for whether it compares to the other Rocky films but you could see that he was a very experienced boxer who has definitely been through a lot in his life. If anything, this film made me want to go and see the other Rocky films because even seeing him at this stage in his life was fascinating and i wanted to know more about the character. But despite the big name and the fact that he is so loved by film fans, he did play second fiddle to Michael B Jordan, and i don't think anyone should be mad about that. There was also one incredible moment in the film that was made even more amazing by the camera-work in this scene. There was a fight that was filmed so amazingly I was mesmerized and totally sucked into the scene. The entire fight was filmed with one continuous tracking shot that takes you all around the ring and made you feel like you were literally in the ring with these fighter, truly incredible film work right there. Apart from the story within the film, we see the real-world torch passing metaphor work as we observe Stallone's role in the franchise that he created noticeably diminishing - both on screen and behind the scenes. Just as he hands off the main role to rising star Michael B. Jordan, he has handed off writing and directing duties to Ryan Coogler (who Jordan served very well in 2013's "Fruitvale Station"). In less talented hands, this transition could have resulted in the dropping of the torch, but Coogler's updating of Stallone's legacy proves effective and entertaining and should appeal to fans of the original Rocky movies as well as fans of both Coogler and Jordan. Both equally emotive and with comic interruptions, Jordan and Stallone deliver impressive performances. Stallone in particular gives what has to be his career best performance since Rocky Balboa, and if this is his franchise swan song (owing to a devastating but befitting plot device) that's all the more reason why this film must be seen. Sylvester Stallone is excellent as the "Mickey"-esque Balboa. Although he didn't write the screenplay for Creed, he is one of the producers and his presence is felt. The dynamic between his character and Donnie is perfect. The right combination of old school and new school. One scene is indicative when Adonis takes a picture on his phone of Rocky's workout routine then tells him it's "in the cloud" to Rocky's bewilderment. Here, director and writer Ryan Coogler is reunited with Jordan. As titular lead, Jordan's performance is on part with Stallone's. He imbues his character with just the right amount of bravado, not cockiness, just confidence, hunger, and drive. He also trained and bulked up for the role. But he's not all fierce competitor, he has funny, sensitive sides as well. Coogler's team decided he should have a love interest. The relationship he forges with a local neo- soul artist played by Tessa Thompson (Dear White People) could have been syrupy, but thankfully it doesn't overshadow the main theme or feel forced. Frankly, some of the scenes with Thompson and Jordan are very good and so is their chemistry. Tony Bellew does well. On the whole, Creed is an gritty, emotional & exceptional crowd pleaser for Rocky fans & the new generations alike. If you have watched the original Rocky and think it is a near classic, then Creed is close. Maybe not a classic, because only time will tell. But it is close in terms of look and feel. There are scenes, tempo, performances, music, and of course the setting (Philadelphia) which harkens back to the award winning 1976 film. This is not a comparison piece, but Creed is what the earlier release of this year Southpaw was close to being; the best gritty, modern day boxing film of this decade.

Just seen this lastnight! I was so excited to see it because if you live in philly, you must watch rocky! and this was a great movie! took the rocky movies to the next level! a definte movie to go see!
Never have I seen a crowd get so riled up near the end. This movie had everything. Not a flop like I thought it was going to be. Great underdog movie and got me motivated.

Rocky is back and this time his story isn't just centered on him. Now it's Apolo Creed's son who takes the reigns (played by an outstanding Michael B. Jordan). Being a fan of the Rocky series, this entry is one of the best. I hope to see more boxing matches with Aldonis Creed in the future. The fight(s) are way more entertaining than the Mayweather Pacquiao fight. Hope this one is up for some awards because it is that good.

Everything you'd expect from a Rocky installment with a high level of execution. Sly's performance is charming and particularly noteworthy. It would be hard to dislike this movie, and I have a feeling that there will be more of them.
Great movie, Rocky fan or not, this movie is great.
Well done and a welcome addition to the franchise.

Happy that something related to Apollo survived in the Rocky series. After a disastrous timeline during the 80s and the 90s, Stallone came back strong in the rocky series, this continues in Creed. Though the timeline could be questioned about Creeds son's age.

Does it pass down the torch? Yes. Does it share similarities with the original "Rocky" film? Yes. Does this film stand on it's own? Absolutely! "Creed" follows the son of the late Apollo Creed as he hunts down Rocky Balboa to train him. In hopes to continue his fathers legacy while still maintaining his own name, young Adonis Creed will do whatever it takes to get into the ring. As he meets a young girl along the way, you completely buy into their connection and you never once think that it feels forced. This film is essentially about fighting for your name, but at its core it really is a release from the "Rocky" films and an introduction into the new generation. Sylvester Stallone and Michael B. Jordan share amazing chemistry, bringing me to tears on multiple occasions. "Creed" is easily one of the best entries in the franchise, even comparable to the original. With a great script, incredible performances, a story worthy of the title, and direction that puts you in the front row, "Creed" is fantastic! If I had one complaint, it would be that it might just share a few too similarities to the first film. By the end of the film I felt I was just accepting the conclusion. In the end, I loved this film from start to finish and I recommend seeing it in the theatres for the full experience. Terrific!
Great movie everyone must see this movie if you are a fan of the rocky movies

Absolutely loved it. It nails the heart of the first Rocky film with a modern update whilst still having a lot of nostalgic easter egg nods to series fans.. In other words providing a homage without feeling like its going through the motions for nostalgia's sake (*Cough* Jurassic World *cough*)..
One of those movies that you will be thinking about for days/ weeks afterward. Puts you in a completely different state of mind.

The seventh entry in the Rocky franchise is the best since the first Rocky and it doesn't even have Rocky's name in the title. Stallone literally passes the gloves to Michael B. Jordan, who plays Apollo Creed's son. Young Creed wants to be a boxer, but wants to do it without his father's name. He seeks out the now retired Rocky Balboa to train him Rocky is reluctant because of what happened to Apollo. But soon enough Rocky agrees to train him. The film mirrors the first Rocky, but the story is fresh tanks to director Ryan Coogler who seems to respect the franchise and the Rocky character. Stallone has never been better as an aging boxer who has lost everything in his life. He needs Creed as much as Creed needs him. It is like a father-son relationship the two have. The cast is great with Tess Thompson playing Creed's version of Adrian. But, she is more than just a love interest. Her character also has to go through some hard times as well. Jordan and Stallone are great together and for Jordan, this surely makes up for Fantastic Four. The final match is as thrilling as the first match between Rocky and Creed. But because the characters are written so well, the boxing felt second nature to the storylines. You care about these characters and you care what happens to them. This is a testament to the young director's respect for the source material and the cast's great chemistry and acting. I am not sure if this is going to start a new set of films, but Rocky has never been better.Grade: A
Absolutely the best one since the original.

A must see if you are a fan of the original Rocky movie. Amazing performances by Michael Jordan, Sylvester Stallone, and that girl, Tessa Thompson. The Philly street scenes will have you looking for the ghost of Mick, Rocky's original trainer. It's a good movie with great dialogue and magnificent performances which will allow old timers to reminisce, and new comers to look forward to more.
Great movie with alot of heart and it stays true to the rocky films

Creed is a film that from the trailers can be looked at as a continuation of the Rocky franchise, but it is actually more of a 'Rebirth' for the franchise and a passing of the baton in a way. My experience with the Rocky franchise is limited to half of the first film and bits and pieces of iconic moments and characters, but missing out on the previous Rocky films will not harm your experience with this film. This is definitely not a 'Rocky movie', it definitely stands on its own and the main focus of the film is Adonis Creed. Of course, being in the same universe and featuring the series' main protagonist does lead to many callbacks to the other Rocky films. Now i didn't know the significance of every reference, but i knew enough to know when they were referring to a past event. But these callbacks (apart from the obvious) are not crucial to the plot and really are just there for die hard fans of the series. The main focus of this film was the journey of Adonis Creed and his rise to hopefully live up to the legacy set by his father with help from Rocky Balboa himself. The story, this journey was incredible to see. There were not too many BIG moments in the film but it really didn't need any because this whole film was a progressive sequence of events that were building up intensity to a big finale. There were many intense training montages and very interesting and emotional storytelling sequences that all tie together the events of the film really really well. There was never a dull moment in its 2 hour runtime and i was glued to the screen and really interested in Adonis' story. He is a very strong minded, likeable and determined character who you really get behind and want him to succeed in every way. Michael B Jordan definitely redeemed himself for that Fant4stic disaster that wasn't necessarily his fault, but at least it can't be held against him now. He embodied the role and you really bought his character, wasn't over the top in any way and played a very grounded, realistic character. He conveyed emotion and determination very well and managed to eclipse the presence of Sylvester Stallone as Rocky Balboa at times. Having Rocky Balboa in the film and being a mentor and coach for Adonis was a really great aspect of the film that worked in every way. This could have easily been a very forced element where they just threw Rocky in a few scenes occasionally to make sure people know "Hey come see this film because...... Rocky". But he really was an integral part of the film and contributed to the plot, bought a slight tad of humour to lighten the mood occasionally and also really emphasis the emotional weight of some of the films key moments. Sylvester Stallone was great in the role, i can't speak for whether it compares to the other Rocky films but you could see that he was a very experienced boxer who has definitely been through a lot in his life. If anything, this film made me WANT to go and see the other Rocky films because even seeing him at this stage in his life was fascinating and i wanted to know more about the character. But despite the big name and the fact that he is so loved by film fans, he did play second fiddle to Michael B Jordan, and i don't think anyone should be mad about that. There was also one incredible moment in the film that was made even more amazing by the camera-work in this scene. There was a fight that was filmed so amazingly i was mesmerised and totally sucked into the scene. The entire fight was filmed with one continuous tracking shot that takes you all around the ring and made you feel like you were literally in the ring with these fighter, truly incredible film work right there. In the end, this was an incredible Boxing film, one of the best if not the best that i have ever seen that if you are a fan of the genre you should definitely see. Fans of the Rocky franchise will love this film for it's callbacks to the other films but as it is a passing of the baton per se, even if you are unfamiliar with the previous films it doesn't lessen the amazing experience you will have with this film. - 9.1
What a movie. Want to watch it again 5 minutes out of the theatre

After the last Rocky movie I felt like there was enough to be said about him. Sure he's a supporting character here, but in this particular movie Stallone gives his most powerful emotional performance than in all the other Rocky movies combined. Michael B. Jordan is excellent here as well, but Sly is the one to watch for. I wouldn't be surprised if he got an Oscar nomination for this one. The boxing action is great, and there's no 'Hollywood' ending here. In the words of Roger Ebert, two thumbs up.

Not only was the intensity of the film thrilling but the story behind the characters was crafted in such a way that the film generated a deeper meaning than boxing. I highly recommend watching this film, one of my all time favorites.
This movie was all that! Very inspirational.

Nothing like the original Rocky's. Slow start. The movie dragged on and on. Some of the training scenes were really cheesy. When Adonis is running through the streets of Philly, gangsters on dirt bikes and four wheelers are riding next to him doing wheelies. They tried to copy the DMX video. Adonis randomly switches training gyms. He only has one fight prior to the final. The finally fight scene is awful. The champion looks out of shape and noting like a champion boxer. Not worth seeing in theater.

It's an unbelievable piece of film making! Easily stands as it's own movie, and a fantastic one at that, then throw in the nods to Rocky movies of old and you have an instant classic. Sly could very well get nominated for best supporting actor, not a stretch at all. You must see this movie! One of the best of the year.

Exciting, motivational, and moving. Creed is exactly what i wanted it to be, giving two incredible performances by the leads, and a story that has enough twists and turns to keep you entertained. Creed is the best Rocky film since the original, even though it's technically not a Rocky film. Creed is a masterpiece, one of the best of 2015.

This is a great boxing movie, and a worthy coda to the Rocky series. Look, if you saw the first three Rocky flicks, you'll know this story, and it combines elements of each movie to the point where you know what's about to happen, down to the post-fight interview in the ring. But this one's directed tightly, the script wastes nothing and never gets maudlin, and Sly and Jordan are magic on the screen. If you weren't a fan of Rocky before, don't bother; this won't change your mind. But if you were, you'll get that feeling you had at the end of the first three.

A little dissapointed... Fight scenes are nicely done..Stallone does a great job as Rocky..The movie gets bogged down with a lifeless romance..bad music and not enough heart . what saves this film is its grittiness and once again its underdog story....It's like a new "Rocky for this generation"
Should have been rocky 1-4 then creed some years later. Very Very good movie. Stalone was the best, deepest Rocky He's ever played. Mike Jordan is very very good.
Solid, exactly what I thought it would be. I'd say the highlight was they stayed away from cheesy/cliche lines throughout the movie.
Breathtaking, Emotional, Inspiring. A true masterpiece. Oscar worthy performances from Michael B. Jordan and Sylvester Stallone. Definitely something truly special in Creed.

It doesn't break the ROCKY mold but it sure does energize it. Jordan is more than capable of carrying this, but I certainly hope that Sly is along for the ride as he is truly terrific in this new, understated role as trainer and mentor.

Brought back everything that made the first four rocky films so great. Jordan delivered an exceptional performance as did stallone. Easy to follow narrative that was very compelling, the fight scenes were absolutely spectacular.
It was everything you can expect from the Rocky franchise.

It's probably a bad idea to do a feel-good boxing movie in 2015, but what the hey, this is a really good one. Rocky Balboa: Everything I got has moved on and I'm [still] here...There's something immensely powerful about the way these last installments have depicted Rocky's character and condition as he approaches the end of his journey. Everything he cherished - his wife, best friend, best rival, career, health (and even son who moved to Canada) has either left his world or faded and yet he still comes out swinging (albeit with great support from his new mentee/son) to knock the f*ck out of life! The parallel is drawn too clearly between his life and time in the ring - get hit, get up, hit back harder. A fighter's life to the very end indeed. Creed - you got me good. I'm definitely sticking around more more!

I'm fairly certain that many people thought it was impossible for Stallone to milk his "Rocky" franchise & find another movie in it, but I am so glad he did. Stallone has long been completely overlooked and underestimated by the Hollywood machine, yet he returns yet again to the storyline that made him a star an not only find a story but makes his best "Rocky" movie since "Rocky!" I'm not going to go into the plot, to prevent giving away spoilers, but I will say that "Creed" is a movie that works on different levels and also tells two different stories to audience members depending upon their ages and life experiences. Older audience members (like me, who saw "Rocky" in the theatres & rooted for it to win Best Picture) can & will see the story through Rocky's eyes. Younger audience members, especially young adults struggling to make their own way & their own name, can & will see the story through Donnie's eyes.  It's also high time to stop making Stallone the butt of everyone's jokes & recognize himi for the extraordinary talent that he is. He *WILL* make you cry in "Creed," & he won't be overly-showy about it, either. There he'll be, just doing his usual "Rocky" shuffle, then *BAM* the audience is in tears. I was one of maybe 2 women in the theatre yesterday, so it isn't a girly thing. Guys were crying too.  Of course, a good story needs a good cast & everyone in "Creed" is just that. Michael B. Jordan is amazing & a possible Oscar contender, although my money is still on Jonny Depp. If I didn't already think Paul Rylands had a strong shot for "Best Supporting Actor," I'd strongly recommend the Academy announce that category is closed & hand the statue to Stallone. If Stallone doesn't even score a nomination for his performance, well, screw the Academy. While it would be nice for the establishment to finally acknowledge Stallone's talent without winking or crossing their fingers behind their backs, he's long since proven he doesn't need them--THEY need him.

My thanksgiving movie, and it was a good one. Creed marks not only the continuation of the Rocky franchise but a refreshing renewal of it. This isn't just about boxing, it's more about pursuing a passion, even when this passion may not seem to make sense on the face of it. You see this in the young Creed and in his love interest, Bianca. Brilliantly acted by Michael B. Jordan, it's difficult not to feel some of the frustration and pain as his mentor, Rocky, seemingly abandons him and the sense of pride and promise after the last fight. Here too, the writer emphasizes how important it is to have a support system and how even the strongest character can fall when this support is taken away. But, it's not about how many times you fall down that determines character, but how many times you get back up. Creed's character becomes stronger as the binds of the ongoing relationships build, but don't we all experience this as well? Frankly, one of the best films of the year, not to be missed.
