Rocky is one of the greatest sports movie put on the big screen. Not only was it one of the highest grossing films of 1976, but it also won an Oscar for Best Picture. So how could this successful Boxing film surpass the original. While Rocky II and III were decent sequels, Rocky IV was a but cheesy and V ruined the entire franchise over the next fifteen year until the release of Rocky Balboa. The film was good, but not as good as the first Rocky. People thought that the sixth film would end the Rocky franchise, but they were wrong. I first heard of Creed from an article I was reading on Facebook and casting Michael B. Jordan as Apollo Creed son was a fantastic idea, with Sylvester Stallone returning as the Italian Stallion. My little brother and I were anticipated about this film getting release. Then the film came and I decided to see it over the final Hunger Games movie, which I will sometime soon. After watching Creed, my thoughts changed about this film. Not only is this the greatest spin-off/ sequel, but one of my favorite films of 2015. Creed learns how to be its own movie without confusing the audience of seeing the previous films. The movie learns how to execute the typical underdog story that the audience have seen from the first Rocky. I actually cared about these characters of the struggles that they were going through. Michael B. Jordan plays as the son of Apollo Creed, Adonis Johnson, who wants to be a professional Boxer like his father, but doesn`t want to be known as the son of Apollo Creed. Johnson goes to Sylvester Stallone character Rocky for training and advise about going into the Boxing Ring. The relationship between these two character is incredible to follow. I actually felt emotion toward these two character together on the same screen. It`s a old vs new which is well balance out. For example, there`s a scene where Rocky makes a training list on a piece of paper and gives it to Adonis, but Adonis takes a picture of the list on his phone and goes off to train, making Rocky confuse on how much has change over the past forty years. This is both a spectacular and comedic scene in the movie. There is also a love interest for Adonis in this movie name Bianca, played by Tessa Thompson, who is a musician who is about to become deaf. This is a perfect love interest for this movie because she has character instead of the typical love interest who motivates the character through the struggle of the plot. The cinematography is glorious. There are moments when the film uses one shot for an entire scene. An example could be Adonis first fight when the camera was moving around the entire without switching to the next clip, similar to the cinematography in Birdman. The film was incredibly well shot in Philadelphia. It makes the audience feel like they are in the same urban environment with a mix of some ghetto environments since this is directed by Ryan Coogler, who previously directed Fruitvale Station, which had the same gritty environment as Creed. I adore the music score done in this film since its a mix of the original Rocky music with some background beats from the hip-hop genre. Its well compose and well executed that I`m actually of listening to it over and over again. I have no flaws with this film because everything from Creed is perfectly done that its actually a bit better than Rocky. The fighting is gory and glorious to watch, that it actually gave me an adrenaline rush every time there is a boxing scene. Creed is a strong movie to stand on its own and thats how most sequels and spinoff should be about. I hope this movie gets an Oscar nomination cause this is a perfect movie that deserves one.

CREED is a KO! Director, Ryan Coogler (Fruitvale Station) has created a modern masterpiece that honors all the best of the venerable Rocky franchise while introducing a deep new layer that stands fully on its own. Once again, Michael B. Jordan (who's middle initial stands for "Bakari" or "One Who Will Succeed") delivers yet another exceptional performance, this time as Adonis, the complex and troubled spawn of Rocky Balboa's late-great nemesis, Apollo Creed. Sylvester Stallone has never been better and easily earns Award recognition for his aging but wise champion-of-the-underdog reprise. In true Rocky spirit, the movie CREED is less about the destination than the mine-laden pathway to pursuing a dream. Along with Coogler, writer Aaron Covington have drafted a tightly paced script that swings you up and down with just the right amount of toughness, tenderness, promise and uncertainty -- not unlike boxing itself, as it builds to a satisfying finale. Coogler and Covington give great hope for the future of Hollywood. As a long time boxing fan, I love how Maryse Alberti (A.S.C.) respects the Sweet Science with arguably some of the best fight cinematography ever (she also did The Wrestler). While there are bonafide (how did they do that) moments of amazing skill during action scenes (Jordan clearly didn't use a stuntman for critical scenes), it's not all blood and sweat. Tessa Thompson (Dear White People) brings exquisite humanity to a beautiful but gritty alternative-R&B singer from Philly who's character demands further exploration (can't believe I'm actually looking forward to a sequel). In these times of cultural disharmony with tragic endings, CREED reminds us that the heart of a champion knows no color, ambition knows no gender, and everlasting hope knows no age. See Creed on the big screen with people you love - everyone will leave feeling just a little better than when they went in. Yes. -CC

First off let me say that I have been a life long Rocky fan. With that being said I went into this film very cautious as almost the entire cast and crew were brand new. The trailers looked good, but today a good trailer is not necessarily an indicator of a good film. Sylvester Stallone killed it as a much older and more breakable Rocky. Michael B. Jordan's performance was as good if not better than Sly's. I think that from this day forward anytime I see Jordan, I will think of him as Creed and not whatever character he is playing. The story was engrossing and well thought out. The film pays a great amount of respect to the Rocky films while at the same time carving out it's own place in boxing film history. Honestly I have no idea how accessible this film would be to someone who's never seen a Rocky film, but I think the way the story flows it wouldn't be too much of an issue. Again, highly recommended.

In the tradition of Rocky, Creed does not disappoint. That being said it is not Rocky. Growing up and in my adulthood I must've seen the entire Rocky series 10 times all through my life. Creed represents the passing of a torch to a new generation. Creed finds rocky very older and once again tryint to leave his fighting days behind him. He still has his small restaurant named after his deceased wife "Adrian" and he still makes frequent visits to her grave and now Paulie's too who it says died in 2012. Rocky beyond all is a loyal and loving person, which makes it impossibe in the end for him to turn his back on a new boxer named Adonis Johnson (Creed) who seeks his help. The illegitimate son of his former opponent turned best friend Apollo Creed. This movie is about Adonis's rise in the boxing circuit and Rocky finding his will to face a new kind of fight. This is definitely worth checking out if you grew up on Rocky and if you didn't its a great way to meet a classic character for the first time.

Certainly the best "Rocky" film we've seen since episode III. Lower-key, with better acting and cinematography. The fight scenes are still a bit over-the-top, but the way they are shot is refreshing and gives Creed its own vibe versus its predecessors. Michael B Jordan is well-suited to the role of a man trying to come to terms with his famous namesake. Tessa Thompson is mesmerizing but underused in the second half. It still has a bit of that Rocky rah-rah element and perhaps would have been better with a little less Stallone, but overall the movie works because it pays homage to the earlier films (especially III and IV) while forging its own path. The writing is on the wall for sequels. Rocky fans will appreciate this outing.

This movie surprised me. Even more, the story is not really that good; the new characters are poorly developed; and the movie made cheap attempts to look like something from 40 years ago. Yet....It worked. CREED kept me interested the entire 132 minutes--it never got boring, and I never looked at my watch. The action is spaced out, but there's enough for us boxing fans...and the boxing itself was done with more than a reasonable amount of reality. The real gem IMO, is Stallone's acting. I think had Stallone never found so much success in action movies, we might have seen an actor wit ha career more like that of George Clooney or Jeff Bridges....a career with some acting roles that deserved praise for acting itself....this movie provided a dose of that. A move worth watching for sure.

Emotions ran high for me during this film. As a young man who has experienced his fair share of life struggles and tribulations, CREED was a refreshing reminder to me, and many others in the theater, that every person alive today is in control of their own destiny. A film that is dominated by it's two lead performances, CREED is not just another ROCKY film. It, like our hero himself, establishes it's own unique identity that is almost completely separate from it's predecessor, Director Ryan Coogler struck gold yet again, and with a familiar face appearing as our titular character. Now, the performances.Michael B. Jordan delivers his finest performance in a film since his role in the critically praised TV show, FRIDAY NIGHT LIGHTS. Jordan never comes off a pouty or cynical, despite his characters "silver spoon" background. Adonis "Donny" Creed is portrayed as a confused but determined young man, eager to prove himself and to make it to the boxing world that his father dominated, to confirm his place in the world but also to prove that he exists. If Jordan were a pitcher; he just pitched a shutout.There isn't much to say about Ol' Sly Stallone's performance in this film. After finally realizing that the franchise had a better chance at surviving in more capable, younger hands, Sylvester made perhaps the greatest move he's made so far in his post-80's career, He. Actually. Acted. Acting again as the beloved (but incredibly creepy as far as box office bomb ROCKY BALBOA goes) Rocky Balboa, Stallone gives a breathtaking, emotionally exhausting performance which is without a doubt the best of his career. I can't put into words how incredible this performance is without shivering at the keyboard I'm sitting at right now. While many actors and actresses and actresses of yesteryear have provided us with an accurate look into chemotherapy and the effects of cancer, none struck truer to the core of me than this performance. If Stallone doesn't receive an Oscar nomination for this performance, I think it might be time to seriously reconsider what it means to have the words "Oscar Award Winning" attached to your name. Bravo, Sly. Bravo.

'Creed' is better than I could ever imagine, even being the third greatest movie in the 'Rocky' saga! Though this also carves out a singular, compelling story for the son of Apollo Creed. Director Ryan Coogler respects the boxing movie and the 'Rocky' movies. He shows restraint when needed, a sly sense of humor, great understanding of the characters and also gets one of Stallone's best performances. Michael B. Jordan gives a star making performance. Stallone's performance is sweet, controlled and even heartbreaking. This might even be Oscar caliber work for Stallone, don't be surprised about a supporting actor nod. I saw an early screening of Creed a week ago, so I thought with it releasing today I would give ya'll my opinion on it! As a big Rocky fan I came into Creed with some relative high expectations. They were met and then some! Creed centers around Adonis Johnson (Michael B Jordan) the bastard son of Apollo Creed (Carl Weathers). Adonis has constantly lived with a chip on his shoulders. When he was young he bounced around to orphanage to orphanage until he was found by Apollo's wife Mary (Phylicia Rashad) and brought to live with her. Several years later Adonis is working at an office, but secretly travels down to Mexico to box. Fightings in his blood and he's really good at it. He decides to quit one day and travel to Philadelphia to seek out Rocky Balboa (Sylvester Stallone). Adonis want's Rocky to train him much like his father trained Rocky (during the events of the third film after Mickey died). Rocky is reluctant at first, but soon see's a fire in Adonis that reminds him of Apollo. Rocky trains Adonis and get's him set for a fight which eventually leads to an even bigger bout...for the both of them. Not spoiling anything here, but the fight scenes in this film are the best I've seen out of all the Rocky films. It's faced paced and realistic looking. The two main leads in Adonis and Rocky work off each other so well. It's a great chemistry between the two and I just loved the nods to the older films. The film also stars Tessa Thompson as Blanca, Adonis's neighbor that's a musician that he eventually falls in love with. This part of the movie is probably the weakest aspect because of the lack of screen time between the two, but it didn't take away from anything for me. The movie raises the question what's in a name? Adonis doesn't go by the Creed name because he feels people don't think he's earned it and that's the only reason he get to fight, but by the end he soon realizes that there's more to a name than just the fame or popularity. Regardless, this movie was a blast and I highly recommend checking this out during this holiday week!

Ryan Coogler's Creed delivers on everything that a great boxing film should, and represents a full return to form for Rocky. Directed by superstar in the making Ryan Coogler, and starring powerful performances from Michael B. Jordan and Sylvester Stallone the film is amazing. Creed is exhilarating, beautifully acted, while honoring the previous Rocky films lovingly. The film may be a little too familiar at times, but at least approaches it's overused plot lines with a different take. From the opening scene the film captures your attention, showing us a glimpse into who this character is "a fighter." The film remains an exhilarating journey with this character, who is easy to connect with. As the film progresses, Coogler mixes old techniques like the famous Rocky slow motion sequences, with newer (less used) techniques like very intimate fight sequences, where the camera helps the viewer feel like they're standing in the ring. The film will draw you in from the moment it starts, to the moment it ends. One reason the film is so exhilarating is the terrific acting of Michael B. Jordan, who leads this journey. Once again teaming up with director Ryan Coogler Jordan anchors the film, and in the process creates a relatable, and human main character. On this note, after seeing "Creed" and "Fruitvale Station" I would be willing to make the bold statement that I think Ryan Coogler is on his way to becoming the next Scorsese. All of this being said what may be even more satisfying is seeing Sylvester Stallone return to form as Rocky Balboa. Some may criticize the movie for not bringing a lot of original plot lines to the movie, they would be right. However, while not very original the film handles these plot lines from a different perspective. No longer are we watching the nobody rising up against the odds, now we see a man trying to get out of the larger than life shadows of a man he never knew. Those who love the Rocky films recognize the slow motion moments in almost every film, and the iconic way the boxing matches were choreographed. Creed departs from the overuse of slow motion and more adapts the fight choreography of Raging Bull, while still mixing the essence of the Rocky fight scenes.  The way Coogler mixes old with new in many different ways helps make the whole film feel like the story it's telling. Coogler captures the tone of the older Rocky films, while also making a film distinctly different. Michael B. Jordan and Sylvester Stallone deliver, and Creed ends up being exactly what fans hoped it would be. In the end if you have the time go see Creed, it's a terrific 2 hours to spend.

Back in 2013, first-time feature director Ryan Coogler wowed the independent film world with his harrowing and extraordinarily thoughtful movie about the 2009 murder of Oscar Grant III�by Oakland transit police, entitled�"Fruitvale Station" (after the Bay Area Rapid Transit, or BART, station where Grant was killed). Born in 1986, Coogler is not yet 30, and here he comes with a second - much bigger - movie,�"Creed," about the son of the great fictional boxer Apollo Creed (from the�"Rocky" films). Starring Michael B. Jordan (Grant in�"Fruitvale Station"), the film treads much the same territory as that of�every other boxing film ever made (you know, stuff about how your most dangerous opponent is YOU), recycling materials (and character arcs) from the original�"Rocky," as well, yet has such heart and spirit that in spite of its lack of originality is terrific fun to watch. Unless you don't like boxing movies. In which case, what are you doing in the theater?It's an unusual step for a relatively young and untested director to take, for sure.�"Creed"�is not quite a franchise film, yet does qualify as a spin-off, even bringing Sylvester Stallone back as Rocky; quite a feat, considering how happy the Italian Stallion was with the way�"Rocky Balboa," in 2006, had concluded the series (according to�"The New York Times," anyway). At first it may seem far-fetched to imagine the filmmaker behind such an intimate drama like�"Fruitvale Station" tackling well-known universe, but as the film progresses, it quickly becomes clear that the protagonists of both stories share a lot in common, and not just because they're played by the same actor. Adonis Creed - Apollo's son - is a boy in a man's body, struggling to mentally grow into his physical size and join the adult world. Where Jordan's Oscar Grant has his mother as a needed mentor, his Creed has Rocky; both need guidance to navigate the pitfalls of responsibility. And both have a supportive woman (of course, what successful cinematic man doesn't?) by their side (as did Rocky). Anyone who doesn't know�how�this particular film is going to end has not been paying attention to the signpost markers.�Just as in the first�"Rocky" film, there's a preening self-involved antagonist for our hero, who refuses to acknowledge the underdog's validity as a contender. Just as in the first�"Rocky" film, there's the woman urging her man to be better. And just as in the first�Rocky film, there's a trainer doing his best to get the young wannabe ready for the big fight. There's no question that it's a great twist that Rocky is now the grizzled veteran, but lay the first film side by side with�"Creed" and it's hard to distinguish the two. Except, you know, that now our main guy is African-American, which�could have allowed Coogler - African-American, himself - to discuss issues of race in the boxing world. But he doesn't. So what we're left with is an entertaining riff on a popular boxing legend, but a riff compromised by formula (aren't riffs usually more improvisatory?). Coogler and Jordan (and even Stallone)�most definitely confirm�their talents here (though poor Tessa Thompson, from�"Dear White People," has nothing to work with); I just wish that talent had been used in service of something truly new and fresh, upholding the promise of their first collaboration.�Here's hoping for Round 3!

Being a big fan of the Rocky franchise, I was very excited for Creed. The trailers were fabulous and I really love Ryan Coogler's first picture: Fruitvale Station. I was also very curious to see where the franchise would go after Rocky Balboa (which I haven't seen). Well, Creed was utterly incredible, making it one of the biggest surprises of 2015!Michael B. Jordan delivers yet another fantastic performance as Adonis Creed. He is so likeable and relatable, and his emotional range is huge. The rest of the supporting cast work well, including the clich�d British villain. However, Sylvester Stallone is the real star here. Just when you thought he had become a parody of himself, he comes and gives a possibly Oscar worthy performance as Rocky Balboa! Though the plot of Creed is your clich� boxing movie plot, it actually works in its favour! I won't reveal anything, but some moments almost had me tearing up. The fighting scenes were incredibly filmed, with many long-takes that were expertly directed. The finale of the movie also had my heart-pounding like no other film has done so far this year!The editing, cinematography and writing were all excellent, with many memorable moments. The musical score also lives up to the Rocky standard!Overall, Creed was a huge surprise! It had excellent acting, fantastic fighting sequences and a very intriguing story. See it!RATING: 9.5/10

I've only seen the first Rocky so I don't have a whole lot of character development in my head for the Rocky character but that all doesn't really mater if you just know that 6 Rocky movies happened. Jordan is great and could really drive another franchise and do it well. The big revelation in this movie is Sylvester Stallone himself. Look, I have not seen most of Stallone's films so saying this is his best performance isn't saying much. He puts so much compassion and humor into this performance and it is unlike I've ever seen him before. This far down the sequel chain, let's be honest...expectations are limited. If you plan to see the Creed movie, you know what you're in for, for the most part. I have to say, this film was a pleasant surprise. Makers of Creed managed to incorporate the spirit of the Rocky franchise while recreating a story line away from the series. Yes, there are some moments in the movie that are as predictable as a slow right hook, but Creed manages to rise above. This isn't a film for the art house movie snob and you may see some reviews that thumb their nose at it. For the person willing to plunk down ten bucks or more to get two hours worth of entertainment, this is well worthy of the investment. Lastly, I expect Sylvester Stallone to earn an Oscar nomination for his supporting role in the film. The one real surprise in the movie was that he was allowed to act again, maybe for the first time since the original Rocky. And he nails it.

Boxing movies generally have a lot of the same plot points, and this one is no different. Before I give my thoughts on this film, I would just like to mention that I saw this at a very early screening. This is important because seeing a film with no official reviews lets you form a opinion much easier. Now, we all know and love Rocky movies. They are inspirational, and a huge part of the 80?s. Creed was a success for me because it followed the traditional boxing movie formula well. Yes, it was cliche at times but overall it was enjoyable. Michael B Jordan was a great lead/Rocky character. He had the acting chops, the look, and the heart. It's not easy to pull off heavy, emotional scenes, and he did with ease. The chemistry between Jordan and Tessa Thompson was very good as well. I totally believed their chemistry and all the love scenes. Now, the character you have all been waiting for. Rocky fricking Balboa. He is an American hero and beloved by all. How is he in this film? Great. As usual Rocky is so damn lovable and gives great advice to all. Stallone added humor to the character which I did not expect. I loved it though! The story of this film is fine. It's a typical boxing movie plot, which is good, but could have been better. Ryan Coogler, the director, really did a great job. I liked his overall direction and style for the movie. Same style as his previous film, "Fruitvale Station" which was fantastic. As for negatives, the story was fine, but nothing special. I feel Coogler could have gone deeper into Creed's backstory and his relationship with his mother. Also, some scenes dragged on way too long and felt very unnecessary to the story. I did like this film and you should see it in a theater near you.

Yes, it's still a passing of the torch, but come one, Stallone is 69 years old, and they did in the best way possible.Also, no spoilers, but the cinematography of Creed's first pro fight is Jaw droppingly good.

Passionate and powerfully acted, Creed serves as a celebration of life, a tale of redemption while honoring the past it's truly a triumph for star Michael B. Jordan and Sylvester Stallone. Ryan Coogler is the real deal, offering a raw, gritty feel that pays tribute yet respect the past predecessors of this franchise. Michael B. Jordan shows sincerity as a hard working, obstacle fighting "Square" who overcomes odds giving you that glimmer that you're staring at what seems to be a parallel to a young Sly in Rocky. Worthy of the legacy of Creed and remains faithful to the legacy of Balboa. One fighting for their life the other fighting for "A life." One of the best films I've seen this year. Already amped to see where this franchise goes next.

No, it's not Rocky VII, although it is a continuation of the franchise. In my opinion, this is an attempt to reboot the franchise. It's pretty predictable, but fun to watch, although there are some lulls. But there's quite some humor, although Stallone's Balboa is harder to understand, than ever, with his constant mumbling. (Note to remind Pops to get the closed captioning device.) But that's the character. And as good of an actor that Jordan is, even with a buffed-up physique, I don't see him as a prize fighter in reality, much less going up for the title, and even less of a chance of winning. But, the storyline builds on that premise, which ends up becoming yet another Rocky movie. However, unlike the other, earlier Rocky movies, I didn't find myself moved to root for the underdog in this one.

Just watched an advanced screening for "Creed". This is not only a worthy sequel to the "Rocky", but a great way to continue the franchise. All of the acting was fantastic across the board. The characters are fully formed and the directing is perfect. Some of the fight sequences had be choreographed so well that continuous stedi cam shots without breaking the action left my jaw on the theater floor. SPOILERS: DO NOT READ FURTHER IF YOU DON'T WANT THE FILM RUINED> YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED>>>>>>The character of Rocky in the film comes full circle. I honestly had a lump in my throat and held back tears for the second half of the film. A well written send off for the character. I could see why Stallone made the film. If you love this franchise you will not be disappointed. The film ended with a round of applause as the credits rolled. If you want to see a positive uplifting film this Thanksgiving then get your tickets to "Creed", sit back, and be entertained. Real heart and soul on par with the original film.

Sylvester Stallone is back as the punchy not so good talking Rocky, he even has a scene where he demonstrates that he can actually act a bit, which I felt he nailed. While not as moving as Up, the scene was pretty moving. Others may call it formulaic but, definitely worth seeing if you enjoy the Rocky franchise. As the title suggests this movie isn't about Rocky he just happens to be in it (a lot), but it really is Michael B. Jordan as Adonis who carries the movie. As with any other Rocky movie there aren't many female roles, two, but both are played as strong people. Tessa Thompson as Bianca especially plays the role of a strong person who has her own life, goals, and drive. While you only see her when her life is intersecting with the life of Adonis, it is made clear that her life is not about being a cheerleader in need of support in his.
